The group has also used a tool that acts as a proxy to allow C2 even if the victim is behind a router. APT28 has also used a machine to relay and obscure communications between CHOPSTICK and their server.[2][3][4]
An APT3 downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.[5]
APT39 used custom tools to create SOCK5 proxies between infected hosts.[6]
AuditCred can utilize proxy for communications.[7]
The "ZJ" variant of BACKSPACE allows "ZJ link" infections with Internet access to relay traffic from "ZJ listen" to a command server.[8]
BADCALL functions as a proxy server between the victim and C2 server.[9]
Cardinal RAT can act as a reverse proxy.[10]
CHOPSTICK used a proxy server between victims and the C2 server.[11]

Cobalt Strike can be configured to have commands relayed over a peer-to-peer network of infected hosts. This can be used to limit the number of egress points, or provide access to a host without direct internet access.[12]
Dridex contains a backconnect module for tunneling network traffic through a victim's computer. Infected computers become part of a P2P botnet that can relay C2 traffic to other infected peers.[13]
Duqu can be configured to have commands relayed over a peer-to-peer network of infected hosts if some of the hosts do not have Internet access.[14]
FLIPSIDE is a simple proxy that creates an outbound RDP connection.[15]
Gazer identifies a proxy server if it exists and uses it to make HTTP requests.[16]
HARDRAIN uses the command cmd.exe /c netsh firewall add portopening TCP 443 "adp" and makes the victim machine function as a proxy server.[17]
HOPLIGHT has multiple proxy options that mask traffic between the malware and the remote operators.[19]
HTRAN can proxy TCP socket connections to obfuscate command and control infrastructure.[20][21]
InvisiMole can function as a proxy to create a serve that relays communication between the client and C&C server.[22]
jRAT can serve as a SOCKS proxy server.[23]
Lazarus Group uses multiple proxies to obfuscate network traffic from victims.[24]
menuPass has used a global service provider's IP as a proxy for C2 traffic from a victim.[25][26]
MuddyWater has controlled POWERSTATS from behind a proxy network to obfuscate the C2 location.[27]
netsh can be used to set up a proxy tunnel to allow remote host access to an infected host.[28]
PoshC2 contains modules that allow for use of proxies in command and control.[29]
POWERSTATS has connected to C2 servers through proxies.[30]
QuasarRAT can communicate over a reverse proxy using SOCKS5.[31][32]
Regin leveraged several compromised universities as proxies to obscure its origin.[33]
Remcos uses the infected hosts as SOCKS5 proxies to allow for tunneling and proxying.[34]
Socksbot can start SOCKS proxy threads.[35]
Soft Cell used a modified version of HTRAN to redirect connections between networks.[36]
Strider has used local servers with both local network and Internet access to act as internal proxy nodes to exfiltrate data from other parts of the network without direct Internet access.[37]
Turla RPC backdoors have included local UPnP RPC proxies.  [38]
A TYPEFRAME variant can force the compromised system to function as a proxy server.[39]
Ursnif  has used a peer-to-peer (P2P) network for C2.[40][41]
Vasport is capable of tunneling though a proxy.[42]
XTunnel relays traffic between a C2 server and a victim.[43]
mitigations: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific C2 protocol used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool C2 signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.[44]
permissions_required: Process use of network, Process monitoring, Netflow/Enclave netflow, Packet capture
title: Connection Proxy

data_sources: API monitoring, Binary file metadata, DLL monitoring, Windows Registry, Windows event logs, Process command-line parameters, Process monitoring
description: Windows Control Panel items are utilities that allow users to view and adjust computer settings. Control Panel items are registered executable (.exe) or Control Panel (.cpl) files, the latter are actually renamed dynamic-link library (.dll) files that export a CPlApplet function. [1] [2] Control Panel items can be executed directly from the command line, programmatically via an application programming interface (API) call, or by simply double-clicking the file. [1] [2] [3]
detection: Monitor and analyze activity related to items associated with CPL files, such as the Windows Control Panel process binary (control.exe) and the Control_RunDLL and ControlRunDLLAsUser API functions in shell32.dll. When executed from the command line or clicked, control.exe will execute the CPL file (ex: control.exe file.cpl) before Rundll32 is used to call the CPL's API functions (ex: rundll32.exe shell32.dll,Control_RunDLL file.cpl). CPL files can be executed directly via the CPL API function with just the latter Rundll32 command, which may bypass detections and/or execution filters for control.exe. [2]
examples: Reaver drops and executes a malicious CPL file as its payload.[4]
mitigations: Identify and block potentially malicious and unknown .cpl files by using application whitelisting tools, like Windows Defender Application Control, AppLocker, or Software Restriction Policies where appropriate.
Restrict storage and execution of Control Panel items to protected directories, such as C:\Windows, rather than user directories.
title: Control Panel Items

data_sources: Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters, Authentication logs, Windows event logs
description: Adversaries with a sufficient level of access may create a local system or domain account. Such accounts may be used for persistence that do not require persistent remote access tools to be deployed on the system.
detection: Collect data on account creation within a network. Event ID 4720 is generated when a user account is created on a Windows system and domain controller. [16] Perform regular audits of domain and local system accounts to detect suspicious accounts that may have been created by an adversary.
examples: APT3 has been known to create or enable accounts, such as support_388945a0.[1]
Calisto has the capability to add its own account to the victim's machine.[2]
Carbanak can create a Windows account.[3]
Dragonfly 2.0 created accounts on victims, including administrator accounts, some of which appeared to be tailored to each individual staging target.[4][5]
Empire has a module for creating a new domain user or local user if permissions allow.[6]
Flame can create backdoor accounts with the login "HelpAssistant" with the Limbo module.[7][8]
HiddenWasp creates a user account as a means to provide initial persistence to the compromised machine.[9]
Leafminer used a tool called Imecab to set up a persistent remote access account on the victim machine.[10]
Mis-Type may create a temporary user on the system named "Lost_{{Unique Identifier}}."[11]
The net user username \password and net user username \password \domain commands in Net can be used to create a local or domain account respectively.[12]
Pupy can user PowerView to perform "net user" commands and create local system and domain accounts.[13]
S-Type may create a temporary user on the system named "Lost_{{Unique Identifier}}" with the password "pond~!@6"{{Unique Identifier}}."[11]
ServHelper may create a new account and add the new user to the "Remote Desktop Users" and "Administrators" groups.[14]
Soft Cell created rogue, high-privileged domain user accounts to maintain access across waves of a compromise.[15]
mitigations: Use multi-factor authentication for user and privileged accounts.
Configure access controls and firewalls to limit access to domain controllers and systems used to create and manage accounts.
Protect domain controllers by ensuring proper security configuration for critical servers.
Do not allow domain administrator accounts to be used for day-to-day operations that may expose them to potential adversaries on unprivileged systems.
title: Create Account

data_sources: API monitoring, Process monitoring, PowerShell logs, Process command-line parameters
description: Credential dumping is the process of obtaining account login and password information, normally in the form of a hash or a clear text password, from the operating system and software. Credentials can then be used to perform Lateral Movement and access restricted information.
detection: Windows
examples: APT1 has been known to use credential dumping.[17]
APT28 regularly deploys both publicly available and custom password retrieval tools on victims.[18][19]
APT3 has used a tool to dump credentials by injecting itself into lsass.exe and triggering with the argument "dig." The group has also used a tools to dump passwords from browsers.[20]
APT32 used Mimikatz, GetPassword_x64, and  customized versions of Windows Credential Dumper, HookChangePassword, and Outlook Credential Dumper to harvest credentials.[21][22]
APT33 has used a variety of publicly available tools like LaZagne, Mimikatz, Gpppassword, SniffPass, and ProcDump to dump credentials.[23][24]
APT37 has used a credential stealer known as ZUMKONG that can harvest usernames and passwords stored in browsers.[25]
APT39 has used Mimikatz, Ncrack, Windows Credential Editor and ProcDump to dump credentials.[26]
Astaroth uses an external software known as NetPass to recover passwords.[27]
Axiom has been known to dump credentials.[28]
Some Backdoor.Oldrea samples contain a publicly available Web browser password recovery tool.[29]
BRONZE BUTLER has used various tools to perform credential dumping.[30]
Cachedump can extract cached password hashes from a system’s registry.[17]
Carbanak obtains Windows logon password details.[31]
ChChes steals credentials stored inside Internet Explorer.[32]
Cleaver has been known to dump credentials.[33]
Cobalt Strike can recover hashed passwords.[34]

CosmicDuke collects user credentials, including passwords, for various programs and browsers, including popular instant messaging applications, Web browsers, and email clients. Windows account hashes, domain accounts, and LSA secrets are also collected, as are WLAN keys.[35]

Password stealer and NTLM stealer modules in CozyCar harvest stored credentials from the victim, including credentials used as part of Windows NTLM user authentication. CozyCar has also executed Mimikatz for further victim penetration.[36]
Crimson contains a module to steal credentials from Web browsers on the victim machine.[37]
Daserf leverages Mimikatz and Windows Credential Editor to steal credentials.[38]
Dragonfly 2.0 dropped and executed SecretsDump and CrackMapExec, tools that can dump password hashes.[39][40][41]
Emotet has been observed dropping browser and password grabber modules including Mimikatz.[42]
Empire contains an implementation of Mimikatz to gather credentials from memory.[43]
Fgdump can dump Windows password hashes.[17]
FIN5 has dumped credentials from victims. Specifically, the group has used the tool GET5 Penetrator to look for remote login and hard-coded credentials.[44][45]
FIN6 has used Windows Credential Editor for credential dumping, as well as Metasploit’s PsExec NTDSGRAB module to obtain a copy of the victim's Active Directory database. [46][47]
FIN8 harvests credentials using Invoke-Mimikatz or Windows Credentials Editor (WCE).[48]
GreyEnergy has a module for Mimikatz to collect Windows credentials from the victim’s machine.[49]
gsecdump can dump Windows password hashes and LSA secrets.[50]
H1N1 dumps usernames and passwords from Firefox, Internet Explorer, and Outlook.[51]
HOPLIGHT has the capability to harvest credentials and passwords.    [53]
SecretsDump and Mimikatz modules within Impacket can perform credential dumping to obtain account and password information.[54]
Ke3chang has dumped credentials, including by using Mimikatz.[55][56]
Koadic can gather hashed passwords by dumping SAM/SECURITY hive and gathers domain controller hashes from NTDS.[57]
KONNI can steal profiles (containing credential information) from Firefox, Chrome, and Opera.[58]
LaZagne can perform credential dumping to obtain account and password information.[59]
Lazarus Group leveraged Mimikatz to extract Windows Credentials of currently logged-in users and steals passwords stored in browsers.[60]
Leafminer used several tools for retrieving login and password information.[61]
Leviathan has used publicly available tools to dump password hashes.[62]
Lslsass can dump active logon session password hashes from the lsass process.[17]
Magic Hound stole domain credentials from Microsoft Active Directory Domain Controller and leveraged Mimikatz.[63]
Matroyshka is capable of stealing Outlook passwords.[64][65]
menuPass has used a modified version of pentesting tools wmiexec.vbs and secretsdump.py to dump credentials.[32][66]

Mimikatz performs credential dumping to obtain account and password information useful in gaining access to additional systems and enterprise network resources. It contains functionality to acquire information about credentials in many ways, including from the LSA, SAM table, credential vault, DCSync/NetSync, and DPAPI.[67][15][68][69]
MimiPenguin can dump process memory and extract clear-text credentials.[70]
Mivast has the capability to gather NTLM password information.[71]
Molerats used the public tool BrowserPasswordDump10 to dump passwords saved in browsers on victims.[72]
MuddyWater has performed credential dumping with Mimikatz, LaZagne, and other tools, including by dumping passwords saved in victim web browsers and email.[73][74]
Net Crawler uses credential dumpers such as Mimikatz and Windows Credential Editor to extract cached credentials from Windows systems.[33]
Night Dragon has dumped account hashes with Carbanak and cracked them with Cain & Abel.[75]
NotPetya contains a modified version of Mimikatz to help gather credentials that are later used for lateral movement.[76][77][69]
OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as Mimikatz and LaZagne to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[78][79][63]
OLDBAIT collects credentials from Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox, Eudora, and several email clients.[80]

Olympic Destroyer contains a module that tries to obtain credentials from LSASS, similar to Mimikatz. These credentials are used with PsExec and Windows Management Instrumentation to help the malware propagate itself across a network.[81]
OnionDuke steals credentials from its victims.[35]
Patchwork dumped the login data database from \AppData\Local\Google\Chrome\User Data\Default\Login Data.[82]

PinchDuke steals credentials from compromised hosts. PinchDuke's credential stealing functionality is believed to be based on the source code of the Pinch credential stealing malware (also known as LdPinch). Credentials targeted by PinchDuke include ones associated with The Bat!, Yahoo!, Mail.ru, Passport.Net, Google Talk, Netscape Navigator, Mozilla Firefox, Mozilla Thunderbird, Internet Explorer, Microsoft Outlook, WinInet Credential Cache, and Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP).[35]
PLATINUM has used keyloggers that are also capable of dumping credentials.[83]
Poseidon Group conducts credential dumping on victims, with a focus on obtaining credentials belonging to domain and database servers.[84]
PoshC2 contains an implementation of Mimikatz to gather credentials from memory.[85]
PowerSploit contains a collection of Exfiltration modules that can harvest credentials from Group Policy Preferences, Windows vault credential objects, or using Mimikatz.[86][87]
POWERTON has the ability to dump password hashes.[24]
A module in Prikormka collects passwords stored in applications installed on the victim.[88]
Pupy executes Mimikatz using PowerShell and can also perform pass-the-ticket and use Lazagne for harvesting credentials.[89]
pwdump can be used to dump credentials.[90]
QuasarRAT can obtain passwords from common browsers and FTP clients.[91][92]
RedLeaves can gather browser usernames and passwords.[93]
Remsec can dump the SAM database.[94]
Revenge RAT has a plugin for credential harvesting.[95]
ROKRAT steals credentials stored in Web browsers by querying the sqlite database and leveraging the Windows Vault mechanism.[96]
Soft Cell used a modified version of Mimikatz along with a PowerShell-based Mimikatz to dump credentials on the victim machines.[97]
Sowbug has used credential dumping tools.[98]
Stealth Falcon malware gathers passwords from multiple sources, including Windows Credential Vault, Internet Explorer, Firefox, Chrome, and Outlook.[99]
Stolen Pencil gathers credentials using Moafee and Procdump.[100]

Strider has registered its persistence module on domain controllers as a Windows LSA (Local System Authority) password filter to dump credentials any time a domain, local user, or administrator logs in or changes a password.[101]
Suckfly used a signed credential-dumping tool to obtain victim account credentials.[102]
TEMP.Veles has used Mimikatz and a custom tool, SecHack, to harvest credentials.[103]
Threat Group-3390 actors have used gsecdump and a modified version of Mimikatz called Wrapikatz to dump credentials. They have also dumped credentials from domain controllers.[104][105]
Trojan.Karagany can dump passwords and save them into \ProgramData\Mail\MailAg\pwds.txt.[29]
Unknown Logger is capable of stealing usernames and passwords from browsers on the victim machine.[106]
Windows Credential Editor can dump credentials.[107]
mitigations: Manage the access control list for "Replicating Directory Changes" and other permissions associated with domain controller replication.[108][109]

With Windows 10, Microsoft implemented new protections called Credential Guard to protect the LSA secrets that can be used to obtain credentials through forms of credential dumping. It is not configured by default and has hardware and firmware system requirements. It also does not protect against all forms of credential dumping.[110][111]
Ensure that local administrator accounts have complex, unique passwords across all systems on the network.

>WindowsDo not put user or admin domain accounts in the local administrator groups across systems unless they are tightly controlled, as this is often equivalent to having a local administrator account with the same password on all systems. Follow best practices for design and administration of an enterprise network to limit privileged account use across administrative tiers.###LinuxScraping the passwords from memory requires root privileges. Follow best practices in restricting access to privileged accounts to avoid hostile programs from accessing such sensitive regions of memory.[113]<
On Windows 8.1 and Windows Server 2012 R2, enable Protected Process Light for LSA.[114]
Limit credential overlap across accounts and systems by training users and administrators not to use the same password for multiple accounts.
title: Credential Dumping

description: Adversaries may search local file systems and remote file shares for files containing passwords. These can be files created by users to store their own credentials, shared credential stores for a group of individuals, configuration files containing passwords for a system or service, or source code/binary files containing embedded passwords.
detection: While detecting adversaries accessing these files may be difficult without knowing they exist in the first place, it may be possible to detect adversary use of credentials they have obtained. Monitor the command-line arguments of executing processes for suspicious words or regular expressions that may indicate searching for a password (for example: password, pwd, login, secure, or credentials). See Valid Accounts for more information.
examples: APT3 has a tool that can locate credentials in files on the file system such as those from Firefox or Chrome.[3]
Azorult can steal credentials in files belonging to common software such as Skype, Telegram, and Steam.[4]
BlackEnergy has used a plug-in to gather credentials stored in files on the host by various software programs, including The Bat! email client, Outlook, and Windows Credential Store.[5][6]
Emotet has been observed leveraging a module that retrieves passwords stored on a system for the current logged-on user.[7][8]
Empire can use various modules to search for files containing passwords.[9]
jRAT can capture passwords from common chat applications such as MSN Messenger, AOL, Instant Messenger, and and Google Talk.[10]
LaZagne can obtain credentials from browsers, chats, databases, mail, and WiFi.[11]

Mimikatz's DPAPI module can harvest protected credentials stored and/or cached by browsers and other user applications by interacting with Windows cryptographic application programming interface (API) functions.[12][13]
MuddyWater has run a tool that steals passwords saved in victim email.[14]
Olympic Destroyer contains a module that tries to obtain stored credentials from web browsers.[15]

If an initial connectivity check fails, pngdowner attempts to extract proxy details and credentials from Windows Protected Storage and from the IE Credentials Store. This allows the adversary to use the proxy credentials for subsequent requests if they enable outbound HTTP access.[16]
PoshC2 contains modules for searching for passwords in local and remote files.[17]
Proton gathers credentials in files for 1password, and keychains.[18]
QuasarRAT can obtain passwords from FTP clients.[19][20]
Smoke Loader searches for files named logins.json to parse for credentials.[21]
Stolen Pencil has used tools that are capable of obtaining credentials from saved mail.[22]
TA505 has used malware to gather credentials from FTP clients and Outlook.[23]
TrickBot can obtain passwords stored in files from several applications such as Outlook, Filezilla, and WinSCP. Additionally, it searches for the ".vnc.lnk" affix to steal VNC credentials.[24][25]
Turla has gathered credentials from the Windows Credential Manager tool.   [26]
XTunnel is capable of accessing locally stored passwords on victims.[27]
mitigations: Preemptively search for files containing passwords and take actions to reduce the exposure risk when found.
Establish an organizational policy that prohibits password storage in files.
Restrict file shares to specific directories with access only to necessary users.
Ensure that developers and system administrators are aware of the risk associated with having plaintext passwords in software configuration files that may be left on endpoint systems or servers.
title: Credentials in Files

description: The Windows Registry stores configuration information that can be used by the system or other programs. Adversaries may query the Registry looking for credentials and passwords that have been stored for use by other programs or services. Sometimes these credentials are used for automatic logons.
detection: Monitor processes for applications that can be used to query the Registry, such as Reg, and collect command parameters that may indicate credentials are being searched. Correlate activity with related suspicious behavior that may indicate an active intrusion to reduce false positives.
examples: PowerSploit has several modules that search the Windows Registry for stored credentials: Get-UnattendedInstallFile, Get-Webconfig, Get-ApplicationHost, Get-SiteListPassword, Get-CachedGPPPassword, and Get-RegistryAutoLogon.[1]
Reg may be used to find credentials in the Windows Registry.[1]
Soft Cell used reg commands to dump specific hives from the Windows Registry, such as the SAM hive, and obtain password hashes.[2]
TrickBot has retrieved PuTTY credentials by querying the Software\SimonTatham\Putty\Sessions registry key[3]
mitigations: Proactively search for credentials within the Registry and attempt to remediate the risk.
Do not store credentials within the Registry.
If it is necessary that software must store credentials in the Registry, then ensure the associated accounts have limited permissions so they cannot be abused if obtained by an adversary.
permissions_required: Ability to query some Registry locations depends on the adversary's level of access. User permissions are usually limited to access of user-related Registry keys.
title: Credentials in Registry
version: Windows Registry, Process command-line parameters, Process monitoring

description: Adversaries may communicate using a custom command and control protocol instead of encapsulating commands/data in an existing Standard Application Layer Protocol. Implementations include mimicking well-known protocols or developing custom protocols (including raw sockets) on top of fundamental protocols provided by TCP/IP/another standard network stack.
detection: Analyze network traffic for ICMP messages or other protocols that contain abnormal data or are not normally seen within or exiting the network.
examples: APT32 uses Cobalt Strike's malleable C2 functionality to blend in with network traffic. The group's backdoor can also exfiltrate data by encoding it in the subdomain field of DNS packets. Additionally, one of the group's macOS backdoors implements a specific format for the C2 packet involving random values.[1][2][3][4][5]
APT37 credential stealer ZUMKONG emails credentials from the victim using HTTP POST requests.[6]
BISCUIT communicates to the C2 server using a custom protocol.[7]
Carbanak uses a custom binary protocol for C2 communications.[8]
Chaos provides a reverse shell connection on 8338/TCP, encrypted via AES.[9]

Cobalt Strike allows adversaries to modify the way the "beacon" payload communicates. This is called "Malleable C2" in the Cobalt Strike manual and is intended to allow a penetration test team to mimic known APT C2 methods.[10][2]
Crimson uses a custom TCP protocol for C2.[11]
Derusbi binds to a raw socket on a random source port between 31800 and 31900 for C2.[13]
A Dipsind variant uses a C2 mechanism similar to port knocking that allows attackers to connect to a victim without leaving the connection open for more than a few sectonds.[14]

Duqu is capable of using its command and control protocol over port 443. However, Duqu is also capable of encapsulating its command protocol over standard application layer protocols. The Duqu command and control protocol implements many of the same features as TCP and is a reliable transport protocol.[15]
Emotet has been observed using an encrypted, modified protobuf-based protocol for command and control messaging.[16][17]
FlawedGrace uses a custom binary protocol for its C2 communications.[18]
InvisiMole communicates with its C2 servers through a TCP socket.[19]
Mis-Type network traffic can communicate over a raw socket.[20]
Misdat network traffic communicates over a raw socket.[20]
MoonWind completes network communication via raw sockets.[21]
Naid connects to C2 infrastructure and establishes backdoors over a custom communications protocol.[22][23]

If NETEAGLE does not detect a proxy configured on the infected machine, it will send beacons via UDP/6000. Also, after retrieving a C2 IP address and Port Number, NETEAGLE will initiate a TCP connection to this socket. The ensuing connection is a plaintext C2 channel in which commands are specified by DWORDs.[24]
njRAT communicates to the C2 server using a custom protocol over TCP.[25]
OilRig has used custom DNS Tunneling protocols for C2.[26]
PHOREAL communicates via ICMP for C2.[1]
PLAINTEE uses a custom UDP protocol to communicate.[12]
PLATINUM has used the Intel® Active Management Technology (AMT) Serial-over-LAN (SOL) channel for command and control.[27]
PlugX can be configured to use raw TCP or UDP for command and control.[28]
Some Reaver variants use raw TCP for C2.[29]
RedLeaves can communicate to its C2 over TCP using a custom binary protocol.[30]
The Regin malware platform can use ICMP to communicate between infected computers.[31]
Remsec is capable of using ICMP, TCP, and UDP for C2.[32][33]
RogueRobin uses a custom DNS tunneling protocol for C2.[34][35]
RTM uses HTTP POST requests with data formatted using a custom protocol.[36]
Seasalt uses a custom binary protocol for C2.[7]
A TYPEFRAME variant uses fake TLS to communicate with the C2 server.[37]

UBoatRAT has used a custom command and control protocol to communicate with C2. The string ‘488’ is placed at the top of the payload and encrypts the entre buffer with a static key using a simple XOR cipher.[38]
Ursnif  has used a custom packet format over TCP and UDP for a peer-to-peer (P2P) network for C2.[39]
Volgmer uses a custom binary protocol to beacon back to its C2 server. It has also used XOR for encrypting communications.[40][41]
WINDSHIELD C2 traffic can communicate via TCP raw sockets.[1]
Zebrocy uses raw sockets to communicate with its C2 server.[42]
mitigations: Filter network traffic to look for unusual or non-standard protocols.

Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific protocol used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool C2 signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.[43]

Properly configure firewalls and proxies to limit outgoing traffic to only necessary ports and through proper network gateway systems. Also ensure hosts are only provisioned to communicate over authorized interfaces.
permissions_required: Packet capture, Netflow/Enclave netflow, Process use of network, Process monitoring, Host network interface, Network intrusion detection system, Network protocol analysis
title: Custom Command and Control Protocol

description: Adversaries may use a custom cryptographic protocol or algorithm to hide command and control traffic. A simple scheme, such as XOR-ing the plaintext with a fixed key, will produce a very weak ciphertext.
detection: If malware uses custom encryption with symmetric keys, it may be possible to obtain the algorithm and key from samples and use them to decode network traffic to detect malware communications signatures. [45]
examples: 3PARA RAT will use an 8-byte XOR key derived from the string HYF54&%9&jkMCXuiS instead if the DES decoding fails.[2]
4H RAT obfuscates C2 communication using a 1-byte XOR with the key 0xBE.[2]
APT28 installed a Delphi backdoor that used a custom algorithm for C2 communications.[3]
BADCALL encrypts C2 traffic using an XOR/ADD cipher and uses a FakeTLS method.[4]
BADNEWS encrypts C2 data with a ROR by 3 and an XOR by 0x23.[5][6]
BBSRAT uses a custom encryption algorithm on data sent back to the C2 server over HTTP.[7]
Bisonal variants reported on in 2014 and 2015 used a simple XOR cipher for C2.[8]
BRONZE BUTLER has used a tool called RarStar that encodes data with a custom XOR algorithm when posting it to a C2 server.[9]
Carbanak uses XOR with random keys for its communications.[10]
Cardinal RAT uses a secret key with a series of XOR and addition operations to encrypt C2 traffic.[11]
ChChes can encrypt C2 data with a custom technique using MD5, base64-encoding, and RC4.[12][13]
CORESHELL C2 messages are encrypted with custom stream ciphers using six-byte or eight-byte keys.[14]
CosmicDuke contains a custom version of the RC4 algorithm that includes a programming error.[1]
Derusbi obfuscates C2 traffic with variable 4-byte XOR keys.[15]
Ebury has encrypted C2 traffic using the client IP address, then encoded it as a hexadecimal string.[16]

The C2 server response to a beacon sent by a variant of Emissary contains a 36-character GUID value that is used as an encryption key for subsequent network communications. Some variants of Emissary use various XOR operations to encrypt C2 data.[17]

The original variant of FakeM encrypts C2 traffic using a custom encryption cipher that uses an XOR key of "YHCRA" and bit rotation between each XOR operation. FakeM has also included HTML code in C2 traffic in an apparent attempt to evade detection. Additionally, some variants of FakeM use modified SSL code for communications back to C2 servers, making SSL decryption ineffective.[18]
FALLCHILL uses fake Transport Layer Security (TLS) to communicate with its C2 server, encoding data with RC4 encryption.[19]
Some Felismus samples use a custom encryption method for C2 traffic using AES, base64 encoding, and multiple keys.[20]
Gazer uses custom encryption for C2 using 3DES and RSA.[21][22]

Before being appended to image files, HAMMERTOSS commands are encrypted with a key composed of both a hard-coded value and a string contained on that day's tweet. To decrypt the commands, an investigator would need access to the intended malware sample, the day's tweet, and the image file containing the command.[23]
HARDRAIN uses FakeTLS to communicate with its C2 server.[24]
HiddenWasp uses an RC4-like algorithm with an already computed PRGA generated key-stream for network communication.[25]
httpclient encrypts C2 content with XOR using a single byte, 0x12.[2]
Hydraq C2 traffic is encrypted using bitwise NOT and XOR operations.[27]
InvisiMole uses variations of a simple XOR encryption routine for C&C communications.[28]
KeyBoy uses custom SSL libraries for C2 traffic.[29]
KEYMARBLE uses a customized XOR algorithm to encrypt C2 communications.[30]
The Komplex C2 channel uses an 11-byte XOR algorithm to hide data.[31]

Several Lazarus Group malware families encrypt C2 traffic using custom code that uses XOR with an ADD operation and XOR with a SUB operation. Another Lazarus Group malware sample XORs C2 traffic. Lazarus Group malware also uses a unique form of communication encryption known as FakeTLS that mimics TLS but uses a different encryption method, evading SSL man-in-the-middle decryption attacks.[32][33][34][35]
Mosquito uses a custom encryption algorithm, which consists of XOR and a stream that is similar to the Blum Blum Shub algorithm.[37]
PLAINTEE encodes C2 beacons using XOR.[38]
RTM encrypts C2 traffic with a custom RC4 variant.[39]
Sakula encodes C2 traffic with single-byte XOR keys.[40]
Sys10 uses an XOR 0x1 loop to encrypt its C2 domain.[41]
Taidoor is known to utilize encryption within network protocols.[42]
TrickBot uses a custom crypter leveraging Microsoft’s CryptoAPI to encrypt C2 traffic.[43]
WannaCry uses a custom cryptographic protocol over the Tor circuit.[44]
mitigations: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Since the custom protocol used may not adhere to typical protocol standards, there may be opportunities to signature the traffic on a network level for detection. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific protocol used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool C2 signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.[46]
permissions_required: Packet capture, Netflow/Enclave netflow, Process use of network, Malware reverse engineering, Process monitoring
title: Custom Cryptographic Protocol

data_sources: API monitoring, Authentication logs, Network protocol analysis, Packet capture
description: DCShadow is a method of manipulating Active Directory (AD) data, including objects and schemas, by registering (or reusing an inactive registration) and simulating the behavior of a Domain Controller (DC). [1] [2] Once registered, a rogue DC may be able to inject and replicate changes into AD infrastructure for any domain object, including credentials and keys.
detection: Monitor and analyze network traffic associated with data replication (such as calls to DrsAddEntry, DrsReplicaAdd, and especially GetNCChanges) between DCs as well as to/from non DC hosts. [5] [1] [2] DC replication will naturally take place every 15 minutes but can be triggered by an attacker or by legitimate urgent changes (ex: passwords). [2] Also consider monitoring and alerting on the replication of AD objects (Audit Detailed Directory Service Replication Events 4928 and 4929). [1]
mitigations: Mimikatz’s LSADUMP::DCShadow module can be used to make AD updates by temporarily setting a computer to be a DC.[4][3]
title: DCShadow

description: Windows systems use a common method to look for required DLLs to load into a program. [1] Adversaries may take advantage of the Windows DLL search order and programs that ambiguously specify DLLs to gain privilege escalation and persistence.
detection: Monitor file systems for moving, renaming, replacing, or modifying DLLs. Changes in the set of DLLs that are loaded by a process (compared with past behavior) that do not correlate with known software, patches, etc., are suspicious. Monitor DLLs loaded into a process and detect DLLs that have the same file name but abnormal paths. Modifications to or creation of .manifest and .local redirection files that do not correlate with software updates are suspicious.
examples: Downdelph uses search order hijacking of the Windows executable sysprep.exe to escalate privileges.[7]
Empire contains modules that can discover and exploit various DLL hijacking opportunities.[8]
A FinFisher variant uses DLL search order hijacking.[9][10]
HTTPBrowser abuses the Windows DLL load order by using a legitimate Symantec anti-virus binary, VPDN_LU.exe, to load a malicious DLL that mimics a legitimate Symantec DLL, navlu.dll.[11]

InvisiMole can be launched by using DLL search order hijacking in which the wrapper DLL is placed in the same folder as explorer.exe and loaded during startup into the Windows Explorer process instead of the legitimate library.[12]
menuPass has used DLL search order hijacking.[13]
MirageFox is likely loaded via DLL hijacking into a legitimate McAfee binary.[14]
PowerSploit contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and exploit DLL hijacking opportunities in services and processes.[15][16]

Prikormka uses DLL search order hijacking for persistence by saving itself as ntshrui.dll to the Windows directory so it will load before the legitimate ntshrui.dll saved in the System32 subdirectory.[17]
RedLeaves is launched through use of DLL search order hijacking to load a malicious dll.[18]
Threat Group-3390 has performed DLL search order hijacking to execute their payload.[19]
Variants of WEBC2 achieve persistence by using DLL search order hijacking, usually by copying the DLL file to %SYSTEMROOT% (C:\WINDOWS\ntshrui.dll).[20]
mitigations: Use auditing tools capable of detecting DLL search order hijacking opportunities on systems within an enterprise and correct them. Toolkits like the PowerSploit framework contain PowerUp modules that can be used to explore systems for DLL hijacking weaknesses.[21]

Adversaries may use new DLLs to execute this technique. Identify and block potentially malicious software executed through search order hijacking by using application whitelisting solutions capable of blocking DLLs loaded by legitimate software.

Disallow loading of remote DLLs. This is included by default in Windows Server 2012+ and is available by patch for XP+ and Server 2003+. Path AlgorithmEnable Safe DLL Search Mode to force search for system DLLs in directories with greater restrictions (e.g. %SYSTEMROOT%)to be used before local directory DLLs (e.g. a user's home directory)The Safe DLL Search Mode can be enabled via Group Policy at Computer Configuration > [Policies] > Administrative Templates > MSS (Legacy): MSS: (SafeDllSearchMode) Enable Safe DLL search mode. The associated Windows Registry key for this is located at HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\SafeDLLSearchMode[22][1]
permissions_required: Ability to add a DLL, manifest file, or .local file, directory, or junction.
title: DLL Search Order Hijacking

description: Programs may specify DLLs that are loaded at runtime. Programs that improperly or vaguely specify a required DLL may be open to a vulnerability in which an unintended DLL is loaded. Side-loading vulnerabilities specifically occur when Windows Side-by-Side (WinSxS) manifests [1] are not explicit enough about characteristics of the DLL to be loaded. Adversaries may take advantage of a legitimate program that is vulnerable to side-loading to load a malicious DLL. [2]
detection: Monitor processes for unusual activity (e.g., a process that does not use the network begins to do so). Track DLL metadata, such as a hash, and compare DLLs that are loaded at process execution time against previous executions to detect differences that do not correlate with patching or updates.
examples: APT19 launched an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant using a legitimate executable that loaded the malicious DLL.[3]
APT3 has been known to side load DLLs with a valid version of Chrome with one of their tools.[4][5]

APT32 ran legitimately-signed executables from Symantec and McAfee which load a malicious DLL. The group also side-loads its backdoor by dropping a library and a legitimate, signed executable (AcroTranscoder).[6][7][8]
BADNEWS typically loads its DLL file into a legitimate signed Java or VMware executable.[9][10]
DLL side-loading has been used to execute BBSRAT through a legitimate Citrix executable, ssonsvr.exe. The Citrix executable was dropped along with BBSRAT by the dropper.[11]
Denis exploits a security vulnerability to load a fake DLL and execute its code.[6]
FinFisher uses DLL side-loading to load malicious programs.[12][13]
A gh0st RAT variant has used DLL side-loading.[14]
HyperBro  has used a legitimate application to sideload a DLL to decrypt, decompress, and run a payload.[16]
menuPass has used DLL side-loading to launch versions of Mimikatz and PwDump6 as well as UPPERCUT.[17][18]
OwaAuth has been loaded onto Exchange servers and disguised as an ISAPI filter (DLL file). The IIS w3wp.exe process then loads the malicious DLL.[15]
A Patchwork .dll that contains BADNEWS is loaded and executed using DLL side-loading.[19]
PlugX has used DLL side-loading to evade anti-virus.[5][15][2][17][20]
Sakula uses DLL side-loading, typically using a digitally signed sample of Kaspersky Anti-Virus (AV) 6.0 for Windows Workstations or McAfee's Outlook Scan About Box to load malicious DLL files.[21]
Soft Cell used DLL side-loading to covertly load PoisonIvy into memory on the victim machine.[22]

During the T9000 installation process, it drops a copy of the legitimate Microsoft binary igfxtray.exe. The executable contains a side-loading weakness which is used to load a portion of the malware.[23]
Threat Group-3390 has used DLL side-loading, including by using legitimate Kaspersky antivirus variants in which the DLL acts as a stub loader that loads and executes the shell code.[15][24][25][16]
Tropic Trooper has been known to side-load DLLs using a valid version of Windows Address Book executable with one of their tools.[26]
Wingbird side loads a malicious file, sspisrv.dll, in part of a spoofed lssas.exe service.[27][28]
ZeroT has used DLL side-loading to load malicious payloads.[29][30]
mitigations: Use the program sxstrace.exe that is included with Windows along with manual inspection to check manifest files for side-loading vulnerabilities in software.
Update software regularly to include patches that fix DLL side-loading vulnerabilities.
permissions_required: Process use of network, Process monitoring, Loaded DLLs
title: DLL Side-Loading

description: An adversary may compress data (e.g., sensitive documents) that is collected prior to exfiltration in order to make it portable and minimize the amount of data sent over the network. The compression is done separately from the exfiltration channel and is performed using a custom program or algorithm, or a more common compression library or utility such as 7zip, RAR, ZIP, or zlib.
detection: Compression software and compressed files can be detected in many ways. Common utilities that may be present on the system or brought in by an adversary may be detectable through process monitoring and monitoring for command-line arguments for known compression utilities. This may yield a significant amount of benign events, depending on how systems in the environment are typically used.
examples: ADVSTORESHELL compresses output data generated by command execution with a custom implementation of the Lempel–Ziv–Welch (LZW) algorithm.[1]
APT1 has used RAR to compress files before moving them outside of the victim network.[2]
APT28 used a publicly available tool to gather and compress multiple documents on the DCCC and DNC networks.[3]
APT3 has used tools to compress data before exfilling it.[4]
APT32's backdoor has used LZMA compression before exfiltration.    [5]
APT33 has used WinRAR to compress data prior to exfil. [6]
APT39 has used WinRAR and 7-Zip to compress an archive stolen data.[7]
BBSRAT can compress data with ZLIB prior to sending it back to the C2 server.[8]
BRONZE BUTLER has compressed data into password-protected RAR archives prior to exfiltration.[9]
Calisto uses the zip -r command to compress the data collected on the local system.[10][11]
Cardinal RAT applies compression to C2 traffic using the ZLIB library.[12]
CopyKittens uses ZPP, a .NET console program, to compress files with ZIP.[13]
CORALDECK has created password-protected RAR, WinImage, and zip archives to be exfiltrated.[14]
Daserf hides collected data in password-protected .rar archives.[15]
Denis compressed collected data using zlib.[16]
Dragonfly 2.0 compressed data into .zip files prior to exfiltrating it.[17]
Modules can be pushed to and executed by Duqu that copy data to a staging area, compress it, and XOR encrypt it.[18]
Empire can ZIP directories on the target system.[19]
Epic compresses the collected data with bzip2 before sending it to the C2 server.[20]
Following data collection, FIN6 has compressed log files into a ZIP archive prior to staging and exfiltration.[21]
FIN8 has used RAR to compress collected data before.[22]
Gallmaker has used WinZip, likely to archive data prior to exfiltration.[23]
Honeybee adds collected files to a temp.zip file saved in the %temp% folder, then base64 encodes it and uploads it to control server.[24]
iKitten will zip up the /Library/Keychains directory before exfiltrating it.[25]
InvisiMole uses WinRAR to compress data that is intended to be exfiltrated.[26]
The Ke3chang group has been known to compress data before exfiltration.[27]

Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is compressed with Zlib, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server. Lazarus Group malware RomeoDelta archives specified directories in .zip format, encrypts the .zip file, and uploads it to its C2 server.[28][29][30]
Lurid can compress data before sending it.[31]
Magic Hound has used RAR to stage and compress local folders.[32]
menuPass has compressed files before exfiltration using TAR and RAR.[33][34]
Micropsia creates a RAR archive based on collected files on the victim's machine.[35]
MuddyWater has used the native Windows cabinet creation tool, makecab.exe, likely to compress stolen data to be uploaded.[36]
OopsIE compresses collected files with both the GZipStream class and a simple character replacement scheme before sending them to its C2 server.[37]
PoshC2 contains a module for compressing data using ZIP.[38]
After collecting documents from removable media, Prikormka compresses the collected files.[39]
Proton zips up files before exfiltrating them.[25]
PUNCHBUGGY has Gzipped information and saved it to a random temp file before exfil.  [40]
Pupy can compress data with Zip before sending it over C2.[41]
RunningRAT contains code to compress files.[42]
SeaDuke compressed data with zlib prior to sending it over C2.[43]
Soft Cell used winrar to compress and encrypt stolen data prior to exfiltration.[44]
Sowbug extracted documents and bundled them into a RAR archive.[45]
Threat Group-3390 has used RAR to compress, encrypt, and password-protect files prior to exfiltration.[46]
The ZLib backdoor compresses communications using the standard Zlib compression library.[47]
mitigations: Network intrusion prevention or data loss prevention tools may be set to block specific file types from leaving the network over unencrypted channels. An adversary may move to an encrypted channel or use other mechanisms of encapsulating the traffic in these situations.
permissions_required: Binary file metadata, File monitoring, Process command-line parameters, Process monitoring
title: Data Compressed

data_sources: File monitoring, Process command-line parameters, Process monitoring
description: Adversaries may destroy data and files on specific systems or in large numbers on a network to interrupt availability to systems, services, and network resources. Data destruction is likely to render stored data irrecoverable by forensic techniques through overwriting files or data on local and remote drives.[1][2][3][4][5][6] Common operating system file deletion commands such as del and rm often only remove pointers to files without wiping the contents of the files themselves, making the files recoverable by proper forensic methodology. This behavior is distinct from Disk Content Wipe and Disk Structure Wipe because individual files are destroyed rather than sections of a storage disk or the disk's logical structure.
detection: Use process monitoring to monitor the execution and command-line parameters of binaries that could be involved in data destruction activity, such as SDelete. Monitor for the creation of suspicious files as well as high unusual file modification activity. In particular, look for large quantities of file modifications in user directories and under C:\Windows\System32\.
examples: APT38 has used a custom secure delete function to make deleted files unrecoverable.[7]
BlackEnergy 2 contains a "Destroy" plug-in that destroys data stored on victim hard drives by overwriting file contents.[8]
Kazuar can overwrite files with random data before deleting them.[9]
Lazarus Group has used a custom secure delete function to overwrite file contents with data from heap memory.[10]
Olympic Destroyer overwrites files locally and on remote shares. [6]
PowerDuke has a command to write random data across a file and delete it.[11]
Proxysvc can overwrite files indicated by the attacker before deleting them.[12]
RawDisk was used in Shamoon to write to protected system locations such as the MBR and disk partitions in an effort to destroy data.[3][5]
SDelete deletes data in a way that makes it unrecoverable.[13]
Shamoon attempts to overwrite operating system files and disk structures with image files. In a later variant, randomly generated data was used for data overwrites.[1][2][3][5]
StoneDrill has a disk wiper module that targets files other than those in the Windows directory.[4]
Xbash has destroyed Linux-based databases as part of its ransomware capabilities.    [14]
mitigations: Consider implementing IT disaster recovery plans that contain procedures for taking regular data backups that can be used to restore organizational data. Ensure backups are stored off system and is protected from common methods adversaries may use to gain access and destroy the backups to prevent recovery.
title: Data Destruction

data_sources: Packet capture, Process use of network, Process monitoring, Network protocol analysis
description: Command and control (C2) information is encoded using a standard data encoding system. Use of data encoding may be to adhere to existing protocol specifications and includes use of ASCII, Unicode, Base64,  MIME, UTF-8, or other binary-to-text and character encoding systems. [1] [2] Some data encoding systems may also result in data compression, such as gzip.
detection: Analyze network data for uncommon data flows (e.g., a client sending significantly more data than it receives from a server). Processes utilizing the network that do not normally have network communication or have never been seen before are suspicious. Analyze packet contents to detect communications that do not follow the expected protocol behavior for the port that is being used. [39]
examples: C2 traffic from ADVSTORESHELL is encrypted, then encoded with Base64 encoding.[3]
An APT19 HTTP malware variant used Base64 to encode communications to the C2 server.[4]
APT33 has used base64 to encode command and control traffic.[5]
Astaroth encodes data using Base64 before sending it to the C2 server.[6]
AutoIt backdoor has sent a C2 response that was base64-encoded.[7]
BADNEWS encodes C2 traffic with base64.[7][8][9]
Bankshot encodes commands from the control server using a range of characters and gzip.[10]
Several BRONZE BUTLER tools encode data with base64 when posting it to a C2 server.[11]
BS2005 uses Base64 encoding for communication in the message body of an HTTP request.[12]
Daserf uses custom base64 encoding to obfuscate HTTP traffic.[11]
Denis encodes the data sent to the server in Base64.[14]
Dipsind encodes C2 traffic with base64.[15]
Elise exfiltrates data using cookie values that are Base64-encoded.[17]

For C2 over HTTP, Helminth encodes data with base64 and sends it via the "Cookie" field of HTTP requests. For C2 over DNS, Helminth converts ASCII characters into their hexadecimal values and sends the data in cleartext.[18]
A JHUHUGIT variant encodes C2 POST data base64.[19]
Kazuar encodes communications to the C2 server in Base64.[20]
A Lazarus Group malware sample encodes data with base64.[21]
Linux Rabbit sends the payload from the C2 server as an encoded URL parameter.[22]
Mis-Type uses Base64 encoding for C2 traffic.[23]
Misdat network traffic is Base64-encoded plaintext.[23]
njRAT uses Base64 encoding for C2 traffic.[24]
OceanSalt can encode data with a NOT operation before sending the data to the control server.[25]
Octopus encodes C2 communications in Base64.[26]
OopsIE encodes data in hexadecimal format over the C2 channel.[27]
Patchwork used Base64 to encode C2 traffic.[28]
Responses from the Pisloader C2 server are base32-encoded.[29]
POWERSTATS encoded C2 traffic with base64.[30]
POWRUNER can use base64 encoded C2 communications.[31]
Prikormka encodes C2 traffic with Base64.[32]
Revenge RAT uses Base64 to encode information sent to the C2 server.[33]
S-Type uses Base64 encoding for C2 traffic.[23]
SpeakUp encodes C&C communication using Base64.[35]
Ursnif  has used encoded data in HTTP URLs for C2.   [36]
Zebrocy has used URL/Percent Encoding on data exfiltrated via HTTP POST requests.[38]
mitigations: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific obfuscation technique used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool C2 signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.[39]
title: Data Encoding

description: Data is encrypted before being exfiltrated in order to hide the information that is being exfiltrated from detection or to make the exfiltration less conspicuous upon inspection by a defender. The encryption is performed by a utility, programming library, or custom algorithm on the data itself and is considered separate from any encryption performed by the command and control or file transfer protocol. Common file archive formats that can encrypt files are RAR and zip.
detection: Encryption software and encrypted files can be detected in many ways. Common utilities that may be present on the system or brought in by an adversary may be detectable through process monitoring and monitoring for command-line arguments for known encryption utilities. This may yield a significant amount of benign events, depending on how systems in the environment are typically used. Often the encryption key is stated within command-line invocation of the software.
mitigations: ADVSTORESHELL encrypts with the 3DES algorithm and a hardcoded key prior to exfiltration.[1]
Agent Tesla encrypts the data with 3DES before sending it over the C2 server.[2]
Agent.btz saves system information into an XML file that is then XOR-encoded.[3]
APT32 backdoors have encrypted data before exfiltration, including by using RC4 encryption.[4][5]
Backdoor.Oldrea writes collected data to a temporary file in an encrypted form before exfiltration to a C2 server.[6]
BRONZE BUTLER has compressed and encrypted data into password-protected RAR archives prior to exfiltration.[7]
CopyKittens encrypts data with a substitute cipher prior to exfiltration.[8]
CORALDECK has created password-protected RAR, WinImage, and zip archives to be exfiltrated.[9]
Daserf hides collected data in password-protected .rar archives.[10]
Modules can be pushed to and executed by Duqu that copy data to a staging area, compress it, and XOR encrypt it.[11]
Emotet has been observed encrypting the data it collects before sending it to the C2 server.[12]

Epic encrypts collected data using a public key framework before sending it over the C2 channel. Some variants encrypt the collected data with AES and encode it with base64 before transmitting it to the C2 server.[13][14]
FELIXROOT encrypts collected data with AES and Base64 and then sends it to the C2 server.[15]
TRINITY malware used by FIN6 encodes data gathered from the victim with a simple substitution cipher and single-byte XOR using the 0xAA key.[16]
FLASHFLOOD employs the same encoding scheme as SPACESHIP for data it stages. Data is compressed with zlib, and bytes are rotated four times before being XOR'ed with 0x23.[17]
Gold Dragon encrypts data using Base64 before being sent to the command and control server.[18]
HAWKBALL has encrypted data with XOR before sending it over the C2 channel.[19]
Honeybee adds collected files to a temp.zip file saved in the %temp% folder, then base64 encodes it and uploads it to control server.[20]
InvisiMole uses a variation of the XOR cipher to encrypt files before exfiltration.[21]
Ke3chang is known to use RAR with passwords to encrypt data prior to exfiltration.[22]

Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is compressed with Zlib, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server. Lazarus Group malware RomeoDelta archives specified directories in .zip format, encrypts the .zip file, and uploads it to its C2 server. A Lazarus Group malware sample encrypts data using a simple byte based XOR operation prior to exfiltration.[23][24][25][26]
LightNeuron contains a function to encrypt and store emails that it collects.[27]
menuPass has encrypted files and information before exfiltration.[28]
OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D scrambles and encrypts data using AES256 before sending it to the C2 server.[29]
OwaAuth DES-encrypts captured credentials using the key 12345678 before writing the credentials to a log file.[30]
Patchwork encrypted the collected files' path with AES and then encoded them with base64.[31]
After collecting files and logs from the victim, Prikormka encrypts some collected data with Blowfish.[32]
RawPOS encodes credit card data it collected from the victim with XOR.[33][34][35]
Reaver encrypts collected data with an incremental XOR key prior to exfiltration.[36]
Remexi encrypts and adds all gathered browser data into files for upload to C2.[37]
RGDoor encrypts files with XOR before sending them back to the C2 server.[38]
Soft Cell used winrar to compress and encrypt stolen data prior to exfiltration.[39]
Data SPACESHIP copies to the staging area is compressed with zlib. Bytes are rotated by four positions and XOR'ed with 0x23.[17]
T9000 encrypts collected data using a single byte XOR key.[40]
Threat Group-3390 has used RAR to compress, encrypt, and password-protect files prior to exfiltration.[41]
Turla has encrypted files stolen from connected USB drives into a RAR file before exfiltration.[42]
VERMIN encrypts the collected files using 3-DES.[43]
Zebrocy uses an encryption method similar to RC4 as well as AES to encrypt data before exfiltration.[44][45]
permissions_required: File monitoring, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters, Binary file metadata
title: Data Encrypted

data_sources: Kernel drivers, File monitoring, Process command-line parameters, Process monitoring
description: Adversaries may encrypt data on target systems or on large numbers of systems in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources. They can attempt to render stored data inaccessible by encrypting files or data on local and remote drives and withholding access to a decryption key. This may be done in order to extract monetary compensation from a victim in exchange for decryption or a decryption key (ransomware) or to render data permanently inaccessible in cases where the key is not saved or transmitted.[1][2][3][4] In the case of ransomware, it is typical that common user files like Office documents, PDFs, images, videos, audio, text, and source code files will be encrypted. In some cases, adversaries may encrypt critical system files, disk partitions, and the MBR.[3]
detection: Use process monitoring to monitor the execution and command line parameters of of binaries involved in data destruction activity, such as vssadmin, wbadmin, and bcdedit. Monitor for the creation of suspicious files as well as unusual file modification activity. In particular, look for large quantities of file modifications in user directories.
examples: APT38 has used Hermes ransomware to encrypt files with AES256.[5]
JCry has encrypted files and demanded Bitcoin to decrypt those files.[6]
LockerGoga  has encrypted files, including core Windows OS files, using RSA-OAEP MGF1 and then demanded Bitcoin be paid for the decryption key.[7][8][9]
NotPetya encrypts user files and disk structures like the MBR with 2048-bit RSA.[10][3]
SamSam encrypts victim files using RSA-2048 encryption and demands a ransom be paid in Bitcoin to decrypt those files.[11]
Shamoon has an operational mode for encrypting data instead of overwriting it.[12][13]
SynAck encrypts the victims machine followed by asking the victim to pay a ransom.[14]
TA505 has used a wide variety of ransomware, such as Locky, Jaff, Bart, Philadelphia, and GlobeImposter, to encrypt victim files and demand a ransom payment.[15]
WannaCry encrypts user files and demands that a ransom be paid in Bitcoin to decrypt those files.[16][2][17]
Xbash has maliciously encrypted victim's database systems and demanded a cryptocurrency ransom be paid.[18]
mitigations: Consider implementing IT disaster recovery plans that contain procedures for regularly taking and testing data backups that can be used to restore organizational data. Ensure backups are stored off system and is protected from common methods adversaries may use to gain access and destroy the backups to prevent recovery.
title: Data Encrypted for Impact

description: Command and control (C2) communications are hidden (but not necessarily encrypted) in an attempt to make the content more difficult to discover or decipher and to make the communication less conspicuous and hide commands from being seen. This encompasses many methods, such as adding junk data to protocol traffic, using steganography, commingling legitimate traffic with C2 communications traffic, or using a non-standard data encoding system, such as a modified Base64 encoding for the message body of an HTTP request.
detection: Analyze network data for uncommon data flows (e.g., a client sending significantly more data than it receives from a server). Processes utilizing the network that do not normally have network communication or have never been seen before are suspicious. Analyze packet contents to detect communications that do not follow the expected protocol behavior for the port that is being used. [24]
examples: APT28 added "junk data" to each encoded string, preventing trivial decoding without knowledge of the junk removal algorithm. Each implant was given a "junk length" value when created, tracked by the controller software to allow seamless communication but prevent analysis of the command protocol on the wire.[1]

The Axiom group has used other forms of obfuscation, include commingling legitimate traffic with communications traffic so that network streams appear legitimate. Some malware that has been used by Axiom also uses steganography to hide communication in PNG image files.[2]
Some Backdoor.Oldrea samples use standard Base64 + bzip2, and some use standard Base64 + reverse XOR + RSA-2048 to decrypt data received from C2 servers.[3]
Newer variants of BACKSPACE will encode C2 communications with a custom system.[4]
After encrypting C2 data, BADNEWS converts it into a hexadecimal representation and then encodes it into base64.[5]
Bankshot generates a false TLS handshake using a public certificate to disguise C2 network communications.[6]
Cobian RAT obfuscates communications with the C2 server using Base64 encoding.[7]
Daserf can use steganography to hide malicious code downloaded to the victim.[8]
Downdelph inserts pseudo-random characters between each original character during encoding of C2 network requests, making it difficult to write signatures on them.[9]
When the Duqu command and control is operating over HTTP or HTTPS, Duqu uploads data to its controller by appending it to a blank JPG file.[10]
FakeM C2 traffic attempts to evade detection by resembling data generated by legitimate messenger applications, such as MSN and Yahoo! messengers.[11]
FlawedAmmyy may obfuscate portions of the initial C2 handshake.[12]
H1N1 obfuscates C2 traffic with an altered version of base64.[13]
HAMMERTOSS is controlled via commands that are appended to image files.[14]
HOPLIGHT has utilized Zlib compression to obfuscate the communications payload.[15]
Ixeshe uses custom Base64 encoding schemes to obfuscate command and control traffic in the message body of HTTP requests.[16][17]
LightNeuron is controlled via commands that are embedded into PDFs and JPGs using steganographic methods.[18]
P2P ZeuS added junk data to outgoing UDP packets to peer implants.[19]
QUADAGENT encodes C2 communications with base64.[20]
RogueRobin base64 encodes strings that are sent to the C2 over its DNS tunnel.[21]
ZeroT has retrieved stage 2 payloads as Bitmap images that use Least Significant Bit (LSB) steganography.[22][23]
mitigations: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate some obfuscation activity at the network level.[24]
permissions_required: Packet capture, Process use of network, Process monitoring, Network protocol analysis
title: Data Obfuscation

description: Collected data is staged in a central location or directory prior to Exfiltration. Data may be kept in separate files or combined into one file through techniques such as Data Compressed or Data Encrypted.
detection: Processes that appear to be reading files from disparate locations and writing them to the same directory or file may be an indication of data being staged, especially if they are suspected of performing encryption or compression on the files.
mitigations: ADVSTORESHELL stores output from command execution in a .dat file in the %TEMP% directory.[1]
APT28 has stored captured credential information in a file named pi.log.[2]
APT3 has been known to stage files for exfiltration in a single location.[3]
Astaroth collects data in a plaintext file named r1.log before exfiltration.[4]
BADNEWS copies documents under 15MB found on the victim system to is the user's %temp%\SMB\ folder. It also copies files from USB devices to a predefined directory.[5][6]
BadPatch stores collected data in log files before exfiltration.[7]
Calisto uses a hidden directory named .calisto to store data from the victim’s machine before exfiltration.[8][9]
Carbon creates a base directory that contains the files and folders that are collected.[10]
Catchamas stores the gathered data from the machine in .db files and .bmp files under four separate locations.[11]
Dragonfly 2.0 created a directory named "out" in the user's %AppData% folder and copied files to it.[12]
Modules can be pushed to and executed by Duqu that copy data to a staging area, compress it, and XOR encrypt it.[13]
Elise creates a file in AppData\Local\Microsoft\Windows\Explorer and stores all harvested data in that file.[14]
FIN5 scripts save memory dump data into a specific directory on hosts in the victim environment.[15]

TRINITY malware used by FIN6 identifies payment card track data on the victim and then copies it to a local file in a subdirectory of C:\Windows\. Once the malware collects the data, FIN6 actors compressed data and moved it to another staging system before exfiltration.[16]
FIN8 aggregates staged data from a network into a single location.[17]
FLASHFLOOD stages data it copies from the local system or removable drives in the "%WINDIR%\$NtUninstallKB885884$\" directory.[18]
Gold Dragon stores information gathered from the endpoint in a file named 1.hwp.[19]
Helminth creates folders to store output from batch scripts prior to sending the information to its C2 server.[20]
Honeybee adds collected files to a temp.zip file saved in the %temp% folder, then base64 encodes it and uploads it to control server.[21]
InvisiMole determines a working directory where it stores all the gathered data about the compromised machine.[22]
Kazuar stages command output and collected data in files before exfiltration.[23]
Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is saved in the %TEMP% directory, then compressed, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server.[24][25]
Leviathan has used C:\Windows\Debug and C:\Perflogs as staging directories.[26]
LightNeuron can store email data in files and directories specified in its configuration, such as C:\Windows\ServiceProfiles\NetworkService\appdata\Local\Temp\.[27]
menuPass stages data prior to exfiltration in multi-part archives, often saved in the Recycle Bin.[28]
MoonWind saves information from its keylogging routine as a .zip file in the present working directory.[29]
NavRAT writes multiple outputs to a TMP file using the >> method.[30]
Night Dragon has copied files to company web servers and subsequently downloaded them.[31]
NOKKI can collect data from the victim and stage it in LOCALAPPDATA%\MicroSoft Updatea\uplog.tmp.[32]
OopsIE stages the output from command execution and collected files in specific folders before exfiltration.[33]
Patchwork copied all targeted files to a directory called index that was eventually uploaded to the C&C server.[6]
PoisonIvy stages collected data in a text file.[34]
Prikormka creates a directory, %USERPROFILE%\AppData\Local\SKC\, which is used to store collected log files.[35]

Pteranodon creates various subdirectories under %Temp%\reports\% and copies files to those subdirectories. It also creates a folder at C:\Users\\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\store to store screenshot JPEG files.[36]
PUNCHBUGGY has saved information to a random temp file before exfil.[37]
PUNCHTRACK aggregates collected data in a tmp file.[17]
Data captured by RawPOS is placed in a temporary file under a directory named "memdump".[38]
Rover copies files from removable drives to C:\system.[39]
Soft Cell compressed and staged files in multi-part archives in the Recycle Bin prior to exfiltration.[40]
SPACESHIP identifies files with certain extensions and copies them to a directory in the user's profile.[18]
TEMP.Veles has created staging folders in directories that were infrequently used by legitimate users or processes.[41]
Threat Group-3390 has staged encrypted archives for exfiltration on Internet-facing servers that had previously been compromised with China Chopper.[42]
Trojan.Karagany can create a directory (C:\ProgramData\Mail\MailAg\gl) to use as a temporary directory for uploading files.[43]
Ursnif  has used tmp files to stage gathered information.[44]
USBStealer collects files matching certain criteria from the victim and stores them in a local directory for later exfiltration.[45][46]
Zebrocy stores all collected information in a single file before exfiltration.[47]
permissions_required: File monitoring, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters
title: Data Staged

description: An adversary may exfiltrate data in fixed size chunks instead of whole files or limit packet sizes below certain thresholds. This approach may be used to avoid triggering network data transfer threshold alerts.
detection: Analyze network data for uncommon data flows (e.g., a client sending significantly more data than it receives from a server). If a process maintains a long connection during which it consistently sends fixed size data packets or a process opens connections and sends fixed sized data packets at regular intervals, it may be performing an aggregate data transfer. Processes utilizing the network that do not normally have network communication or have never been seen before are suspicious. Analyze packet contents to detect communications that do not follow the expected protocol behavior for the port that is being used. [6]
examples: Carbanak exfiltrates data in compressed chunks if a message is larger than 4096 bytes .[1]
Helminth splits data into chunks up to 23 bytes and sends the data in DNS queries to its C2 server.[2]
OopsIE exfiltrates command output and collected files to its C2 server in 1500-byte blocks.[3]
Threat Group-3390 actors have split RAR files for exfiltration into parts.[5]
mitigations: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary command and control infrastructure and malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.[6]
permissions_required: Packet capture, Netflow/Enclave netflow, Process use of network, Process monitoring
title: Data Transfer Size Limits

data_sources: Application logs, Authentication logs, Data loss prevention, Third-party application logs
description: Adversaries may leverage information repositories to mine valuable information. Information repositories are tools that allow for storage of information, typically to facilitate collaboration or information sharing between users, and can store a wide variety of data that may aid adversaries in further objectives, or direct access to the target information.
detection: As information repositories generally have a considerably large user base, detection of malicious use can be non-trivial. At minimum, access to information repositories performed by privileged users (for example, Active Directory Domain, Enterprise, or Schema Administrators) should be closely monitored and alerted upon, as these types of accounts should not generally used to access information repositories. If the capability exists, it may be of value to monitor and alert on users that are retrieving and viewing a large number of documents and pages; this behavior may be indicative of programmatic means being used to retrieve all data within the repository. In environments with high-maturity, it may be possible to leverage User-Behavioral Analytics (UBA) platforms to detect and alert on user based anomalies.
examples: APT28 has collected information from Microsoft SharePoint services within target networks.[1]
Ke3chang used a SharePoint enumeration and data dumping tool known as spwebmember.[2]
spwebmember is used to enumerate and dump information from Microsoft SharePoint.[2]
mitigations: Consider periodic review of accounts and privileges for critical and sensitive repositories.
Enforce the principle of least-privilege. Consider implementing access control mechanisms that include both authentication and authorization.
Develop and publish policies that define acceptable information to be stored in repositories.
title: Data from Information Repositories

data_sources: File monitoring, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters
description: Sensitive data can be collected from local system sources, such as the file system or databases of information residing on the system prior to Exfiltration.
detection: Monitor processes and command-line arguments for actions that could be taken to collect files from a system. Remote access tools with built-in features may interact directly with the Windows API to gather data. Data may also be acquired through Windows system management tools such as Windows Management Instrumentation and PowerShell.
mitigations: APT1 has collected files from a local victim.[1]
APT28 has retrieved internal documents from machines inside victim environments, including by using Forfiles to stage documents before.[2][3]
APT3 will identify Microsoft Office documents on the victim's computer.[4]
APT37 has collected data from victims' local systems.[5]
When it first starts, BADNEWS crawls the victim's local drives and collects documents with the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .pdf, .ppt, .pptx, and .txt.[6][7]
BadPatch collects files from the local system that have the following extensions, then prepares them for exfiltration: .xls, .xlsx, .pdf, .mdb, .rar, .zip, .doc, .docx.[8]
Bankshot collects files from the local system.[9]
BRONZE BUTLER has exfiltrated files stolen from local systems.[10]
Calisto can collect data from user directories.[11]
China Chopper's server component can upload local files.[12][13][14]
Cobalt Strike can collect data from a local system.[15]
CosmicDuke steals user files from local hard drives with file extensions that match a predefined list.[16]
Dark Caracal collected complete contents of the 'Pictures' folder from compromised Windows systems.[17]
Dragonfly 2.0 collected data from local victim systems.[18]
Dust Storm has used Android backdoors capable of exfiltrating specific files directly from the infected devices.[19]

FLASHFLOOD searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on the local system. FLASHFLOOD will scan the My Recent Documents, Desktop, Temporary Internet Files, and TEMP directories. FLASHFLOOD also collects information stored in the Windows Address Book.[20]
Forfiles can be used to act on (ex: copy, move, etc.) files/directories in a system during (ex: copy files into a staging area before).[2]
GravityRAT steals files with the following extensions: .docx, .doc, .pptx, .ppt, .xlsx, .xls, .rtf, and .pdf.[21]
Honeybee collects data from the local victim system.[22]
Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can read data from files.[23][24]
Ixeshe can collect data from a local system.[25]
Kazuar uploads files from a specified directory to the C2 server.[26]
Ke3chang gathered information and files from local directories for exfiltration.[27]
Koadic can download files off the target system to send back to the server.[28]

Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is uploaded to one of its 10 C2 servers.
