Identify and block potentially malicious software executed path interception by using application whitelisting tools, like Windows Defender Application Control, AppLocker, or Software Restriction Policies where appropriate.[15][16][17][18][19][20]
Require that all executables be placed in write-protected directories.

Ensure that proper permissions and directory access control are set to deny users the ability to write files to the top-level directory C: and system directories, such as C:\Windows\, to reduce places where malicious files could be placed for execution.
title: Path Interception

description: Adversaries may attempt to gather information about attached peripheral devices and components connected to a computer system. The information may be used to enhance their awareness of the system and network environment or may be used for further actions.
detection: System and network discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities based on the information obtained.
mitigations: APT28 uses a module to receive a notification every time a USB mass storage device is inserted into a victim.[2]
APT37 has a Bluetooth device harvester, which uses Windows Bluetooth APIs to find information on connected Bluetooth devices.[3]
BADNEWS checks for new hard drives on the victim, such as USB devices, by listening for the WM_DEVICECHANGE window message.[4][5]
BlackEnergy can gather very specific information about attached USB devices, to include device instance ID and drive geometry.[6]
Equation has used tools with the functionality to search for specific information about the attached hard drive that could be used to identify and overwrite the firmware.[7]
FlawedAmmyy will attempt to detect if a usable smart card is current inserted into a card reader.[8]
Gamaredon Group tools contained an application to check performance of USB flash drives.[9]
MoonWind obtains the number of removable drives from the victim.[11]
njRAT will attempt to detect if the victim system has a camera during the initial infection.[12]
A module in Prikormka collects information on available printers and disk drives.[13]
RTM can obtain a list of smart card readers attached to the victim.[14]
T9000 searches through connected drives for removable storage devices.[15]
USBStealer monitors victims for insertion of removable drives. When dropped onto a second victim, it also enumerates drives connected to the system.[16]
WannaCry contains a thread that will attempt to scan for new attached drives every few seconds. If one is identified, it will encrypt the files on the attached device.[17]
XAgentOSX contains the showBackupIosFolder function to check for IOS device backups by running ls -la ~/Library/Application\ Support/MobileSync/Backup/.[18]
Zebrocy enumerates information about connected storage devices.[19]
title: Peripheral Device Discovery

data_sources: API monitoring, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters
description: Adversaries may attempt to find local system or domain-level groups and permissions settings.
detection: System and network discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as Lateral Movement, based on the information obtained.
mitigations: admin@338 actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with LOWBALL malware to list local groups: net localgroup administrator >> %temp%\download[1]
APT3 has a tool that can enumerate the permissions associated with Windows groups.[2]
Dragonfly 2.0 used batch scripts to enumerate administrators in the environment.[3]
dsquery can be used to gather information on permission groups within a domain.[4]
Emissary has the capability to execute the command net localgroup administrators.[5]
Epic gathers information on local group names.[6]
FIN6 has used tools like Adfind to query users, groups, organizational units, and trusts.[7]
FlawedAmmyy enumerates the privilege level of the victim during the initial infection.[8]

Helminth has checked for the local admin group domain admin group and Exchange Trusted Subsystem groups using the commands net group Exchange Trusted Subsystem /domain and net group domain admins /domain.[9]
JPIN can obtain the victim user name.[10]
Kazuar gathers information about local groups and members.[11]
Ke3chang performs discovery of permission groups net group /domain.[12]

Kwampirs collects lists of local accounts with administrative access, local group user accounts, and domain local groups with the commands net localgroup administrators, net localgroup users, and net localgroup /domain.[13]
MURKYTOP has the capability to retrieve information about groups.[14]
Commands such as net group and net localgroup can be used in Net to gather information about and manipulate groups.[15]

OilRig has used net group /domain, net localgroup administrators, net group "domain admins" /domain, and net group "Exchange Trusted Subsystem" /domain to find group permission settings on a victim.[16]
OSInfo specifically looks for Domain Admins, Power Users, and the Administrators groups within the domain and locally[2]
PoshC2 contains modules, such as Get-LocAdm for enumerating permission groups.[17]
POWRUNER may collect permission group information by running net group /domain or a series of other commands on a victim.[18]
PUNCHBUGGY can gather domain and workgroup information.  [19]
Sys10 collects the group name of the logged-in user and sends it to the C2.[20]
title: Permission Groups Discovery

data_sources: File monitoring, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters
description: Property list (plist) files contain all of the information that macOS and OS X uses to configure applications and services. These files are UTF-8 encoded and formatted like XML documents via a series of keys surrounded by < >. They detail when programs should execute, file paths to the executables, program arguments, required OS permissions, and many others. plists are located in certain locations depending on their purpose such as /Library/Preferences (which execute with elevated privileges) and ~/Library/Preferences (which execute with a user's privileges). Adversaries can modify these plist files to point to their own code, can use them to execute their code in the context of another user, bypass whitelisting procedures, or even use them as a persistence mechanism. [1]
detection: File system monitoring can determine if plist files are being modified. Users should not have permission to modify these in most cases. Some software tools like "Knock Knock" can detect persistence mechanisms and point to the specific files that are being referenced. This can be helpful to see what is actually being executed.
mitigations: Prevent plist files from being modified by users by making them read-only.
title: Plist Modification
version: Application whitelisting, Process whitelisting, Whitelisting by file name or path

description: Port Knocking is a well-established method used by both defenders and adversaries to hide open ports from access. To enable a port, an adversary sends a series of packets with certain characteristics before the port will be opened. Usually this series of packets consists of attempted connections to a predefined sequence of closed ports, but can involve unusual flags, specific strings or other unique characteristics. After the sequence is completed, opening a port is often accomplished by the host based firewall, but could also be implemented by custom software.
detection: Record network packets sent to and from the system, looking for extraneous packets that do not belong to established flows.
examples: Chaos provides a reverse shell is triggered upon receipt of a packet with a special string, sent to any port.[2]
Umbreon provides additional access using its backdoor Espeon, providing a reverse shell upon receipt of a special packet[3]
mitigations: Mitigation of some variants of this technique could be achieved through the use of stateful firewalls, depending upon how it is implemented.
tactic: Defense Evasion, Persistence, Command And Control
title: Port Knocking

description: A port monitor can be set through the  [1] API call to set a DLL to be loaded at startup. [1] This DLL can be located in C:\Windows\System32 and will be loaded by the print spooler service, spoolsv.exe, on boot. The spoolsv.exe process also runs under SYSTEM level permissions. [2] Alternatively, an arbitrary DLL can be loaded if permissions allow writing a fully-qualified pathname for that DLL to HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Print\Monitors.
detection: Monitor process API calls to  [1].Monitor DLLs that are loaded by spoolsv.exe for DLLs that are abnormal.New DLLs written to the System32 directory that do not correlate with known good software or patching may be suspicious.Monitor Registry writes to HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Print\Monitors.Run the Autoruns utility, which checks for this Registry key as a persistence mechanism [4]
mitigations: APT38 installed a port monitoring tool, MAPMAKER, to print the active TCP connections on the local system.[3]
title: Port Monitors
version: File monitoring, API monitoring, DLL monitoring, Windows Registry, Process monitoring

data_sources: PowerShell logs, Loaded DLLs, DLL monitoring, Windows Registry, File monitoring, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters
description: PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system. [1] Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code. Examples include the Start-Process cmdlet which can be used to run an executable and the Invoke-Command cmdlet which runs a command locally or on a remote computer.
detection: If proper execution policy is set, adversaries will likely be able to define their own execution policy if they obtain administrator or system access, either through the Registry or at the command line. This change in policy on a system may be a way to detect malicious use of PowerShell. If PowerShell is not used in an environment, then simply looking for PowerShell execution may detect malicious activity.
examples: APT19 used PowerShell commands to execute payloads.[7]
APT28 downloads and executes PowerShell scripts.[8]
APT29 has used encoded PowerShell scripts uploaded to CozyCar installations to download and install SeaDuke. APT29 also used PowerShell scripts to evade defenses.[9][10][11]
APT3 has used PowerShell on victim systems to download and run payloads after exploitation.[12]
APT32 has used PowerShell-based tools, PowerShell one-liners, and shellcode loaders for execution.[13][14][15]
APT33 has utilized PowerShell to download files from the C2 server and run various scripts.[16]
AutoIt backdoor downloads a PowerShell script that decodes to a typical shellcode loader.[17]
BRONZE BUTLER has used PowerShell for execution.[20]
Cobalt Group has used powershell.exe to download and execute scripts.[21][22][23][24][25][26]
Cobalt Strike can execute a payload on a remote host with PowerShell. This technique does not write any data to disk.[27]
DarkHydrus leveraged PowerShell to download and execute additional scripts for execution.[29][30]
Deep Panda has used PowerShell scripts to download and execute programs in memory, without writing to disk.[31]
Dragonfly 2.0 used PowerShell scripts for execution.[33][34][35]
Emotet has used Powershell to retrieve the malicious payload and download additional resources like Mimikatz.[36][37][38][39][40]
Empire leverages PowerShell for the majority of its client-side agent tasks. Empire also contains the ability to conduct PowerShell remoting with the Invoke-PSRemoting module.[41][42]
FIN10 uses PowerShell for execution as well as PowerShell Empire to establish persistence.[43][41]
FIN6 has used a Metasploit PowerShell module to download and execute shellcode and to set up a local listener.[44][45]
FIN7 uses a PowerShell script to launch shellcode that retrieves an additional payload.[46][47]
FIN8's malicious spearphishing payloads are executed as PowerShell. FIN8 has also used PowerShell during and.[48][49]
Gallmaker used PowerShell to download additional payloads.[50]
Gorgon Group malware can use PowerShell commands to download and execute a payload and open a decoy document on the victim’s machine.[51]
HAMMERTOSS is known to use PowerShell.[52]
One version of Helminth uses a PowerShell script.[53]
JCry has used PowerShell to execute payloads.[54]
KeyBoy uses PowerShell commands to download and execute payloads.[55]
KONNI used PowerShell to download and execute a specific 64-bit version of the malware.[56]
Leviathan has used PowerShell for execution.[57][58]
Magic Hound has used PowerShell for execution and privilege escalation.[59][60]
menuPass uses PowerSploit to inject shellcode into PowerShell.[61]
MuddyWater has used PowerShell for execution.[63][64][65][66][67][68]
OilRig has used PowerShell scripts for execution, including use of a macro to run a PowerShell command to decode file contents.[18][69][70]
Patchwork used PowerSploit to download payloads, run a reverse shell, and execute malware on the victim's machine.[71][72]
The Poseidon Group's Information Gathering Tool (IGT) includes PowerShell components.[73]
POSHSPY uses PowerShell to execute various commands, one to execute its payload.[74]
PowerSploit modules are written in and executed via PowerShell.[77][78]
PowerStallion uses PowerShell loops to iteratively check for available commands in its OneDrive C2 server.[79]
POWERSTATS uses PowerShell for obfuscation and execution.[80][67]
Pupy has a module for loading and executing PowerShell scripts.[82]
QUADAGENT uses PowerShell scripts for execution.[83]
There is a variant of RATANKBA that uses a PowerShell script instead of the traditional PE form.[84][85]
Revenge RAT uses the PowerShell command Reflection.Assembly to load itself into memory to aid in execution.[86]
SeaDuke uses a module to execute Mimikatz with PowerShell to perform Pass the Ticket.[9]
Socksbot can write and execute PowerShell scripts.[72]
Soft Cell used PowerShell for execution to assist in lateral movement as well as for dumping credentials stored on compromised machines.[88]
SQLRat has used PowerShell to create a Meterpreter session.[89]
Stealth Falcon malware uses PowerShell commands to perform various functions, including gathering system information via WMI and executing commands from its C2 server.[90]
TA459 has used PowerShell for execution of a payload.[91]
TA505 has used PowerShell to download and execute malware and reconnaissance scripts.[92][93][94][95]
TEMP.Veles has used a publicly-available PowerShell-based tool, WMImplant. The group has also used PowerShell to perform Timestomping.[96][97]
Threat Group-3390 has used PowerShell for execution.[98]
Thrip leveraged PowerShell to run commands to download payloads, traverse the compromised networks, and carry out reconnaissance.[99]

Turla has used PowerShell to execute commands/scripts, in some cases via a custom executable or code from Empire's PSInject. Turla has also used PowerShell scripts to load and execute malware in memory.[100][79][101]
Ursnif  droppers have used PowerShell in download cradles to download and execute the malware's full executable payload.[102]
WIRTE has used PowerShell for script execution.[103]
Xbash can use scripts to invoke PowerShell to download a malicious PE executable or PE DLL for execution.[104]
Zeus Panda uses PowerShell to download and execute the payload.[105]
mitigations: Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts.
Disable or Remove Feature or Program

It may be possible to remove PowerShell from systems when not needed, but a review should be performed to assess the impact to an environment, since it could be in use for many legitimate purposes and administrative functions.Disable/restrict the WinRM Service to help prevent uses of PowerShell for remote execution.

When PowerShell is necessary, restrict PowerShell execution policy to administrators. Be aware that there are methods of bypassing the PowerShell execution policy, depending on environment configuration.
title: PowerShell

description: Private cryptographic keys and certificates are used for authentication, encryption/decryption, and digital signatures. [1]
detection: Monitor access to files and directories related to cryptographic keys and certificates as a means for potentially detecting access patterns that may indicate collection and exfiltration activity. Collect authentication logs and look for potentially abnormal activity that may indicate improper use of keys or certificates for remote authentication.
examples: Ebury has intercepted unencrypted private keys as well as private key pass-phrases.  [4]
Empire can use modules like Invoke-SessionGopher to extract private key and session information.[5]
jRAT can steal keys for VPNs and cryptocurrency wallets.[6]
Mimikatz's CRYPTO::Extract module can extract keys by interacting with Windows cryptographic application programming interface (API) functions.[7]
mitigations: Ensure only authorized keys are allowed access to critical resources and audit access lists regularly.
When possible, store keys on separate cryptographic hardware instead of on the local system.
Use separate infrastructure for managing critical systems to prevent overlap of credentials and permissions on systems that could be used as vectors for lateral movement.
Use strong passphrases for private keys to make cracking difficult.
Ensure permissions are properly set on folders containing sensitive private keys to prevent unintended access.
title: Private Keys

description: Adversaries may attempt to get information about running processes on a system. Information obtained could be used to gain an understanding of common software running on systems within the network.
detection: System and network discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as Lateral Movement, based on the information obtained.
mitigations: 4H RAT has the capability to obtain a listing of running processes (including loaded modules).[1]
Agent Tesla lists the current running processes on the system.[3]
APT1 gathered a list of running processes on the system using tasklist /v.[4]
An APT28 loader Trojan will enumerate the victim's processes searching for explorer.exe if its current process does not have necessary permissions.[5]
APT3 has a tool that can list out currently running processes.[6][7]
APT37's Freenki malware lists running processes using the Microsoft Windows API.[8]
APT38 leveraged Sysmon to understand the processes, services in the organization.[9]
Astaroth searches for different processes on the system.[10]
Azorult can collect a list of running processes by calling CreateToolhelp32Snapshot.[11][12]
Backdoor.Oldrea collects information about running processes.[13]
BACKSPACE may collect information about running processes.[14]
Bankshot identifies processes and collects the process ids.[15]
BISCUIT has a command to enumerate running processes and identify their owners.[17]
Bisonal can obtain a list of running processes on the victim’s machine.[18]
BLACKCOFFEE has the capability to discover processes.[19]
BlackEnergy has gathered a process list by using Tasklist.exe.[20][21]
Brave Prince lists the running processes.[22]
Cannon can obtain a list of processes running on the system.[23][24]
Carbon can list the processes on the victim’s machine.[26]
Cardinal RAT contains watchdog functionality that ensures its process is always running, else spawns a new instance.[27]
ChChes collects its process identifier (PID) on the victim.[28]
Cobalt Strike's "beacon" payload can collect information on process details.[29]
Comnie uses the tasklist to view running processes on the victim’s machine.[30]
Crimson contains a command to list processes.[31]
DarkComet can list active processes running on the victim’s machine.[32]
Darkhotel has searched for anti-malware strings and anti-virus processes running on the system.[33]
Deep Panda uses the Microsoft Tasklist utility to list processes running on systems.[34]
Derusbi collects current and parent process IDs.[35][36]
The discovery modules used with Duqu can collect information on process details.[37]
DustySky collects information about running processes from victims.[38]
Elise enumerates processes via the tasklist command.[39]
ELMER is capable of performing process listings.[40]
Emotet has been observed enumerating local processes.[41]
Empire can find information about processes running on local and remote systems.[42]
Epic uses the tasklist /v command to obtain a list of processes.[43][44]
EvilBunny has used EnumProcesses() to identify how many process are running in the environment.[45]
FELIXROOT collects a list of running processes.[46]
Final1stspy obtains a list of running processes.[47]
FinFisher checks its parent process for indications that it is running in a sandbox setup.[48][49]
FruitFly has the ability to list processes on the system.[50]
GeminiDuke collects information on running processes and environment variables from the victim.[51]
gh0st RAT has the capability to list processes.[52]
Gold Dragon checks the running processes on the victim’s machine.[22]
GravityRAT lists the running processes on the system.[53]
HALFBAKED can obtain information about running processes on the victim.[54]
Helminth has used Tasklist to get information on processes.[5]
Honeybee gathers a list of processes using the tasklist command and then is sent back to the control server.[55]
Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can monitor processes.[56][57]
iKitten lists the current processes running.[50]
InvisiMole obtains a list of running processes.[58]
JHUHUGIT obtains a list of running processes on the victim.[60][61]
jRAT can query and kill system processes.[63]
Kasidet has the ability to search for a given process name in processes currently running in the system.[64]
Kazuar obtains a list of running processes through WMI querying and the ps command.[65]
Ke3chang performs process discovery using tasklist commands.[66][67]
KEYMARBLE can obtain a list of running processes on the system.[68]
The OsInfo function in Komplex collects a running process list.[69]
Kwampirs collects a list of running services with the command tasklist /v.[70]

Several Lazarus Group malware families gather a list of running processes on a victim system and send it to their C2 server. A Destover-like variant used by Lazarus Group also gathers process times.[71][72][73][74]
Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve a list of running processes.[75]
Magic Hound malware can list running processes.[76]
MobileOrder has a command to upload information about all running processes to its C2 server.[77]
Molerats actors obtained a list of active processes on the victim and sent them to C2 servers.[38]
MoonWind has a command to return a list of running processes.[78]
Mosquito runs tasklist to obtain running processes.[79]
MuddyWater has used malware to obtain a list of running processes on the system.[80]
NavRAT uses tasklist /v to check running processes.[81]
NETEAGLE can send process listings over the C2 channel.[14]
OceanSalt can collect the name and ID for every process running on the system.[82]
OilRig has run tasklist on a victim's machine.[83]
Orz can gather a process list from the victim.[84]
Pasam creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve lists of running processes.[85]
PLAINTEE performs the tasklist command to list running processes.[86]
PlugX has a module to list the processes running on a machine.[87]
After compromising a victim, Poseidon Group lists all running processes.[89]
PowerDuke has a command to list the victim's processes.[90]
PowerSploit's Get-ProcessTokenPrivilege Privesc-PowerUp module can enumerate privileges for a given process.[91][92]
PowerStallion has been used to monitor process lists.[93]
POWRUNER may collect process information by running tasklist on a victim.[94]
Proxysvc lists processes running on the system.[74]
Pupy can list the running processes and get the process ID and parent process’s ID.[95]
Remsec can obtain a process list from the victim.[98]
RogueRobin checks the running processes for evidence it may be running in a sandbox environment. It specifically enumerates processes for Wireshark and Sysinternals.[99]
ROKRAT lists the current running processes on the system.[100]
RTM can obtain information about process integrity levels.[101]
Seasalt has a command to perform a process listing.[17]
SHOTPUT has a command to obtain a process listing.[102]
Socksbot can list all running processes.[103]
Stealth Falcon malware gathers a list of running processes.[104]
StreamEx has the ability to enumerate processes.[105]
Sykipot may gather a list of running processes by running tasklist /v.[106]
Tasklist can be used to discover processes running on a system.[109]
Trojan.Karagany can use tasklist to collect a list of running tasks.[13]
Tropic Trooper enumerates the running processes on the system.[110]

Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover running processes using the tasklist /v command. Turla RPC backdoors have also enumerated processes associated with specific open ports or named pipes.[43][93]
UBoatRAT can list running processes on the system.[111]
Ursnif  has gathered information about running processes.[112][113]
VERMIN can get a list of the processes and running tasks on the system.[114]
Volgmer can gather a list of processes.[115]
WinMM sets a WH_CBT Windows hook to collect information on process creation.[116]
Winnti Group looked for a specific process running on infected servers.[117]
XAgentOSX contains the getProcessList function to run ps aux to get running processes.[118]
yty gets an output of running processes using the tasklist command.[119]
Zebrocy uses the tasklist and wmic process get Capture, ExecutablePath commands to gather the processes running on the system.[23][120][24][121][122]
Zeus Panda checks for running processes on the victim’s machine.[123]
permissions_required: Administrator, SYSTEM may provide better process ownership details
title: Process Discovery

description: Windows Transactional NTFS (TxF) was introduced in Vista as a method to perform safe file operations. [1] To ensure data integrity, TxF enables only one transacted handle to write to a file at a given time. Until the write handle transaction is terminated, all other handles are isolated from the writer and may only read the committed version of the file that existed at the time the handle was opened. [2] To avoid corruption, TxF performs an automatic rollback if the system or application fails during a write transaction. [3]
detection: Monitor and analyze calls to CreateTranscation, CreateFileTransacted, RollbackTransaction, and other rarely used functions indicative of TxF activity. Process Doppelgänging also invokes an outdated and undocumented implementation of the Windows process loader via calls to NtCreateProcessEx and NtCreateThreadEx as well as API calls used to modify memory within another process, such as WriteProcessMemory. [4] [7]
mitigations: SynAck abuses NTFS transactions to launch and conceal malicious processes.[5][6]
title: Process Doppelgänging
version: Process whitelisting, Anti-virus, Whitelisting by file name or path, Signature-based detection

description: Process hollowing occurs when a process is created in a suspended state then its memory is unmapped and replaced with malicious code. Similar to Process Injection, execution of the malicious code is masked under a legitimate process and may evade defenses and detection analysis. [1] [2]
detection: Monitoring API calls may generate a significant amount of data and may not be directly useful for defense unless collected under specific circumstances for known bad sequences of calls, since benign use of API functions may be common and difficult to distinguish from malicious behavior. API calls that unmap process memory, such as ZwUnmapViewOfSection or NtUnmapViewOfSection, and those that can be used to modify memory within another process, such as WriteProcessMemory, may be used for this technique. [2]
mitigations: Astaroth searches for unins000.exe (GAS Tecnologia software), Syswow64\userinit.exe or System32\userinit.exe to evasively create a new process in suspended state.[3]
Azorult can decrypt the payload into memory, create a new suspended process of itself, then inject a decrypted payload to the new process and resume new process execution.[4]
BADNEWS has a command to download an .exe and use process hollowing to inject it into a new process.[5][6]
Bandook has been launched by starting iexplore.exe and replacing it with Bandook's payload.[7][8]
BBSRAT has been seen loaded into msiexec.exe through process hollowing to hide its execution.[9]
Cobalt Strike can use process hollowing for execution.[10]
Duqu is capable of loading executable code via process hollowing.[11]
Gorgon Group malware can use process hollowing to inject one of its trojans into another process.[12]
ISMInjector hollows out a newly created process RegASM.exe and injects its payload into the hollowed process.[13]
menuPass has used process hollowing in iexplore.exe to load the RedLeaves implant.[14]
Some Orz versions have an embedded DLL known as MockDll that uses process hollowing and Regsvr32 to execute another payload.[15]
A Patchwork payload uses process hollowing to hide the UAC bypass vulnerability exploitation inside svchost.exe.[16]
Smoke Loader spawns a new copy of c:\windows\syswow64\explorer.exe and then replaces the executable code in memory with malware.[17][18]
Ursnif  has used process hollowing to inject into child processes.[19]
title: Process Hollowing
version: Process whitelisting, Whitelisting by file name or path, Signature-based detection, Anti-virus

description: Process injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process. Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges. Execution via process injection may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked under a legitimate process.
detection: Monitoring Windows API calls indicative of the various types of code injection may generate a significant amount of data and may not be directly useful for defense unless collected under specific circumstances for known bad sequences of calls, since benign use of API functions may be common and difficult to distinguish from malicious behavior. API calls such as CreateRemoteThread, SuspendThread/SetThreadContext/ResumeThread, QueueUserAPC/NtQueueApcThread, and those that can be used to modify memory within another process, such as WriteProcessMemory, may be used for this technique. [1]
examples: APT37 injects its malware variant, ROKRAT, into the cmd.exe process.[12]
AuditCred can inject code from files to other running processes.[13]
BlackEnergy injects its DLL component into svchost.exe.[15]
Carbanak downloads an executable and injects it directly into a new process.[16]
Carbon has a command to inject code into a process.[17]
Cardinal RAT injects into a newly spawned process created from a native Windows executable.[18]
Cobalt Group has injected code into trusted processes.[19]
Cobalt Strike can inject a variety of payloads into processes dynamically chosen by the adversary.[20]
Denis injects its payload into Windows host processes.[21]
Derusbi injects itself into the secure shell (SSH) process.[22]

Duqu will inject itself into different processes to evade detection. The selection of the target process is influenced by the security software that is installed on the system (Duqu will inject into different processes depending on which security suite is installed on the infected host).[23]
Dyre injects into other processes to load modules.[24]
Elise injects DLL files into iexplore.exe.[25][26]
Emissary injects its DLL file into a newly spawned Internet Explorer process.[27]
Emotet has been observed injecting in to Explorer.exe and other processes.[28][29][30]
Empire contains multiple modules for injecting into processes, such as Invoke-PSInject.[31]
FinFisher injects itself into various processes depending on whether it is low integrity or high integrity.[32][33]

Gazer performs thread execution hijacking to inject its orchestrator into a running thread from a remote process. Gazer performs a separate injection of its communication module into an Internet accessible process through which it performs C2.[34][35]
Gorgon Group malware can download a remote access tool, ShiftyBug, and inject into another process.[36]
GreyEnergy has a module to inject a PE binary into a remote process.[37]
HiddenWasp adds itself to the LD_PRELOAD path and sets a series of environment variables.[38]
HIDEDRV injects a DLL for Downdelph into the explorer.exe process.[39]
Honeybee uses a batch file to load a DLL into the svchost.exe process.[40]
HOPLIGHT has injected into running processes.    [41]
HTRAN can inject into into running processes.[42]
HyperBro  can run shellcode it injects into a newly created process.[43]
JHUHUGIT performs code injection injecting its own functions to browser processes.[44][45]
JPIN can inject content into lsass.exe to load a module.[46]

If running in a Windows environment, Kazuar saves a DLL to disk that is injected into the explorer.exe process to execute the payload. Kazuar can also be configured to inject and execute within specific processes.[47]
Koadic can perform process injection by using a reflective DLL.[48]
A Lazarus Group malware sample performs reflective DLL injection.[49]
Matroyshka uses reflective DLL injection to inject the malicious library and execute the RAT.[50]
NavRAT copies itself into a running Internet Explorer process to evade detection.[51]
PLATINUM has used various methods of process injection including hot patching.[46]
PoisonIvy can inject a malicious DLL into a process.[52][53]
PoshC2 contains multiple modules for injecting into processes, such as Invoke-PSInject.[54]
PowerSploit contains a collection of CodeExecution modules that enable by injecting code (DLL, shellcode) or reflectively loading a Windows PE file into a process.[55][56]
Pupy can migrate into another process using reflective DLL injection.[57]

An executable dropped onto victims by Putter Panda aims to inject the specified DLL into a process that would normally be accessing the network, including Outlook Express (msinm.exe), Outlook (outlook.exe), Internet Explorer (iexplore.exe), and Firefox (firefox.exe).[58]

After decrypting itself in memory, RARSTONE downloads a DLL file from its C2 server and loads it in the memory space of a hidden Internet Explorer process. This "downloaded" file is actually not dropped onto the system.[59]
RATANKBA performs a reflective DLL injection using a given pid.[60][61]
Remcos has a command to hide itself through injecting into another process.[62]
Smoke Loader injects into the Internet Explorer process.[64]
Socksbot creates a suspended svchost process and injects its DLL into it.[65]
StoneDrill has relied on injecting its payload directly into the process memory of the victim's preferred browser.[66]
Sykipot injects itself into running instances of outlook.exe, iexplore.exe, or firefox.exe.[67]
A Threat Group-3390 tool can spawn svchost.exe and inject the payload into that process.[69][70]
TrickBot injects into the svchost.exe process.[71][72][73]
Tropic Trooper has injected a DLL backdoor into a file dllhost.exe.[74]

Turla has used Metasploit to perform reflective DLL injection in order to escalate privileges. Turla has also used PowerSploit's Invoke-ReflectivePEInjection.ps1 to reflectively load a PowerShell payload into a random process on the victim system.[75][76][77]
TURNEDUP is capable of injecting code into the APC queue of a created Rundll32 process as part of an "Early Bird injection."[4]
Ursnif  has injected code into target processes via thread local storage callbacks.[78][79][80]
Wiarp creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can inject files into running processes.[81]
Wingbird performs multiple process injections to hijack system processes and execute malicious code.[82]
Zeus Panda checks processes on the system and if they meet the necessary requirements, it injects into that process.[83]
mitigations: Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process.

>LinuxUtilize Yama to mitigate ptrace based process injection by restricting the use of ptrace to privileged users only. Other mitigation controls involve the deployment of security kernel modules that provide advanced access control and process restrictions such as SELinux, grsecurity, and AppAmour.<
title: Process Injection
version: API monitoring, Windows Registry, File monitoring, DLL monitoring, Process monitoring, Named Pipes

data_sources: Windows Registry, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters
description: Adversaries may interact with the Windows Registry to gather information about the system, configuration, and installed software.
detection: System and network discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as Lateral Movement, based on the information obtained.
mitigations: APT32's backdoor can query the Windows Registry to gather system information.[4]
Azorult can check for installed software on the system under the Registry key Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall.[5]
BACKSPACE is capable of enumerating and making modifications to an infected system's Registry.[6]
Bankshot searches for certain Registry keys to be configured before executing the payload.[7]
Brave Prince gathers information about the Registry.[8]
Carbanak checks the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings for proxy configurations information.[9]
Carbon enumerates values in the Registry.[10]
Cardinal RAT contains watchdog functionality that periodically ensures HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\Load is set to point to its executable.[11]
CHOPSTICK provides access to the Windows Registry, which can be used to gather information.[12]
Denis queries the Registry for keys and values.[13]
Derusbi is capable of enumerating Registry keys and values.[14]
DownPaper searches and reads the value of the Windows Update Registry Run key.[15]
Dragonfly 2.0 queried the Registry to identify victim information.[16]
Epic uses the rem reg query command to obtain values from Registry keys.[17]
FELIXROOT queries the Registry for specific keys for potential privilege escalation and proxy information. FELIXROOT has also used WMI to query the Windows Registry.[18][19]
FinFisher queries Registry values as part of its anti-sandbox checks.[20][21]
Gold Dragon enumerates registry keys with the command regkeyenum and obtains information for the Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run.[8]
A variant of HOPLIGHT hooks lsass.exe, and lsass.exe then checks the Registry for the data value 'rdpproto' under the key SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa Name.[22]
Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve system information, such as CPU speed, from Registry keys.[23][24]
InvisiMole can enumerate Registry values, keys, and data.[25]

Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia checks Registry keys within HKCU and HKLM to determine if certain applications are present, including SecureCRT, Terminal Services, RealVNC, TightVNC, UltraVNC, Radmin, mRemote, TeamViewer, FileZilla, pcAnyware, and Remote Desktop. Another Lazarus Group malware sample checks for the presence of the following Registry key:HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Bitcoin\Bitcoin-Qt.[27][28][29]
OilRig has used reg query "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Default" on a victim to query the Registry.[30]
OSInfo queries the registry to look for information about Terminal Services.[31]
PlugX can enumerate and query for information contained within the Windows Registry.[32][33]
POWERSOURCE queries Registry keys in preparation for setting Run keys to achieve persistence.[34]
PowerSploit contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can query Registry keys for potential opportunities.[35][36]
POWRUNER may query the Registry by running reg query on a victim.[37]

Proxysvc gathers product names from the Registry key: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion ProductName and the processor description from the Registry key HKLM\HARDWARE\DESCRIPTION\System\CentralProcessor\0 ProcessorNameString.[38]
QUADAGENT checks if a value exists within a Registry key in the HKCU hive whose name is the same as the scheduled task it has created.[39]
RATANKBA uses the command reg query "HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\InternetSettings".[40]
Reaver queries the Registry to determine the correct Startup path to use for persistence.[41]
Reg may be used to gather details from the Windows Registry of a local or remote system at the command-line interface.[42]
ROKRAT accesses the HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\mssmbios\Data\SMBiosData Registry key to obtain the System manufacturer value to identify the machine type.[43]
Shamoon queries several Registry keys to identify hard disk partitions to overwrite.[44]
Stealth Falcon malware attempts to determine the installed version of .NET by querying the Registry.[45]
StoneDrill has looked in the registry to find the default browser path.[46]
SynAck enumerates Registry keys associated with event logs.[47]
A Threat Group-3390 tool can read and decrypt stored Registry values.[48]

Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover information in the Windows Registry with the reg query command. Turla has also retrieved PowerShell payloads hidden in Registry keys as well as checking keys associated with null session named pipes .[17][49]
Ursnif  has used Reg to query the Registry for installed programs.[50][51]
Volgmer checks the system for certain Registry keys.[52]
Zebrocy executes the reg query command to obtain information in the Registry.[54]
Zeus Panda checks for the existence of a Registry key and if it contains certain values.[55]
title: Query Registry

description: During the boot process, macOS executes source /etc/rc.common, which is a shell script containing various utility functions. This file also defines routines for processing command-line arguments and for gathering system settings, and is thus recommended to include in the start of Startup Item Scripts [1]. In macOS and OS X, this is now a deprecated technique in favor of launch agents and launch daemons, but is currently still used.
detection: The /etc/rc.common file can be monitored to detect changes from the company policy. Monitor process execution resulting from the rc.common script for unusual or unknown applications or behavior.
examples: iKitten adds an entry to the rc.common file for persistence.[3]
mitigations: Limit privileges of user accounts so only authorized users can edit the rc.common file.
title: Rc.common

description: Starting in Mac OS X 10.7 (Lion), users can specify certain applications to be re-opened when a user reboots their machine. While this is usually done via a Graphical User Interface (GUI) on an app-by-app basis, there are property list files (plist) that contain this information as well located at ~/Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow.plist and ~/Library/Preferences/ByHost/com.apple.loginwindow.* .plist.
detection: Monitoring the specific plist files associated with reopening applications can indicate when an application has registered itself to be reopened.
mitigations: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
This feature can be disabled entirely with the following terminal command: defaults write -g ApplePersistence -bool no.
Holding the Shift key while logging in prevents apps from opening automatically.
title: Re-opened Applications

data_sources: Process monitoring, Process use of network, Packet capture, Network protocol analysis, File monitoring, Authentication logs, Binary file metadata
description: Adversaries may use more than one remote access tool with varying command and control protocols as a hedge against detection. If one type of tool is detected and blocked or removed as a response but the organization did not gain a full understanding of the adversary's tools and access, then the adversary will be able to retain access to the network. Adversaries may also attempt to gain access to Valid Accounts to use External Remote Services such as external VPNs as a way to maintain access despite interruptions to remote access tools deployed within a target network. [1]
detection: Existing methods of detecting remote access tools are helpful. Backup remote access tools or other access points may not have established command and control channels open during an intrusion, so the volume of data transferred may not be as high as the primary channel unless access is lost.
examples: 3PARA RAT will sleep until after a date/time value loaded from a .dat file has passed. This allows the RAT to remain dormant until a set date, which could allow a means to regain access if other parts of the actors' toolset are removed from a victim.[2]
APT3 has been known to use multiple backdoors per campaign.[3]
Cobalt Group has used TeamViewer to preserve remote access in case control using the Cobalt Strike module was lost.[4]
FIN5 maintains access to victim environments by using Valid Accounts to access External Remote Services as well as establishing a backup RDP tunnel by using FLIPSIDE.[5]
Leafminer used a tool called Imecab to set up a persistent remote access account on the victim machine.[6]

OilRig has used RGDoor via Web shell to establish redundant access. The group has also used harvested credentials to gain access to Internet-accessible resources such as Outlook Web Access, which could be used for redundant access.[7]
Stolen Pencil has a tool to add a Windows admin account in order to allow them to ensure continued access via RDP.[8]
Threat Group-3390 has deployed backup web shells and obtained OWA account credentials during intrusions that it subsequently used to attempt to regain access when evicted from a victim network.[9]
mitigations: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and will be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.[10]
title: Redundant Access

description: Adding an entry to the "run keys" in the Registry or startup folder will cause the program referenced to be executed when a user logs in. [1] These programs will be executed under the context of the user and will have the account's associated permissions level.
mitigations: ADVSTORESHELL achieves persistence by adding itself to the HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run Registry key.[4][5][6]
Agent Tesla adds itself to the Registry as a startup program to establish persistence.[7]
APT18 establishes persistence via the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run key.[8][9]
An APT19 HTTP malware variant establishes persistence by setting the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Windows Debug Tools-%LOCALAPPDATA%\.[10]
APT29 added Registry Run keys to establish persistence.[11]
APT3 places scripts in the startup folder for persistence.[12]
APT32 established persistence using Registry Run keys, both to execute PowerShell and VBS scripts as well as to execute their backdoor directly.[13][14][15]
APT33 has deployed a tool known as DarkComet to the Startup folder of a victim.[16]
APT37's has added persistence via the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\.[17][18]
APT39 has maintained persistence using the startup folder.[19]
Astaroth creates a startup item for persistence.[20]
Backdoor.Oldrea adds Registry Run keys to achieve persistence.[21]
BACKSPACE achieves persistence by creating a shortcut to itself in the CSIDL_STARTUP directory.[22]
BADNEWS installs a registry Run key to establish persistence.[23]
BadPatch establishes a foothold by adding a link to the malware executable in the startup folder.[24]

BBSRAT has been loaded through DLL side-loading of a legitimate Citrix executable that is set to persist through the Registry Run key location HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ssonsvr.exe.
Bisonal adds itself to the Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\ for persistence.[25]
The BlackEnergy 3 variant drops its main DLL component and then creates a .lnk shortcut to that file in the startup folder.[26]
Briba creates run key Registry entries pointing to malicious DLLs dropped to disk.[27]
BRONZE BUTLER has used a batch script that adds a Registry Run key to establish malware persistence.[28]
Carbanak stores a configuration files in the startup directory to automatically execute commands in order to persist across reboots.[29]
Cardinal RAT establishes Persistence by setting the  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\Load Registry key to point to its executable.[30]
ChChes establishes persistence by adding a Registry Run key.[31]
Cobalt Group has used Registry Run keys for persistence. The group has also set a Startup path to launch the PowerShell shell command and download Cobalt Strike.[32]
Cobian RAT creates an autostart Registry key to ensure persistence.[33]
Comnie achieves persistence by adding a shortcut of itself to the startup path in the Registry.[34]

CORESHELL has established persistence by creating autostart extensibility point (ASEP) Registry entries in the Run key and other Registry keys, as well as by creating shortcuts in the Internet Explorer Quick Start folder.[35]

One persistence mechanism used by CozyCar is to set itself to be executed at system startup by adding a Registry value under one of the following Registry keys: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run[36]
CrossRAT uses run keys for persistence on Windows
Dark Caracal's version of Bandook adds a registry key to HKEY_USERS\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run for persistence.[37]
DarkComet adds several Registry entries to enable automatic execution at every system startup.[38][39]
Darkhotel has been known to establish persistence by adding programs to the Run Registry key.[40]
DownPaper uses PowerShell to add a Registry Run key in order to establish persistence.[41]
Dragonfly 2.0 added the registry value ntdll to the Registry Run key to establish persistence.[42]
DustySky achieves persistence by creating a Registry entry in HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run.[43]

If establishing persistence by installation as a new service fails, one variant of Elise establishes persistence for the created .exe file by setting the following Registry key: HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\svchost : %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Network\svchost.exe. Other variants have set the following Registry keys for persistence: HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\imejp : [self] and HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\IAStorD.[44][45]
Variants of Emissary have added Run Registry keys to establish persistence.[46]
Emotet has been observed adding the downloaded payload to the HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run key to maintain persistence.[47][48][49]
Empire can modify the registry run keys HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run and HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run for persistence.[50]
EvilBunny has created Registry keys for persistence in [HKLM|HKCU]\…\CurrentVersion\Run.    [51]
EvilGrab adds a Registry Run key for ctfmon.exe to establish persistence.[31]
FELIXROOT adds a shortcut file to the startup folder for persistence.[52]
FIN10 has established persistence by using the Registry option in PowerShell Empire to add a Run key.[53][50]
FIN6 has used Registry Run keys to establish persistence for its downloader tools known as HARDTACK and SHIPBREAD.[54]
FIN7 malware has created Registry Run and RunOnce keys to establish persistence, and has also added items to the Startup folder.[55][56]
Final1stspy creates a Registry Run key to establish persistence.[57]
FinFisher establishes persistence by creating the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\Run.[58][59]
FLASHFLOOD achieves persistence by making an entry in the Registry's Run key.[22]
Gazer can establish persistence by creating a .lnk file in the Start menu.[60][61]
gh0st RAT adds a Registry Run key to establish persistence.[62]
Gold Dragon establishes persistence in the Startup folder.[63]
Gorgon Group malware can create a .lnk file and add a Registry Run key to establish persistence.[64]
Helminth establishes persistence by creating a shortcut in the Start Menu folder.[65]
Hi-Zor creates a Registry Run key to establish persistence.[66]
Honeybee uses a batch file that configures the ComSysApp service to autostart in order to establish persistence.[67]

HTTPBrowser has established persistence by setting the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run key value for wdm to the path of the executable. It has also used the Registry entry HKEY_USERS\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run vpdn "%ALLUSERPROFILE%\%APPDATA%\vpdn\VPDN_LU.exe" to establish persistence.[68][69]
Some InnaputRAT variants establish persistence by modifying the Registry key HKU\\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run:%appdata%\NeutralApp\NeutralApp.exe.[70]
Ixeshe can achieve persistence by adding itself to the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run Registry key.[71]
JCry has created payloads in the Startup directory to maintain persistence.[72]
JHUHUGIT has used a Registry Run key to establish persistence by executing JavaScript code within the rundll32.exe process.[73]
Kasidet creates a Registry Run key to establish persistence.[74][75]
Kazuar adds a sub-key under several Registry run keys.[76]
Several Ke3chang backdoors achieved persistence by adding a Run key.[77]
A version of KONNI drops a Windows shortcut into the Startup folder to establish persistence.[78]
Lazarus Group malware attempts to maintain persistence by saving itself in the Start menu folder or by adding a Registry Run key.[79][80][81]
Leviathan has used JavaScript to create a shortcut file in the Startup folder that points to its main backdoor.[82][83]
LoJax has modified the Registry key ‘HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\BootExecute’ from ‘autocheck autochk ’ to ‘autocheck autoche
permissions_required: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE keys require administrator access to create and modify
title: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder

description: Regsvcs and Regasm are Windows command-line utilities that are used to register .NET Component Object Model (COM) assemblies. Both are digitally signed by Microsoft. [1] [2]
detection: Use process monitoring to monitor the execution and arguments of Regsvcs.exe and Regasm.exe. Compare recent invocations of Regsvcs.exe and Regasm.exe with prior history of known good arguments and executed binaries to determine anomalous and potentially adversarial activity. Command arguments used before and after Regsvcs.exe or Regasm.exe invocation may also be useful in determining the origin and purpose of the binary being executed.
mitigations: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Regsvcs and Regasm may not be necessary within a given environment.
Block execution of Regsvcs.exe and Regasm.exe if they are not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries.
title: Regsvcs/Regasm

data_sources: Loaded DLLs, Process monitoring, Windows Registry, Process command-line parameters
description: Regsvr32.exe is a command-line program used to register and unregister object linking and embedding controls, including dynamic link libraries (DLLs), on Windows systems. Regsvr32.exe can be used to execute arbitrary binaries. [1]
detection: Use process monitoring to monitor the execution and arguments of regsvr32.exe. Compare recent invocations of regsvr32.exe with prior history of known good arguments and loaded files to determine anomalous and potentially adversarial activity. Command arguments used before and after the regsvr32.exe invocation may also be useful in determining the origin and purpose of the script or DLL being loaded. [3]
examples: APT19 used Regsvr32 to bypass application whitelisting techniques.[5]

APT32 created a Scheduled Task that used regsvr32.exe to execute a COM scriptlet that dynamically downloaded a backdoor and injected it into memory. The group has also used regsvr32 to run their backdoor.[6][7][8]
Astaroth can be loaded through regsvr32.exe.[9]
Cobalt Group has used regsvr32.exe to execute scripts.[10][11][12]
Deep Panda has used regsvr32.exe to execute a server variant of Derusbi in victim networks.[13]
Derusbi variants have been seen that use Registry persistence to proxy execution through regsvr32.exe.[14]
Hi-Zor executes using regsvr32.exe called from the Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder persistence mechanism.[15]
Koadic can use Regsvr32 to execute additional payloads.[16]
Leviathan has used regsvr32 for execution.[17]
Some Orz versions have an embedded DLL known as MockDll that uses Process Hollowing and regsvr32 to execute another payload.[17]
RogueRobin uses regsvr32.exe to run a .sct file for execution.[18]
WIRTE has used Regsvr32.exe to trigger the execution of a malicious script.[19]
Xbash can use regsvr32 for executing scripts.[20]
mitigations: Microsoft's Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) feature can be used to block regsvr32.exe from being used to bypass whitelisting. Identify and block potentially malicious software executed through regsvr32 functionality by using application whitelisting tools, like Windows Defender Application Control, AppLocker, or Software Restriction Policies where appropriate.[21][22][23][24][25][26][27]
title: Regsvr32

data_sources: Network intrusion detection system, Network protocol analysis, Process use of network, Process monitoring
description: An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks. These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be whitelisted within a target environment. Remote access tools like VNC, Ammy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. [1]
detection: Monitor for applications and processes related to remote admin tools. Correlate activity with other suspicious behavior that may reduce false positives if these tools are used by legitimate users and administrators.
examples: Carbanak has a plugin for VNC and Ammyy Admin Tool.[4]
Carbanak used legitimate programs such as AmmyAdmin and Team Viewer for remote interactive C2 to target systems.[5]
Cobalt Group used the Ammyy Admin tool as well as TeamViewer for remote access.[6][7][8]
Dridex contains a module for VNC.[9]
Night Dragon has used several remote administration tools as persistent infiltration channels.[10]
Thrip used a cloud-based remote access software called LogMeIn for their attacks.[11]
mitigations: Use application whitelisting to mitigate installation and use of unapproved software that can be used for remote access.
Properly configure firewalls, application firewalls, and proxies to limit outgoing traffic to sites and services used by remote access tools.
Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures may be able to prevent traffic to remote access services.
title: Remote Access Tools

description: Remote desktop is a common feature in operating systems. It allows a user to log into an interactive session with a system desktop graphical user interface on a remote system. Microsoft refers to its implementation of the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) as Remote Desktop Services (RDS). [1] There are other implementations and third-party tools that provide graphical access Remote Services similar to RDS.
detection: Use of RDP may be legitimate, depending on the network environment and how it is used. Other factors, such as access patterns and activity that occurs after a remote login, may indicate suspicious or malicious behavior with RDP. Monitor for user accounts logged into systems they would not normally access or access patterns to multiple systems over a relatively short period of time.
examples: The APT1 group is known to have used RDP during operations.[6]
APT3 enables the Remote Desktop Protocol for persistence.[7]
APT39 has been seen using RDP for lateral movement and persistence.[8]
The Axiom group is known to have used RDP during operations.[9]
Carbanak enables concurrent Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP).[10]
Cobalt Group has used Remote Desktop Protocol to conduct lateral movement.[11]
Cobalt Strike can start a VNC-based remote desktop server and tunnel the connection through the already established C2 channel.[12]
DarkComet can open an active screen of the victim’s machine and take control of the mouse and keyboard.[13]
FIN10 has used RDP to move laterally to systems in the victim environment.[16]
FIN6 used RDP to move laterally in victim networks.[17][18]
Koadic can enable remote desktop on the victim's machine.[21]
Lazarus Group malware SierraCharlie uses RDP for propagation.[22][23]
Leviathan has targeted RDP credentials and used it to move through the victim environment. [24]
menuPass has used RDP connections to move across the victim network.[25][26]
njRAT has a module for performing remote desktop access.[27]
OilRig has used Remote Desktop Protocol for lateral movement. The group has also used tunneling tools to tunnel RDP into the environment.[28][29]
Patchwork attempted to use RDP to move laterally.[30]
Pupy can enable/disable RDP connection and can start a remote desktop session using a browser web socket client.[31]
QuasarRAT has a module for performing remote desktop access.[32][33]
Revenge RAT has a plugin to perform RDP access.[34]
ServHelper has commands for adding a remote desktop user and sending RDP traffic to the attacker through a reverse SSH tunnel.[35]
Stolen Pencil utilized RDP for direct remote point-and-click access.[36]
TEMP.Veles utilized RDP throughout an operation.   [37]
WannaCry enumerates current remote desktop sessions and tries to execute the malware on each session.[38]
zwShell has used RDP for lateral movement.[39]
mitigations: Audit the Remote Desktop Users group membership regularly. Remove unnecessary accounts and groups from Remote Desktop Users groups
Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Disable the RDP service if it is unnecessary.
Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Use multi-factor authentication for remote logins.[40]
Do not leave RDP accessible from the internet. Enable firewall rules to block RDP traffic between network security zones within a network.

Change GPOs to define shorter timeouts sessions and maximum amount of time any single session can be active. Change GPOs to specify the maximum amount of time that a disconnected session stays active on the RD session host server.[41]
Consider removing the local Administrators group from the list of groups allowed to log in through RDP.
Limit remote user permissions if remote access is necessary.
permissions_required: RDP service enabled, account in the Remote Desktop Users group.
title: Remote Desktop Protocol
version: Authentication logs, Netflow/Enclave netflow, Process monitoring

data_sources: File monitoring, Packet capture, Process use of network, Netflow/Enclave netflow, Network protocol analysis, Process monitoring
description: Files may be copied from one system to another to stage adversary tools or other files over the course of an operation. Files may be copied from an external adversary-controlled system through the Command and Control channel to bring tools into the victim network or through alternate protocols with another tool such as FTP. Files can also be copied over on Mac and Linux with native tools like scp, rsync, and sftp.
detection: Monitor for file creation and files transferred within a network over SMB. Unusual processes with external network connections creating files on-system may be suspicious. Use of utilities, such as FTP, that does not normally occur may also be suspicious.
examples: Agent Tesla can download additional files for execution on the victim’s machine.[1][2]
Agent.btz attempts to download an encrypted binary from a specified domain.[3]
APT18 can upload a file to the victim’s machine.[4]
APT28 has downloaded additional files, including by using a first-stage downloader to contact the C2 server to obtain the second-stage implant.[5][6][7]
APT3 has a tool that can copy files to remote machines.[8]
APT32 has added JavaScript to victim websites to download additional frameworks that profile and compromise website visitors.[9][10]
APT33 has downloaded additional files and programs from its C2 server. [11]
APT37 has downloaded second stage malware from compromised websites.[12][13]
APT38 used a backdoor, NESTEGG, that has the capability to download and upload files to and from a victim’s machine.[14]
Astaroth uses certutil and BITSAdmin to download additional malware.[15][16]
AuditCred can download files and additional malware.[17]
Azorult can download and execute additional files. Azorult has also downloaded a ransomware payload called Hermes.[18][19]
BADNEWS is capable of downloading additional files through C2 channels, including a new version of itself.[20][21][22]
BadPatch can download and execute or update malware.[23]
Bankshot uploads files and secondary payloads to the victim's machine.[24]
BISCUIT has a command to download a file from the C2 server.[25]
Bisonal has the capability to download files to execute on the victim’s machine.[26]
BITSAdmin can be used to create BITS Jobs to upload and/or download files.[27]
BONDUPDATER can download or upload files from its C2 server.[28]
Briba downloads files onto infected hosts.[29]
BRONZE BUTLER has used various tools to download files, including DGet (a similar tool to wget).[30]
Calisto has the capability to upload and download files to the victim's machine.[31]
CallMe has the capability to download a file to the victim from the C2 server.[32]
Cannon can download a payload for execution.[33]
Cardinal RAT is downloaded and installed via an executed Assess leadership areas of interest payload. Cardinal RAT can also download and execute additional payloads.[34]
certutil can be used to download files from a given URL.[35][36]
ChChes is capable of downloading files, including additional modules.[37][38][39]
China Chopper's server component can download remote files.[40][41][42]
CHOPSTICK is capable of performing remote file transmission.[43]
CloudDuke downloads and executes additional malware from either a Web address or a Microsoft OneDrive account.[44]
cmd can be used to copy files to a remotely connected system.[45]

Cobalt Group has used public sites such as github.com and sendspace.com to upload files and then download them to victim computers. The group's JavaScript backdoor is also capable of downloading files.[46][47][48]
CoinTicker executes a Python script to download its second stage.[49]
CORESHELL downloads another dropper from its C2 server.[50]
Crimson contains a command to retrieve files from its C2 server.[51]
DarkComet can load any files onto the infected machine to execute.[52][53]
DDKONG downloads and uploads files on the victim’s machine.[55]
Denis deploys additional backdoors and hacking tools to the system.[56]
DOGCALL can download and execute additional payloads.[58]
After downloading its main config file, Downdelph downloads multiple payloads from C2 servers.[59]
Dragonfly 2.0 copied and installed tools for operations once in the victim environment.[60][61]
DustySky searches for network drives and removable media and duplicates itself onto them.[62]
Dyre has a command to download and executes additional files.[63]
The Ritsol backdoor trojan used by Elderwood can download files onto a compromised host from a remote location.[64]
Elise can download additional files from the C2 server for execution.[65]
Emissary has the capability to download files from the C2 server.[66]
Empire can upload and download to and from a victim machine.[67]
EvilBunny has downloaded additional Lua scripts from the C2.[68]
Exaramel has a command to download a file from a remote server to execute.[69]
Expand can be used to download or upload a file over a network share.[70]
Felismus can download files from remote servers.[71]
FELIXROOT downloads and uploads files to and from the victim’s machine.[72][73]
FIN10 has deployed Meterpreter stagers and SplinterRAT instances in the victim network after moving laterally.[74]
FIN7 has downloaded additional malware to execute on the victim's machine, including by using a PowerShell script to launch shellcode that retrieves an additional payload.[75][76]
FIN8 has used remote code execution to download subsequent payloads.[77]
Tools used by Gamaredon Group are capable of downloading and executing additional payloads.[78]
Gazer can execute a task to download a file.[79][80]
gh0st RAT can download files to the victim’s machine.[81]
Gold Dragon can download additional components from the C2 server.[82]
Gorgon Group malware can download additional files from C2 servers.[83]
GreyEnergy can download additional modules and payloads.[73]
H1N1 contains a command to download and execute a file from a remotely hosted URL using WinINet HTTP requests.[84]
can download and execute a second-stage payload.[12]
HAWKBALL has downloaded additional files from the C2.[85]
Hi-Zor has the ability to upload and download files from its C2 server.[87]
HiddenWasp downloads a tar compressed archive from a download server to the system.[88]
HOPLIGHT has the ability to connect to a remote host in order to upload and download files.  [89]
HTTPBrowser is capable of writing a file to the compromised system from the C2 server.[90]
Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can download files and additional malware components.[91][92]
HyperBro  has the ability to download additional files.[93]
InvisiMole can upload files to the victim's machine for operations.[94]
Ixeshe can download and execute additional files.[95]
JHUHUGIT can retrieve an additional payload from its C2 server. JHUHUGIT has a command to download files to the victim’s machine.[96][97][98]
JPIN can download files and upgrade itself.[57]
jRAT can download and execute files.[99][100][101]
KARAE can upload and download files, including second-stage malware.[12]
Kasidet has the ability to download and execute additional files.[102]
Kazuar downloads additional plug-ins to load on the victim’s machine, including the ability to upgrade and replace its own binary.[103]
KeyBoy has a download and upload functionality.[104][105]
KEYMARBLE can upload files to the victim’s machine and can download additional payloads.[106]
KONNI can download files and execute them on the victim’s machine.[108]
Kwampirs downloads additional files from C2 servers.[109]
Several Lazarus Group malware families are capable of downloading and executing binaries from its C2 server.[110][111][112]
Leviathan has downloaded additional scripts and files from adversary-controlled servers. Leviathan has also used an uploader known as LUNCHMONEY that can exfiltrate files to Dropbox.[113][40]
LightNeuron has the ability to download and execute additional files.[114]
Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can download files onto compromised hosts.[115]

LockerGoga  has been observed moving around the victim network via SMB, indicating the actors behind this ransomware are manually copying files form computer to computer instead of self-propagating.[116]

LOWBALL uses the Dropbox API to request two files, one of which is the same file as the one dropped by the malicious email attachment. This is most likely meant to be a mechanism to update the compromised host with a new version of the LOWBALL malware.[117]
Magic Hound has downloaded additional code and files from servers onto victims.[118]
menuPass has installed updates and new malware on victims.[119][120]
Micropsia can download and execute an executable from the C2 server.[121][122]
MiniDuke can download additional encrypted backdoors onto the victim via GIF files.[123]
Misdat is capable of downloading files from the C2.[124]
Mivast has the capability to download and execute .exe files.[125]
MobileOrder has a command to download a file from the C2 server to the victim mobile device's SD card.[32]
More_eggs can download and launch additional payloads.[126]
Mosquito can upload and download files to the victim.[127]
MuddyWater has used malware that can upload additional files to the victim’s machine.[128][129]
NanHaiShu can download additional files from URLs.[113]

NDiskMonitor can download and execute a file from given URL.[22]

Nidiran can download and execute files.[133]
njRAT can upload and download files to and from the victim’s machine.[134]
NOKKI has downloaded a remote module for execution.[135]
Octopus can upload and download files to and from the victim’s machine.[[136]
