OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D has a command to download and execute a file on the victim’s machine.[141]
Pasam creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can upload files.[142]
Patchwork payloads download additional files from the C2 server.[143][22]
Pisloader has a command to upload a file to the victim machine.[144]
PLAINTEE has downloaded and executed additional plugins.[55]
PLATINUM has transferred files using the Intel® Active Management Technology (AMT) Serial-over-LAN (SOL) channel.[145]
PlugX has a module to download and execute files on the compromised machine.[146]
PoisonIvy creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can upload files.[147]
POSHSPY downloads and executes additional PowerShell code and Windows binaries.[148]
PowerDuke has a command to download a file.[149]
POWERSOURCE has been observed being used to download TEXTMATE and the Cobalt Strike Beacon payload onto victims.[150]
POWERSTATS can retrieve and execute additional PowerShell payloads from the C2 server.[151]
POWRUNER can download or upload files from its C2 server.[137]
Psylo has a command to download a file to the system from its C2 server.[32]
Pteranodon can download and execute additional files.[78]
PUNCHBUGGY can download additional files and payloads to compromised hosts.[152][153]
Pupy can upload and download to/from a victim machine.[154]
QuasarRAT can download files to the victim’s machine and execute them.[155][156]
Rancor has downloaded additional malware, including by using certutil.[55]
RARSTONE downloads its backdoor component from a C2 server and loads it directly into memory.[157]
RedLeaves is capable of downloading a file from a specified URL.[160]
Remcos can upload and download files to and from the victim’s machine.[161]
RemoteCMD copies a file over to the remote system before execution.[162]
Remsec contains a network loader to receive executable modules from remote attackers and run them on the local victim. It can also upload and download files over HTTP and HTTPS.[163][164]
Revenge RAT has the ability to upload and download files.[165]
RGDoor uploads and downloads files to and from the victim’s machine.[166]
RogueRobin can save a new file to the system from the C2 server.[167][168]
ROKRAT retrieves additional malicious payloads from the C2 server.[169]
Sakula has the capability to download files.[171]
SeaDuke is capable of uploading and downloading files.[172]
Seasalt has a command to download additional files.[25][25]
SEASHARPEE can download remote files onto victims.[173]
ServHelper may download additional files to execute.[174][175]
Shamoon can download an executable to run on the victim.[176]
SHUTTERSPEED can download and execute an arbitary executable.[12]
Smoke Loader downloads a new version of itself once it has installed. It also downloads additional plugins.[177]
Soft Cell dropped additional tools to victims during their operation, including portqry.exe, a renamed cmd.exe file, winrar, and HTRAN.[178]
SpeakUp downloads and executes additional files from a remote server.[179]
SQLRat can make a direct SQL connection to a Microsoft database controlled by the attackers, retrieve an item from the bindata table, then write and execute the file on disk.   [180]
StoneDrill has downloaded and dropped temporary files containing scripts; it additionally has a function to upload files from the victims machine.   [181]
TA505 has downloaded additional malware to execute on victim systems.[182][175][183]
TDTESS has a command to download and execute an additional file.[184]

After re-establishing access to a victim network, Threat Group-3390 actors download tools including gsecdump and WCE that are staged temporarily on websites that were previously compromised but never used.[90]
TrickBot downloads several additional files and saves them to the victim's machine.[185]
Trojan.Karagany can upload, download, and execute files on the victim.[186]
Turla has used shellcode to download Meterpreter after compromising a victim. Turla RPC backdoors can also download files onto victim machines.[187][188][189]
TURNEDUP is capable of downloading additional files.[190]
TYPEFRAME can upload and download files to the victim’s machine.[191]
UBoatRAT can upload and download files to the victim’s machine.[192]
Unknown Logger is capable of downloading remote files.[20]
UPPERCUT can download and upload files to and from the victim’s machine.[193]
Ursnif  has dropped payload and configuration files to disk. Ursnif  has also been used to download and execute additional payloads.[194][195]
VERMIN can download and upload files to the victim's machine.[197]
Volgmer can download remote files and additional payloads to the victim's machine.[198][199][200]
WannaCry attempts to copy itself to remote computers after gaining access via an SMB exploit.[201]
WEBC2 can download and execute a file.[202]
Wiarp creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can download files.[203]
WIRTE has downloaded PowerShell code from the C2 server to be executed.[204]
Xbash can download additional malicious files from its C2 server.[205]
XTunnel is capable of downloading additional files.[206]
Yahoyah uses HTTP GET requests to download other files that are executed in memory.[207]
Zebrocy obtains additional code to execute on the victim's machine, including the downloading of a secondary payload.[208][33][209][7]
ZeroT can download additional payloads onto the victim.[210]
Zeus Panda can download additional malware plug-in modules and execute them on the victim’s machine.[211]
ZLib has the ability to download files.[124]
mitigations: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware or unusual data transfer over known tools and protocols like FTP can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific obfuscation technique used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool C2 signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.[212]
title: Remote File Copy

description: An adversary may use Valid Accounts to log into a service specifically designed to accept remote connections, such as telnet, SSH, and VNC. The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.
detection: Correlate use of login activity related to remote services with unusual behavior or other malicious or suspicious activity. Adversaries will likely need to learn about an environment and the relationships between systems through Discovery techniques prior to attempting Lateral Movement.
examples: APT39 used secure shell (SSH) to move laterally among their targets.[1]
Cobalt Strike can SSH to a remote service.[2]
Empire contains modules for executing commands over SSH as well as in-memory VNC agent injection.[3]
GCMAN uses Putty and VNC for lateral movement.[4]
Leviathan used ssh for internal reconnaissance.[5]
menuPass has used Putty Secure Copy Client (PSCP) to transfer data.[6]
OilRig has used Putty to access compromised systems.[7]
Proton uses VNC to connect into systems.[8]
TEMP.Veles has relied on encrypted SSH-based tunnels to transfer tools and for remote command/program execution.[9]
mitigations: Use multi-factor authentication on remote service logons where possible.
Limit the accounts that may use remote services. Limit the permissions for accounts that are at higher risk of compromise; for example, configure SSH so users can only run specific programs.
permissions_required: Active remote service accepting connections and valid credentials
title: Remote Services

data_sources: Network protocol analysis, Process monitoring, Process use of network, Process command-line parameters
description: Adversaries will likely attempt to get a listing of other systems by IP address, hostname, or other logical identifier on a network that may be used for Lateral Movement from the current system. Functionality could exist within remote access tools to enable this, but utilities available on the operating system could also be used. Adversaries may also use local host files in order to discover the hostname to IP address mappings of remote systems.
detection: System and network discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as Lateral Movement, based on the information obtained.
mitigations: APT3 has a tool that can detect the existence of remote systems.[1][2]
APT32 used the net view command to show all shares available, including the administrative shares such as C$ and ADMIN$. APT32 also used the ping command.[3]
BRONZE BUTLER typically use ping and Net to enumerate systems.[4]
Carbon uses the net view command.[5]
Cobalt Strike uses the native Windows Network Enumeration APIs to interrogate and discover targets in a Windows Active Directory network.[6]
Comnie runs the net view command
Deep Panda has used ping to identify other machines of interest.[7]
Dragonfly 2.0 likely obtained a list of hosts in the victim environment.[8]
Epic uses the net view command on the victim’s machine.[9]
FIN5 has used the open source tool Essential NetTools to map the network and build a list of targets.[10]

FIN6 used publicly available tools (including Microsoft's built-in SQL querying tool, osql.exe) to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance against Active Directory, Structured Query Language (SQL) servers, and NetBIOS.[11]
FIN8 uses dsquery and other Active Directory utilities to enumerate hosts.[12]
Ke3chang has used network scanning and enumeration tools, including Ping.[13]
Kwampirs collects a list of available servers with the command net view.[14]
Leafminer used Microsoft’s Sysinternals tools to gather detailed information about remote systems.[15]

menuPass uses scripts to enumerate IP ranges on the victim network. menuPass has also issued the command net view /domain to a PlugX implant to gather information about remote systems on the network.[16][17]
MURKYTOP has the capability to identify remote hosts on connected networks.[18]
Commands such as net view can be used in Net to gather information about available remote systems.[19]
njRAT can identify remote hosts on connected networks.[20]
Nltest may be used to enumerate remote domain controllers using options such as /dclist and /dsgetdc.[21]
Olympic Destroyer uses Windows Management Instrumentation to enumerate all systems in the network.[22]
OSInfo performs a connection test to discover remote systems in the network[1]
Ping can be used to identify remote systems within a network.[23]
RATANKBA runs the net view /domain and net view commands.[24]
Remsec can ping or traceroute a remote host.[25]
Shamoon scans the C-class subnet of the IPs on the victim's interfaces.[26]
SHOTPUT has a command to list all servers in the domain, as well as one to locate domain controllers on a domain.[27]
Soft Cell used a modified version of nbtscan to identify available NetBIOS name servers over the network as well as ping to identify remote systems.[28]
Sykipot may use net view /domain to display hostnames of available systems on a network.[29]
Threat Group-3390 has used the net view command.[30]
Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover remote systems on a local network using the net view and net view /DOMAIN commands.[9]
WannaCry scans its local network segment for remote systems to try to exploit and copy itself to.[31]
yty uses the net view command for discovery.[32]
title: Remote System Discovery

description: Adversaries may move onto systems, possibly those on disconnected or air-gapped networks, by copying malware to removable media and taking advantage of Autorun features when the media is inserted into a system and executes. In the case of Lateral Movement, this may occur through modification of executable files stored on removable media or by copying malware and renaming it to look like a legitimate file to trick users into executing it on a separate system. In the case of Initial Access, this may occur through manual manipulation of the media, modification of systems used to initially format the media, or modification to the media's firmware itself.
detection: Monitor file access on removable media. Detect processes that execute from removable media after it is mounted or when initiated by a user. If a remote access tool is used in this manner to move laterally, then additional actions are likely to occur after execution, such as opening network connections for Command and Control and system and network information Discovery.
examples: Agent.btz drops itself onto removable media devices and creates an autorun.inf file with an instruction to run that file. When the device is inserted into another system, it opens autorun.inf and loads the malware.[1]
APT28 uses a tool to infect connected USB devices and transmit itself to air-gapped computers when the infected USB device is inserted.[2]
Part of APT28's operation involved using CHOPSTICK modules to copy itself to air-gapped machines and using files written to USB sticks to transfer data and command traffic.[3][2]
Darkhotel's selective infector modifies executables stored on removable media as a method of spreading across computers.[4]
DustySky searches for removable media and duplicates itself onto it.[5]
Flame contains modules to infect USB sticks and spread laterally to other Windows systems the stick is plugged into using Autorun functionality.[6]
H1N1 has functionality to copy itself to removable media.[7]
njRAT can be configured to spread via removable drives.[8]

APT30 may have used the SHIPSHAPE malware to move onto air-gapped networks. SHIPSHAPE targets removable drives to spread to other systems by modifying the drive to use Autorun to execute or by hiding legitimate document files and copying an executable to the folder with the same name as the legitimate document.[9]
Unknown Logger is capable of spreading to USB devices.[10]
Ursnif  has copied itself to and infected removable drives for propagation.[11][12]
USBStealer drops itself onto removable media and relies on Autorun to execute the malicious file when a user opens the removable media on another system.[13]
mitigations: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Disable Autorun if it is unnecessary. Disallow or restrict removable media at an organizational policy level if it is not required for business operations.[14][15]
Limit the use of USB devices and removable media within a network.
permissions_required: Removable media allowed, Autorun enabled or vulnerability present that allows for code execution
title: Replication Through Removable Media

data_sources: Process use of network, Process monitoring, Network protocol analysis, Network device logs
description: Adversaries may leverage the resources of co-opted systems in order to solve resource intensive problems which may impact system and/or hosted service availability.
detection: Consider monitoring process resource usage to determine anomalous activity associated with malicious hijacking of computer resources such as CPU, memory, and graphics processing resources. Monitor for suspicious use of network resources associated with cryptocurrency mining software. Monitor for common cryptomining software process names and files on local systems that may indicate compromise and resource usage.
mitigations: Lazarus Group has subset groups like Bluenoroff who have used cryptocurrency mining software on victim machines.[1]
title: Resource Hijacking

description: Rootkits are programs that hide the existence of malware by intercepting (i.e., Hooking) and modifying operating system API calls that supply system information. [1] Rootkits or rootkit enabling functionality may reside at the user or kernel level in the operating system or lower, to include a Hypervisor, Master Boot Record, or the System Firmware. [2]
detection: Some rootkit protections may be built into anti-virus or operating system software. There are dedicated rootkit detection tools that look for specific types of rootkit behavior. Monitor for the existence of unrecognized DLLs, devices, services, and changes to the MBR. [2]
mitigations: APT28 has used a UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) rootkit known as LoJax.[5][6]
Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit is a UEFI BIOS rootkit developed by the company Hacking Team to persist remote access software on some targeted systems.[7]
HiddenWasp uses a rootkit to hook and implement functions on the system.[8]
HIDEDRV is a rootkit that hides certain operating system artifacts.[9]
HTRAN can install a rootkit to hide network connections from the host OS.[10]
LoJax is a UEFI BIOS rootkit deployed to persist remote access software on some targeted systems.[6]
PoisonIvy starts a rootkit from a malicious file dropped to disk.[11]

Umbreon hides from defenders by hooking libc function calls, hiding artifacts that would reveal its presence, such as the user account it creates to provide access and undermining strace, a tool often used to identify malware.[12]
Uroburos is a rootkit used by Turla.[13]
Winnti Group used a rootkit to modify typical server functionality.[14]
title: Rootkit
version: File monitoring, Host intrusion prevention systems, Process whitelisting, Signature-based detection, System access controls, Whitelisting by file name or path, Anti-virus

data_sources: File monitoring, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters, Binary file metadata
description: The rundll32.exe program can be called to execute an arbitrary binary. Adversaries may take advantage of this functionality to proxy execution of code to avoid triggering security tools that may not monitor execution of the rundll32.exe process because of whitelists or false positives from Windows using rundll32.exe for normal operations.
detection: Use process monitoring to monitor the execution and arguments of rundll32.exe. Compare recent invocations of rundll32.exe with prior history of known good arguments and loaded DLLs to determine anomalous and potentially adversarial activity. Command arguments used with the rundll32.exe invocation may also be useful in determining the origin and purpose of the DLL being loaded.
examples: ADVSTORESHELL has used rundll32.exe in a Registry value to establish persistence.[3]
APT19 configured its payload to inject into the rundll32.exe.[4]

APT28 executed CHOPSTICK by using rundll32 commands such as rundll32.exe "C:\Windows\twain_64.dll". APT28 also executed a .dll for a first stage dropper using rundll32.exe. An APT28 loader Trojan saved a batch script that uses rundll32 to execute a DLL payload.[5][3][6][7][8]
APT29 has used rundll32.exe for execution.[9]
APT3 has a tool that can run DLLs.[10]

Bisonal uses rundll32.exe to execute as part of the Registry Run key it adds: HKEY_CURRENT_USER \Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\"vert" = "rundll32.exe c:\windows\temp\pvcu.dll , Qszdez".[11]
Briba uses rundll32 within Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder entries to execute malicious DLLs.[12]
Carbanak installs VNC server software that executes through rundll32.[13]
Comnie uses Rundll32 to load a malicious DLL.[14]
CopyKittens uses rundll32 to load various tools on victims, including a lateral movement tool named Vminst, Cobalt Strike, and shellcode.[15]
CORESHELL is installed via execution of rundll32 with an export named "init" or "InitW."[16]
The CozyCar dropper copies the system file rundll32.exe to the install location for the malware, then uses the copy of rundll32.exe to load and execute the main CozyCar component.[17]
DDKONG uses Rundll32 to ensure only a single instance of itself is running at once.[18]
After copying itself to a DLL file, a variant of Elise calls the DLL file using rundll32.exe.[19]
Variants of Emissary have used rundll32.exe in Registry values added to establish persistence.[20]
FELIXROOT uses Rundll32 for executing the dropper program.[21][22]
Rundll32.exe is used as a way of executing Flame at the command-line.[23]
A gh0st RAT variant has used rundll32 for execution.[24]
GreyEnergy uses PsExec locally in order to execute rundll32.exe at the highest privileges (NTAUTHORITY\SYSTEM).[22]
Koadic can use Rundll32 to execute additional payloads.[27]
Kwampirs uses rundll32.exe in a Registry value added to establish persistence.[28]
Matroyshka uses rundll32.exe in a Registry Run key value for execution as part of its persistence mechanism.[29]
Mosquito's launcher uses rundll32.exe in a Registry Key value to start the main backdoor capability.[30]
MuddyWater has used malware that leveraged rundll32.exe in a Registry Run key to execute a .dll.[31]
NOKKI has used rundll32 for execution.[32]
NotPetya uses rundll32.exe to install itself on remote systems when accessed via PsExec or wmic.[33]
Prikormka uses rundll32.exe to load its DLL.[35]
PUNCHBUGGY can load a DLL using Rundll32.[37]
RTM runs its core DLL file using rundll32.exe.[38]
Sakula calls cmd.exe to run various DLL files via rundll32.[39]
ServHelper contains a module for downloading and executing DLLs that leverages rundll32.exe.[40]
StreamEx uses rundll32 to call an exported function.[41]
TA505 has leveraged rundll32.exe to execute malicious DLLs.[42][40]
The Winnti installer loads a DLL using rundll32.[43]
mitigations: Microsoft's Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) feature can be used to block methods of using rundll32.exe to bypass whitelisting.
title: Rundll32

description: Adversaries may modify systems in order to manipulate the data as it is accessed and displayed to an end user.[1][2] By manipulating runtime data, adversaries may attempt to affect a business process, organizational understanding, and decision making.
detection: Inspect important application binary file hashes, locations, and modifications for suspicious/unexpected values.
examples: APT38 has used DYEPACK.FOX to manipulate PDF data as it is accessed to remove traces of fraudulent SWIFT transactions from the data displayed to the end user.[1]
mitigations: Identify critical business and system processes that may be targeted by adversaries and work to isolate and secure those systems against unauthorized access and tampering.
Prevent critical business and system processes from being replaced, overwritten, or reconfigured to load potentially malicious code.
title: Runtime Data Manipulation

data_sources: API monitoring, Authentication logs, Windows event logs
description: The Windows security identifier (SID) is a unique value that identifies a user or group account. SIDs are used by Windows security in both security descriptors and access tokens. [1] An account can hold additional SIDs in the SID-History Active Directory attribute [2], allowing inter-operable account migration between domains (e.g., all values in SID-History are included in access tokens).
detection: Examine data in user’s SID-History attributes using the PowerShell Get-ADUser Cmdlet [10], especially users who have SID-History values from the same domain. [11]
examples: Empire can add a SID-History to a user if on a domain controller.[4]

Mimikatz's MISC::AddSid module can appended any SID or user/group account to a user's SID-History. Mimikatz also utilizes SID-History Injection to expand the scope of other components such as generated Kerberos Golden Tickets and DCSync beyond a single domain.[5][6]
mitigations: Clean up SID-History attributes after legitimate account migration is complete.Consider applying SID Filtering to interforest trusts, such as forest trusts and external trusts, to exclude SID-History from requests to access domain resources. SID Filtering ensures that any authentication requests over a trust only contain SIDs of security principals from the trusted domain (i.e preventing the trusted domain from claiming a user has membership in groups outside of the domain).SID Filtering of forest trusts is enabled by default, but may have been disabled in some cases to allow a child domain to transitively access forest trusts. SID Filtering of external trusts is automatically enabled on all created external trusts using Server 2003 or later domain controllers. However note that SID Filtering is not automatically applied to legacy trusts or may have been deliberately disabled to allow inter-domain access to resources.SID Filtering can be applied by: Disabling SIDHistory on forest trusts using the netdom tool (netdom trust /domain: /EnableSIDHistory:no on the domain controller) Applying SID Filter Quarantining to external trusts using the netdom tool (netdom trust  /domain: /quarantine:yes on the domain controller)* Applying SID Filtering to domain trusts within a single forest is not recommended as it is an unsupported configuration and can cause breaking changes. If a domain within a forest is untrustworthy then it should not be a member of the forest. In this situation it is necessary to first split the trusted and untrusted domains into separate forests where SID Filtering can be applied to an interforest trust[7][8][9][6]
title: SID-History Injection
version: Vincent Le Toux; Alain Homewood, Insomnia Security

data_sources: API monitoring, Application logs, DLL monitoring, Loaded DLLs, Process monitoring, Windows Registry, Windows event logs
description: In user mode, Windows Authenticode [1] digital signatures are used to verify a file's origin and integrity, variables that may be used to establish trust in signed code (ex: a driver with a valid Microsoft signature may be handled as safe). The signature validation process is handled via the WinVerifyTrust application programming interface (API) function,  [2] which accepts an inquiry and coordinates with the appropriate trust provider, which is responsible for validating parameters of a signature. [3]
detection: Periodically baseline registered SIPs and trust providers (Registry entries and files on disk), specifically looking for new, modified, or non-Microsoft entries. [3]
mitigations: Enable whitelisting solutions such as AppLocker and/or Device Guard to block the loading of malicious SIP DLLs.
Restrict storage and execution of SIP DLLs to protected directories, such as C:\Windows, rather than user directories.

Ensure proper permissions are set for Registry hives to prevent users from modifying keys related to SIP and trust provider components. Components may still be able to be hijacked to suitable functions already present on disk if malicious modifications to Registry keys are not prevented.
title: SIP and Trust Provider Hijacking
version: Application whitelisting, Autoruns Analysis, Digital Certificate Validation, Process whitelisting, User Mode Signature Validation

description: Secure Shell (SSH) is a standard means of remote access on Linux and macOS systems. It allows a user to connect to another system via an encrypted tunnel, commonly authenticating through a password, certificate or the use of an asymmetric encryption key pair.
detection: Use of SSH may be legitimate, depending upon the network environment and how it is used. Other factors, such as access patterns and activity that occurs after a remote login, may indicate suspicious or malicious behavior with SSH. Monitor for user accounts logged into systems they would not normally access or access patterns to multiple systems over a relatively short period of time. Also monitor user SSH-agent socket files being used by different users.
examples: Ebury has hijacked the OpenSSH process by injecting into the existing session as opposed to creating a new session.[5]
mitigations: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Ensure that agent forwarding is disabled on systems that do not explicitly require this feature to prevent misuse.[6]
Ensure SSH key pairs have strong passwords and refrain from using key-store technologies such as ssh-agent unless they are properly protected.
Do not allow remote access via SSH as root or other privileged accounts.
Ensure proper file permissions are set and harden system to prevent root privilege escalation opportunities.
Ensure that all private keys are stored securely in locations where only the legitimate owner has access to with strong passwords and are rotated frequently.
permissions_required: SSH service enabled, trust relationships configured, established connections
title: SSH Hijacking

description: Utilities such as at and schtasks, along with the Windows Task Scheduler, can be used to schedule programs or scripts to be executed at a date and time. A task can also be scheduled on a remote system, provided the proper authentication is met to use RPC and file and printer sharing is turned on. Scheduling a task on a remote system typically required being a member of the Administrators group on the the remote system. [1]
detection: Monitor scheduled task creation from common utilities using command-line invocation. Legitimate scheduled tasks may be created during installation of new software or through system administration functions. Monitor process execution from the svchost.exe in Windows 10 and the Windows Task Scheduler taskeng.exe for older versions of Windows. [78] If scheduled tasks are not used for persistence, then the adversary is likely to remove the task when the action is complete. Monitor Windows Task Scheduler stores in %systemroot%\System32\Tasks for change entries related to scheduled tasks that do not correlate with known software, patch cycles, etc. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as network connections made for Command and Control, learning details about the environment through Discovery, and Lateral Movement.
examples: APT18 actors used the native at Windows task scheduler tool to use scheduled tasks for execution on a victim network.[2]
APT29 used named and hijacked scheduled tasks to establish persistence.[3]
An APT3 downloader creates persistence by creating the following scheduled task: schtasks /create /tn "mysc" /tr C:\Users\Public\test.exe /sc ONLOGON /ru "System".[4]
APT32 has used scheduled tasks to persist on victim systems.[5][6][7][8]
APT33 has created a scheduled task to execute a .vbe file multiple times a day.[9]
at can be used to schedule a task on a system.[11]
BADNEWS creates a scheduled task to establish by executing a malicious payload every subsequent minute.[12]
BONDUPDATER persists using a scheduled task that executes every minute.[13]
BRONZE BUTLER has used at and schtasks to register a scheduled task to execute malware during lateral movement.[14]
Carbon creates several tasks for later execution to continue persistence on the victim’s machine.[15]
Cobalt Group has created Windows tasks to establish persistence.[16]
CosmicDuke uses scheduled tasks typically named "Watchmon Service" for persistence.[17]
One persistence mechanism used by CozyCar is to register itself as a scheduled task.[18]
Dragonfly 2.0 used scheduled tasks to automatically log out of created accounts every 8 hours as well as to execute malicious files.[19][20]

Adversaries can instruct Duqu to spread laterally by copying itself to shares it has enumerated and for which it has obtained legitimate credentials (via keylogging or other means). The remote host is then infected by using the compromised credentials to schedule a task on remote machines that executes the malware.[21]
Emotet has maintained persistence through a scheduled task.[22]
Empire has modules to interact with the Windows task scheduler.[23]
EvilBunny has executed commands via scheduled tasks.[24]
FIN10 has established persistence by using S4U tasks as well as the Scheduled Task option in PowerShell Empire.[25][23]
FIN6 has used scheduled tasks to establish persistence for various malware it uses, including downloaders known as HARDTACK and SHIPBREAD and PoS malware known as TRINITY.[26]
FIN7 malware has created scheduled tasks to establish persistence.[27][28][29][30]
FIN8 has used scheduled tasks to maintain RDP backdoors.[31]
Gazer can establish persistence by creating a scheduled task.[32][33]
GravityRAT creates a scheduled task to ensure it is re-executed everyday.[34]
Helminth has used a scheduled task for persistence.[35]
ISMInjector creates scheduled tasks to establish persistence.[36]
JHUHUGIT has registered itself as a scheduled task to run each time the current user logs in.[37][38]
Matroyshka can establish persistence by adding a Scheduled Task named "Microsoft Boost Kernel Optimization".[39][40]
menuPass has used a script (atexec.py) to execute a command on a target machine via Task Scheduler.[41]
MURKYTOP has the capability to schedule remote AT jobs.[42]
NotPetya creates a task to reboot the system one hour after infection.[43]
OilRig has created scheduled tasks that run a VBScript to execute a payload on victim machines.[44][45]
OopsIE creates a scheduled task to run itself every three minutes.[44][46]
A Patchwork file stealer can run a TaskScheduler DLL to add persistence.[47]
PowerSploit's New-UserPersistenceOption Persistence argument can be used to establish via a Scheduled Task.[48][49]

POWERSTATS has established persistence through a scheduled task using the command "C:\Windows\system32\schtasks.exe" /Create /F /SC DAILY /ST 12:00 /TN MicrosoftEdge /TR "c:\Windows\system32\wscript.exe C:\Windows\temp\Windows.vbe".[50]
POWRUNER persists through a scheduled task that executes it every minute.[51]
Pteranodon schedules tasks to invoke its components in order to establish persistence.[52]
QUADAGENT creates a scheduled task to maintain persistence on the victim’s machine.[45]
QuasarRAT contains a .NET wrapper DLL for creating and managing scheduled tasks for maintaining persistence upon reboot.[53]
Rancor launched a scheduled task to gain persistence using the schtasks /create /sc command.[54]
Remexi utilizes scheduled tasks as a persistence mechanism.[55]
RemoteCMD can execute commands remotely by creating a new schedule task on the remote system[56]
Remsec schedules the execution one of its modules by creating a new scheduler task.[57]
Revenge RAT schedules tasks to run malicious scripts at different intervals.[58]
RTM tries to add a scheduled task to establish persistence.[59]
schtasks is used to schedule tasks on a Windows system to run at a specific date and time.[60]
ServHelper contains modules that will use schtasks to carry out malicious operations.[61]
Shamoon copies an executable payload to the target system by using Windows Admin Shares and then scheduling an unnamed task to execute the malware.[62][63]
Silence has used scheduled tasks to stage its operation.[64]
Smoke Loader launches a scheduled task.[65]
Soft Cell established persistence for PoisonIvy by created a scheduled task.[66]
SQLRat has created scheduled tasks in %appdata%\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\.[30]
Stealth Falcon malware creates a scheduled task entitled "IE Web Cache" to execute a malicious file hourly.[67]
TEMP.Veles has used scheduled task XML triggers.[68]
Threat Group-3390 actors use at to schedule tasks to run self-extracting RAR archives, which install HTTPBrowser or PlugX on other victims on a network.[69]
TrickBot creates a scheduled task on the system that provides persistence.[70][71][72]
yty establishes persistence by creating a scheduled task with the command SchTasks /Create /SC DAILY /TN BigData /TR " + path_file + "/ST 09:30".[73]
zwShell has used SchTasks for execution.[74]
mitigations: Toolkits like the PowerSploit framework contain PowerUp modules that can be used to explore systems for permission weaknesses in scheduled tasks that could be used to escalate privileges.[75]

Configure settings for scheduled tasks to force tasks to run under the context of the authenticated account instead of allowing them to run as SYSTEM. The associated Registry key is located at HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\SubmitControl. The setting can be configured through GPO: Computer Configuration > [Policies] > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Local Policies > Security Options: Domain Controller: Allow server operators to schedule tasks, set to disabled.[76]

Configure the Increase Scheduling Priority option to only allow the Administrators group the rights to schedule a priority process. This can be can be configured through GPO: Computer Configuration > [Policies] > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Local Policies > User Rights Assignment: Increase scheduling priority.[77]
Limit privileges of user accounts and remediate Privilege Escalation vectors so only authorized administrators can create scheduled tasks on remote systems.
title: Scheduled Task
version: File monitoring, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters, Windows event logs

description: Data exfiltration may be performed only at certain times of day or at certain intervals. This could be done to blend traffic patterns with normal activity or availability.
detection: Monitor process file access patterns and network behavior. Unrecognized processes or scripts that appear to be traversing file systems and sending network traffic may be suspicious. Network connections to the same destination that occur at the same time of day for multiple days are suspicious.
examples: ADVSTORESHELL collects, compresses, encrypts, and exfiltrates data to the C2 server every 10 minutes.[1]
Cobalt Strike can set its "beacon" payload to reach out to the C2 server on an arbitrary and random interval. In addition it will break large data sets into smaller chunks for exfiltration.[2]
Dipsind can be configured to only run during normal working hours, which would make its communications harder to distinguish from normal traffic.[3]
jRAT can be configured to reconnect at certain intervals.[4]
Kazuar can sleep for a specific time and be set to communicate at specific intervals.[5]
LightNeuron can be configured to exfiltrate data during nighttime or working hours.[6]
Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can change the frequency at which compromised hosts contact remote C2 infrastructure.[7]
POWERSTATS can sleep for a given number of seconds.[8]
mitigations: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary command and control infrastructure and malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific obfuscation technique used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool command and control signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way to avoid detection by common defensive tools.[9]
permissions_required: Netflow/Enclave netflow, Process use of network, Process monitoring
title: Scheduled Transfer

description: Adversaries may attempt to take screen captures of the desktop to gather information over the course of an operation. Screen capturing functionality may be included as a feature of a remote access tool used in post-compromise operations.
detection: Monitoring for screen capture behavior will depend on the method used to obtain data from the operating system and write output files. Detection methods could include collecting information from unusual processes using API calls used to obtain image data, and monitoring for image files written to disk. The sensor data may need to be correlated with other events to identify malicious activity, depending on the legitimacy of this behavior within a given network environment.
mitigations: Agent Tesla can capture screenshots of the victim’s desktop.[2][3][4][5]
APT28 has used tools to take screenshots from victims.[6][7]
Azorult can capture screenshots of the victim’s machines.[8]
BADNEWS has a command to take a screenshot and send it to the C2 server.[9][10]
BadPatch captures screenshots in .jpg format and then exfiltrates them.[11]
Bandook is capable of taking an image of and uploading the current desktop.[12]
BISCUIT has a command to periodically take screenshots of the system.[13]
BlackEnergy is capable of taking screenshots.[14]
BRONZE BUTLER has used a tool to capture screenshots.[15]
Cannon can take a screenshot of the desktop.[16]
Carbanak performs desktop video recording and captures screenshots of the desktop and sends it to the C2 server.[17]
Catchamas captures screenshots based on specific keywords in the window’s title.[19]
CHOPSTICK has the capability to capture screenshots.[7]
Cobalt Strike's "beacon" payload is capable of capturing screen shots.[20]
Cobian RAT has a feature to perform screen capture.[21]
CosmicDuke takes periodic screenshots and exfiltrates them.[22]
Crimson contains a command to perform screen captures.[23]
CrossRAT is capable of taking screen captures.[12]
Dark Caracal took screen shots using their Windows malware.[12]
Derusbi is capable of performing screen captures.[25]
DOGCALL is capable of capturing screenshots of the victim's machine.[26][27]
Dragonfly 2.0 has performed screen captures of victims, including by using a tool, scr.exe (which matched the hash of ScreenUtil).[28][29]
Empire is capable of capturing screenshots on Windows and macOS systems.[30]
EvilGrab has the capability to capture screenshots.[31]
FIN7 captured screenshots and desktop video recordings.[32]

FinFisher takes a screenshot of the screen and displays it on top of all other windows for few seconds in an apparent attempt to hide some messages showed by the system during the setup process.[33][34]
Flame can take regular screenshots when certain applications are open that are sent to the command and control server.[35]
FruitFly takes screenshots of the user's desktop.[36]
gh0st RAT can capture the victim’s screen remotely.[37]
Malware used by Group5 is capable of watching the victim's screen.[38]
HALFBAKED can obtain screenshots from the victim.[39]
Hydraq includes a component based on the code of VNC that can stream a live feed of the desktop of an infected host.[40]
HyperBro  has the ability to take screenshots.[41]
InvisiMole can capture screenshots of not only the entire screen, but of each separate window open, in case they are overlapping.[42]
Janicab captured screenshots and sent them out to a C2 server.[43][44]

A JHUHUGIT variant takes screenshots by simulating the user pressing the "Take Screenshot" key (VK_SCREENSHOT), accessing the screenshot saved in the clipboard, and converting it to a JPG image.[45][46]
jRAT has the capability to take screenshots of the victim’s machine.[47][48]
Kasidet has the ability to initiate keylogging and screen captures.[49]
Kazuar captures screenshots of the victim’s screen.[50]
KeyBoy has a command to perform screen grabbing.[51]
KEYMARBLE can capture screenshots of the victim’s machine.[52]
KONNI can take screenshots of the victim’s machine.[53]
MacSpy can capture screenshots of the desktop over multiple monitors.[36]
Magic Hound malware can take a screenshot and upload the file to its C2 server.[54]
Matroyshka is capable of performing screen captures.[55][56]
Micropsia takes screenshots every 90 seconds by calling the Gdi32.BitBlt API.[57]
MuddyWater has used malware that can capture screenshots of the victim’s machine.[58]
NETWIRE can capture the victim's screen.[59]
njRAT can capture screenshots of the victim’s machines.[60]
Octopus can capture screenshots of the victims’ machine.[61]
OilRig has a tool called CANDYKING to capture a screenshot of user's desktop.[62]
PlugX allows the operator to capture screenshots.[63]
PowerSploit's Get-TimedScreenshot Exfiltration module can take screenshots at regular intervals.[64][65]
POWERSTATS can retrieve screenshots from compromised hosts.[66]
POWRUNER can capture a screenshot from a victim.[67]
Prikormka contains a module that captures screenshots of the victim's desktop.[68]
Proton captures the content of the desktop with the screencapture binary.[36]
Pteranodon can capture screenshots at a configurable interval.[69]
Pupy can drop a mouse-logger that will take small screenshots around at each click and then send back to the server.[70]
Remcos takes automated screenshots of the infected machine.[73]
Remexi takes screenshots of windows of interest.[74]
Revenge RAT has a plugin for screen capture.[75]
RogueRobin has a command named $screenshot that may be responsible for taking screenshots of the victim machine.[76]
ROKRAT captures screenshots of the infected system.[77][78][79]
Rover takes screenshots of the compromised system's desktop and saves them to C:\system\screenshot.bmp for exfiltration every 60 minutes.[80]
Silence can capture victim screen activity.    [82]

Trojan.Karagany can take a desktop screenshot and save the file into \ProgramData\Mail\MailAg\shot.png.[87]

XAgentOSX contains the takeScreenShot (along with startTakeScreenShot and stopTakeScreenShot) functions to take screenshots using the CGGetActiveDisplayList, CGDisplayCreateImage, and NSImage:initWithCGImage methods.[93]
yty collects screenshots of the victim machine.[94]
A variant of Zebrocy captures screenshots of the victim’s machine in JPEG and BMP format.[16][95][96][97][98]

permissions_required: API monitoring, Process monitoring, File monitoring
title: Screen Capture

data_sources: Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters, Windows Registry, File monitoring
description: Screensavers are programs that execute after a configurable time of user inactivity and consist of Portable Executable (PE) files with a .scr file extension.[1] The Windows screensaver application scrnsave.scr is located in C:\Windows\System32\, and C:\Windows\sysWOW64\ on 64-bit Windows systems, along with screensavers included with base Windows installations.
detection: Monitor process execution and command-line parameters of .scr files. Monitor changes to screensaver configuration changes in the Registry that may not correlate with typical user behavior.
examples: Gazer can establish persistence through the system screensaver by configuring it to execute the malware.[2]
mitigations: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Use Group Policy to disable screensavers if they are unnecessary.
Block .scr files from being executed from non-standard locations.
title: Screensaver

data_sources: Process monitoring, File monitoring, Process command-line parameters
description: Adversaries may use scripts to aid in operations and perform multiple actions that would otherwise be manual. Scripting is useful for speeding up operational tasks and reducing the time required to gain access to critical resources. Some scripting languages may be used to bypass process monitoring mechanisms by directly interacting with the operating system at an API level instead of calling other programs. Common scripting languages for Windows include VBScript and PowerShell but could also be in the form of command-line batch scripts.
detection: Scripting may be common on admin, developer, or power user systems, depending on job function. If scripting is restricted for normal users, then any attempts to enable scripts running on a system would be considered suspicious. If scripts are not commonly used on a system, but enabled, scripts running out of cycle from patching or other administrator functions are suspicious. Scripts should be captured from the file system when possible to determine their actions and intent.
examples: APT1 has used batch scripting to automate execution of commands.[5]
APT19 downloaded and launched code within a SCT file.[6]
An APT28 loader Trojan uses a batch script to run its payload. The group has also used macros to execute payloads.[7][8][9][10]
APT29 has used encoded PowerShell scripts uploaded to CozyCar installations to download and install SeaDuke, as well as to evade defenses.[11][12]
APT3 has used PowerShell on victim systems to download and run payloads after exploitation.[13]
APT32 has used macros, PowerShell scripts, COM scriptlets, and VBS scripts.[14][15]
APT37 executes shellcode and a script to decode Base64 strings.[16]
APT39 utilized custom scripts to perform internal reconnaissance.[17]
Astaroth uses JavaScript to perform its core functionalities.[18]
Bisonal's dropper creates VBS scripts on the victim’s machine.[19]
BRONZE BUTLER has used VBS, VBE, and batch scripts for execution.[20]
China Chopper's server component is a text based payload available in a variety of scripting languages.  [21]

Cobalt Group has sent Word OLE compound documents with malicious obfuscated VBA macros that will run upon user execution and executed JavaScript scriptlets on the victim's machine. The group has also used an exploit toolkit known as Threadkit that launches .bat files.[22][23][24][25][26][27]
Cobalt Strike can use PowerShell, Python, VBA, PowerSploit, other scripting frameworks to perform execution.[28][29]
CoinTicker executes a bash script to establish a reverse shell and a Python script to download its second stage.[30]
Comnie executes BAT and VBS scripts.[31]
Dark Caracal has used macros in Word documents that would download a second stage if executed.[32]
DarkComet can execute various types of scripts on the victim’s machine.[33]
Darkhotel has dropped an mspaint.lnk shortcut to disk which launches a shell script that downloads and executes a file.[34]
DealersChoice makes modifications to open-source scripts from GitHub and executes them on the victim’s machine.[35]
Deep Panda has used PowerShell scripts to download and execute programs in memory, without writing to disk.[4]
Denis executes shellcode on the victim's machine.[15]
Dragonfly 2.0 used various types of scripting to perform operations, including Python and batch scripts. The group was observed installing Python 2.7 on a victim.[36][37]
Emotet has sent Microsoft Word documents with embedded macros that will invoke scripts to download additional payloads.[38][39][40][41][42]
Empire has modules for executing scripts.[43]
EvilBunny has an integrated scripting engine to download and execute Lua scripts.[44]
Exaramel has a command to execute VBS and GO scripts on the victim’s machine.[45]
FELIXROOT executes batch scripts on the victim’s machine.[46]
FIN10 has executed malicious .bat files containing PowerShell commands.[47]
FIN4 has used VBA macros to display a dialog box and collect victim credentials.[48][49]
FIN5 scans processes on all victim systems in the environment and uses automated scripts to pull back the results.[50]

FIN6 has used a Metasploit PowerShell module to download and execute shellcode and to set up a local listener. FIN6 has also used scripting to iterate through a list of compromised PoS systems, copy data to a log file, and remove the original data files.[51][52]
FIN7 used SQL, VBS and JavaScript scripts to help perform tasks on the victim's machine.[53][54]
FIN8 has used a Batch file to automate frequently executed post compromise cleanup activities.[55]
Gallmaker used PowerShell scripts for execution.[56]
Gamaredon Group has used various batch scripts to establish C2, download additional files, and conduct other functions.[57]
Gorgon Group has used macros in Spearphishing Attachments as well as executed VBScripts on victim machines.[58]
One version of Helminth consists of VBScript and PowerShell scripts. The malware also uses batch scripting.[59]
HiddenWasp uses a script to automate tasks on the victim's machine and to assist in execution.[60]
Honeybee embeds a Visual Basic script within a malicious Word document as part of initial access; the script is executed when the Word document is opened. The actors also used batch scripting.[61]
JHUHUGIT uses a .bat file to execute a .dll.[8]
jRAT has been distributed as HTA files with VBScript+JScript.[63]
Ke3chang has used batch scripts in its malware to install persistence mechanisms.[64]
KeyBoy uses Python and VBS scripts for installing files and performing execution.[65]
Keydnap uses Python for scripting to execute additional commands.[66]
Koadic performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host (Jscript and VBScript) and runs arbitrary shellcode .[67]
A Destover-like variant used by Lazarus Group uses a batch file mechanism to delete its binaries from the system.[68]
Leafminer infected victims using JavaScript code.[69]
Leviathan has used multiple types of scripting for execution, including JavaScript, JavaScript Scriptlets in XML, and VBScript.[70]
Magic Hound malware has used .vbs scripts for execution.[71]
menuPass has used malicious macros embedded inside Office documents to execute files.[72][73]
MoonWind uses batch scripts for various purposes, including to restart and uninstall itself.[74]
MuddyWater has used VBScript and JavaScript files to execute its POWERSTATS payload. MuddyWater has also used Microsoft scriptlets, macros, and PowerShell scripts.[[75][76][77][78][79]
NanHaiShu executes additional Jscript and VBScript code on the victim's machine.[80]
NanoCore uses VBS and JavaScript files.[81]
NavRAT loads malicious shellcode and executes it in memory.[82]
OceanSalt has been executed via malicious macros.[83]
OilRig has used various types of scripting for execution, including .bat and .vbs scripts. The group has also used macros to deliver malware such as QUADAGENT and OopsIE.[84][85][86][87][88]
OopsIE creates and uses a VBScript as part of its persistent execution.[86][89]
Orz can execute commands with script as well as execute JavaScript.[70]
OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D uses macros for execution as well as VBS and PowerShell scripts.[90]
Patchwork used Visual Basic Scripts (VBS), JavaScript code, batch files, and .SCT files on victim machines.[91][92]
PowerStallion uses PowerShell loops to iteratively check for available commands in its OneDrive C2 server.[93]
POWERSTATS can use VBScript (VBE), PowerShell, and JavaScript code for execution.[79]
Proton uses macOS' .command file type to script actions.[94]
Proxysvc uses a batch file to delete itself.[68]
PUNCHBUGGY has used PowerShell, python, and shellcode scripts.[95]

Pupy can use an add on feature when creating payloads that allows you to create custom Python scripts ("scriptlets") to perform tasks offline (without requiring a session) such as sandbox detection, adding persistence, etc.[96]
QUADAGENT uses VBScripts and batch scripts.[87]
Rancor has used shell and VBS scripts as well as embedded macros for execution.[97]
Remexi uses AutoIt and VBS scripts throughout its execution process.[99]
Revenge RAT executes scripts on the victim's machine.[100][101]

To assist in establishing persistence, RogueRobin creates %APPDATA%\OneDrive.bat and saves the following string to it:powershell.exe -WindowStyle Hidden -exec bypass -File "%APPDATA%\OneDrive.ps1". RogueRobin also uses Windows Script Components.[102][103]
RunningRAT uses a batch file to kill a security program task and then attempts to remove itself.[104]
SamSam uses custom batch scripts to execute some of its components.[105]
SeaDuke uses a module to execute Mimikatz with PowerShell to perform Pass the Ticket.[11]
Silence has used JS, VBS, and PowerShell scripts.[106]
Smoke Loader adds a Visual Basic script in the Startup folder to deploy the payload.[107]
SpeakUp uses Perl and Python scripts.[108]
SQLRat has used SQL to execute JavaScript and VB scripts on the host system.[54]
Stealth Falcon malware uses PowerShell and WMI to script data collection and command execution on the victim.[109]
StoneDrill has several VBS scripts used throughout the malware's lifecycle.  [110]
TA459 has a VBScript for execution.[111]
TA505 has used PowerShell, VBS, and JavaScript for code execution.[112][113]
TrickBot has used macros in Excel documents to download and deploy the malware on the user’s machine.[114]
Turla has used PowerShell and VBS scripts throughout its operations.   [115]
TYPEFRAME can uninstall malware components using a batch script. Additionally, a malicious Word document used for delivery uses VBA macros for execution.[116]
Ursnif  droppers have used VBA macros and PowerShell to download and execute the malware's full executable payload.[117]
WIRTE has used VBS and PowerShell scripts throughout its operation.    [118]
Xbash can execute malicious JavaScript and VBScript payloads on the victim’s machine.[119]
Zeus Panda can launch remote scripts on the victim’s machine.[120]
mitigations: Configure Office security settings enable Protected View, to execute within a sandbox environment, and to block macros through Group Policy. Other types of virtualization and application microsegmentation may also mitigate the impact of compromise.
Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Turn off unused features or restrict access to scripting engines such as VBScript or scriptable administration frameworks such as PowerShell.
title: Scripting
version: Process whitelisting, Data Execution Prevention, Exploit Prevention

data_sources: File monitoring, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters
description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of security software, configurations, defensive tools, and sensors that are installed on the system. This may include things such as local firewall rules and anti-virus. These checks may be built into early-stage remote access tools.
detection: System and network discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as lateral movement, based on the information obtained.
mitigations: Astaroth checks for the presence of Avast antivirus in the C:\Program\Files\ folder.[1]
BadPatch uses WMI to enumerate installed security products in the victim’s environment.[2]
CHOPSTICK checks for antivirus and forensics software.[3]
Cobalt Group used a JavaScript backdoor that is capable of collecting a list of the security solutions installed on the victim's machine.[4]
Comnie attempts to detect several anti-virus products.[5]
The main CozyCar dropper checks whether the victim has an anti-virus product installed. If the installed product is on a predetermined list, the dropper will exit.[6]
Crimson contains a command to collect information about anti-virus software on the victim.[7]
Darkhotel has searched for anti-malware strings and anti-virus processes running on the system.[8]
DustySky checks for the existence of anti-virus.[9]
Empire can enumerate antivirus software on the target.[10]
Epic searches for anti-malware services running on the victim’s machine and terminates itself if it finds them.[11]
EvilBunny has been observed querying installed antivirus software.[12]
Exaramel checks for anti-virus software installed on the victim’s machine.[13]
Felismus checks for processes associated with anti-virus vendors.[14]
FELIXROOT checks for installed security software like antivirus and firewall.[15]
FIN8 has used Registry keys to detect and avoid executing in potential sandboxes.[16]
FinFisher probes the system to check for antimalware processes.[17][18]
Flame identifies security software such as antivirus through the Security module.[19][20]
FlawedAmmyy will attempt to detect anti-virus products during the initial infection.[21]
Gold Dragon checks for anti-malware products and processes.[22]
JPIN checks for the presence of certain security-related processes and deletes its installer/uninstaller component if it identifies any of them.[23]
jRAT can list security software, such as by using WMIC to identify anti-virus products installed on the victim’s machine and to obtain firewall details.[24][25]
Kasidet has the ability to identify any anti-virus installed on the infected system.[26]
Micropsia searches for anti-virus software and firewall products installed on the victim’s machine using WMI.[27][28]
More_eggs can obtain information on installed anti-malware programs.[29]
Mosquito's installer searches the Registry and system to see if specific antivirus tools are installed on the system.[30]
MuddyWater has used malware to check running processes against a hard-coded list of security tools often used by malware researchers.[31]
Naikon uses commands such as netsh advfirewall firewall to discover local firewall settings.[32]
netsh can be used to discover system firewall settings.[33][34]
Patchwork scanned the "Program Files" directories for a directory with the string "Total Security" (the installation path of the "360 Total Security" antivirus tool).[35]
POWRUNER may collect information the victim's anti-virus software.[37]
A module in Prikormka collects information from the victim about installed anti-virus software.[38]
PUNCHBUGGY can gather AVs registered in the system.  [39]
Remsec has a plugin to detect active drivers of some security products.[40]
RogueRobin enumerates running processes to search for Wireshark and Windows Sysinternals suite.[41][42]
RTM can obtain information about security software on the victim.[44]
StoneDrill can check for antivirus and antimalware programs. [45]
StreamEx has the ability to scan for security tools such as firewalls and antivirus tools.[46]
T9000 performs checks for various antivirus and security products during installation.[47]
Tasklist can be used to enumerate security software currently running on a system by process name of known products.[48]
The White Company has checked for specific antivirus products on the target’s computer, including Kaspersky, Quick Heal, AVG, BitDefender, Avira, Sophos, Avast!, and ESET.[49]
Tropic Trooper searches for anti-virus software running on the system.[50]
VERMIN uses WMI to check for anti-virus software installed on the system.[51]
Wingbird checks for the presence of Bitdefender security software.[52]
Yahoyah checks for antimalware solution processes on the system.[53]
Zeus Panda checks to see if anti-virus, anti-spyware, or firewall products are installed in the victim’s environment.[54][55]
title: Security Software Discovery

data_sources: DLL monitoring, Windows Registry, Loaded DLLs
description: Windows Security Support Provider (SSP) DLLs are loaded into the Local Security Authority (LSA) process at system start. Once loaded into the LSA, SSP DLLs have access to encrypted and plaintext passwords that are stored in Windows, such as any logged-on user's Domain password or smart card PINs. The SSP configuration is stored in two Registry keys: HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\Security Packages and HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\OSConfig\Security Packages. An adversary may modify these Registry keys to add new SSPs, which will be loaded the next time the system boots, or when the AddSecurityPackage Windows API function is called. [1]
detection: Monitor the Registry for changes to the SSP Registry keys. Monitor the LSA process for DLL loads. Windows 8.1 and Windows Server 2012 R2 may generate events when unsigned SSP DLLs try to load into the LSA by setting the Registry key HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options\LSASS.exe with AuditLevel = 8. [1] [6]
examples: Empire can enumerate Security Support Providers (SSPs) as well as utilize PowerSploit's Install-SSP and Invoke-Mimikatz to install malicious SSPs and log authentication events.[2]
The Mimikatz credential dumper contains an implementation of an SSP.[3]
PowerSploit's Install-SSP Persistence module can be used to establish by installing a SSP DLL.[4][5]
mitigations: Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2012 R2, and later versions may make LSA run as a Protected Process Light (PPL) by setting the Registry key HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\RunAsPPL, which requires all SSP DLLs to be signed by Microsoft.
title: Security Support Provider

description: In OS X prior to El Capitan, users with root access can read plaintext keychain passwords of logged-in users because Apple’s keychain implementation allows these credentials to be cached so that users are not repeatedly prompted for passwords. [1] [2] Apple’s securityd utility takes the user’s logon password, encrypts it with PBKDF2, and stores this master key in memory. Apple also uses a set of keys and algorithms to encrypt the user’s password, but once the master key is found, an attacker need only iterate over the other values to unlock the final password. [1]
mitigations: Keydnap uses the keychaindump project to read securityd memory.[4]
title: Securityd Memory

data_sources: Windows Registry, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters
description: Adversaries may execute a binary, command, or script via a method that interacts with Windows services, such as the Service Control Manager. This can be done by either creating a new service or modifying an existing service. This technique is the execution used in conjunction with New Service and Modify Existing Service during service persistence or privilege escalation.
detection: Changes to service Registry entries and command-line invocation of tools capable of modifying services that do not correlate with known software, patch cycles, etc., may be suspicious. If a service is used only to execute a binary or script and not to persist, then it will likely be changed back to its original form shortly after the service is restarted so the service is not left broken, as is the case with the common administrator tool PsExec.
examples: APT32's backdoor has used Windows services as a way to execute its malicious payload.[1]
BBSRAT can start, stop, or delete services.[2]
Cobalt Strike can use PsExec to execute a payload on a remote host. It can also use Service Control Manager to start new services.[3][4]
Empire can use PsExec to execute a payload on a remote host.[5]
FIN6 has created Windows services to execute encoded PowerShell commands.[6]
Honeybee launches a DLL file that gets executed as a service using svchost.exe[7]
HOPLIGHT has used svchost.exe to execute a malicious DLL .[8]
Hydraq uses svchost.exe to execute a malicious DLL included in a new service group.[9]
HyperBro  has the ability to start and stop a specified service.[10]
Impacket contains various modules emulating other service execution tools such as PsExec.[11]
Ke3chang has used a tool known as RemoteExec (similar to PsExec) to remotely execute batch scripts and binaries.[12]
Koadic can run a command on another machine using PsExec.[13]
The net start and net stop commands can be used in Net to execute or stop Windows services.[14]
Net Crawler uses PsExec to perform remote service manipulation to execute a copy of itself as part of lateral movement.[15]
NotPetya can use PsExec to help propagate itself across a network.[16][17]
Olympic Destroyer utilizes PsExec to help propagate itself across a network.[18]
PoshC2 contains an implementation of PsExec for remote execution.[19]
Proxysvc registers itself as a service on the victim’s machine to run as a standalone process.[20]
Microsoft Sysinternals PsExec is a popular administration tool that can be used to execute binaries on remote systems using a temporary Windows service.[21]
Pupy uses PsExec to execute a payload or commands on a remote host.[22]
RemoteCMD can execute commands remotely by creating a new service on the remote system.[23]
Shamoon creates a new service named "ntssrv" to execute the payload.[24]
Silence has used Winexe to install a service on the remote system.[25]
Winexe installs a service on the remote system, executes the command, then uninstalls the service.[26]
Wingbird uses services.exe to register a new autostart service named "Audit Service" using a copy of the local lsass.exe file.[27][28]
xCmd can be used to execute binaries on remote systems by creating and starting a service.[29]
mitigations: Ensure that permissions disallow services that run at a higher permissions level from being created or interacted with by a user with a lower permission level.
Also ensure that high permission level service binaries cannot be replaced or modified by users with a lower permission level.
title: Service Execution

description: Windows stores local service configuration information in the Registry under HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services. The information stored under a service's Registry keys can be manipulated to modify a service's execution parameters through tools such as the service controller, sc.exe, PowerShell, or Reg. Access to Registry keys is controlled through Access Control Lists and permissions. [1]
detection: Service changes are reflected in the Registry. Modification to existing services should not occur frequently. If a service binary path or failure parameters are changed to values that are not typical for that service and does not correlate with software updates, then it may be due to malicious activity. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as network connections made for Command and Control, learning details about the environment through Discovery, and Lateral Movement.
mitigations: Ensure proper permissions are set for Registry hives to prevent users from modifying keys for system components that may lead to privilege escalation.
permissions_required: Ability to modify service values in the Registry
title: Service Registry Permissions Weakness

data_sources: Process command-line parameters, Process monitoring, Windows Registry, API monitoring
description: Adversaries may stop or disable services on a system to render those services unavailable to legitimate users. Stopping critical services can inhibit or stop response to an incident or aid in the adversary's overall objectives to cause damage to the environment.[1][2]
detection: Monitor processes and command-line arguments to see if critical processes are terminated or stop running.
examples: Lazarus Group has stopped the MSExchangeIS service to render Exchange contents inaccessible to users.[4]
Olympic Destroyer uses the API call ChangeServiceConfigW to disable all services on the affected system.[1]
WannaCry attempts to kill processes associated with Exchange, Microsoft SQL Server, and MySQL to make it possible to encrypt their data stores.[5][3]
mitigations: Operate intrusion detection, analysis, and response systems on a separate network from the production environment to lessen the chances that an adversary can see and interfere with critical response functions.
Ensure proper process and file permissions are in place to inhibit adversaries from disabling or interfering with critical services.
Ensure proper registry permissions are in place to inhibit adversaries from disabling or interfering with critical services.
Limit privileges of user accounts and groups so that only authorized administrators can interact with service changes and service configurations.
title: Service Stop

description: When the setuid or setgid bits are set on Linux or macOS for an application, this means that the application will run with the privileges of the owning user or group respectively  [1]. Normally an application is run in the current user’s context, regardless of which user or group owns the application. There are instances where programs need to be executed in an elevated context to function properly, but the user running them doesn’t need the elevated privileges. Instead of creating an entry in the sudoers file, which must be done by root, any user can specify the setuid or setgid flag to be set for their own applications. These bits are indicated with an "s" instead of an "x" when viewing a file's attributes via ls -l. The chmod program can set these bits with via bitmasking, chmod 4777 [file] or via shorthand naming, chmod u+s [file].
detection: Monitor the file system for files that have the setuid or setgid bits set. Monitor for execution of utilities, like chmod, and their command-line arguments to look for setuid or setguid bits being set.
examples: Keydnap adds the setuid flag to a binary so it can easily elevate in the future.[2]
mitigations: Applications with known vulnerabilities or known shell escapes should not have the setuid or setgid bits set to reduce potential damage if an application is compromised. Additionally, the number of programs with setuid or setgid bits set should be minimized across a system.
title: Setuid and Setgid
version: File monitoring, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters

description: Adversaries may add malicious content to an internally accessible website through an open network file share that contains the website's webroot or Web content directory [1] [2] and then browse to that content with a Web browser to cause the server to execute the malicious content. The malicious content will typically run under the context and permissions of the Web server process, often resulting in local system or administrative privileges, depending on how the Web server is configured.
detection: Use file and process monitoring to detect when files are written to a Web server by a process that is not the normal Web server process or when files are written outside of normal administrative time periods. Use process monitoring to identify normal processes that run on the Web server and detect processes that are not typically executed.
mitigations: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Disallow remote access to the webroot or other directories used to serve Web content.

Networks that allow for open development and testing of Web content and allow users to set up their own Web servers on the enterprise network may be particularly vulnerable if the systems and Web servers are not properly secured to limit unauthenticated network share access and network/system isolation

Networks that allow for open development and testing of Web content and allow users to set up their own Web servers on the enterprise network may be particularly vulnerable if the systems and Web servers are not properly secured to limit privileged account use and unauthenticated network share access.
Disable execution on directories within the webroot. Ensure proper permissions on directories that are accessible through a Web server.

Ensure that permissions of the Web server process are only what is required by not using built-in accounts; instead, create specific accounts to limit unnecessary access or permissions overlap across multiple systems.[4][5]
permissions_required: Shared webroot directory on remote system
title: Shared Webroot

data_sources: File monitoring, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters
description: Shortcuts or symbolic links are ways of referencing other files or programs that will be opened or executed when the shortcut is clicked or executed by a system startup process. Adversaries could use shortcuts to execute their tools for persistence. They may create a new shortcut as a means of indirection that may use Masquerading to look like a legitimate program. Adversaries could also edit the target path or entirely replace an existing shortcut so their tools will be executed instead of the intended legitimate program.
detection: Since a shortcut's target path likely will not change, modifications to shortcut files that do not correlate with known software changes, patches, removal, etc., may be suspicious. Analysis should attempt to relate shortcut file change or creation events to other potentially suspicious events based on known adversary behavior such as process launches of unknown executables that make network connections.
examples: APT29 drops a Windows shortcut file for execution.[1]
Astaroth's initial payload is a malicious .LNK file.(Citation :Cybereason Astaroth Feb 2019)[3]
BACKSPACE achieves persistence by creating a shortcut to itself in the CSIDL_STARTUP directory.[4]
The BlackEnergy 3 variant drops its main DLL component and then creates a .lnk shortcut to that file in the startup folder.[5]
Comnie establishes persistence via a .lnk file in the victim’s startup path.[6]
Darkhotel has dropped an mspaint.lnk shortcut to disk which launches a shell script that downloads and executes a file.[7]
Dragonfly 2.0 manipulated .lnk files to gather user credentials in conjunction with Forced Authentication.[8]
Empire can persist by modifying a .LNK file to include a backdoor.[9]
FELIXROOT creates a .LNK file for persistence.[10]
FIN7 created several .LNK files on the victim's machine.[11]
Gazer can establish persistence by creating a .lnk file in the Start menu or by modifying existing .lnk files to execute the malware through cmd.exe.[12][13]
Gorgon Group malware can create a .lnk file and add a Registry Run key to establish persistence.[14]
Helminth establishes persistence by creating a shortcut.[15]
Kazuar adds a .lnk file to the Windows startup folder.[16]
A version of KONNI drops a Windows shortcut on the victim’s machine to establish persistence.[17]
A Lazarus Group malware sample adds persistence on the system by creating a shortcut in the user’s Startup folder.[18]
Leviathan has used JavaScript to create a shortcut file in the Startup folder that points to its main backdoor.[19][20]
Micropsia creates a shortcut to maintain persistence.[21]
Reaver creates a shortcut file and saves it in a Startup folder to establish persistence.[22]
RedLeaves attempts to add a shortcut file in the Startup folder to achieve persistence.[23][24]
RogueRobin establishes persistence by creating a shortcut (.LNK file) in the Windows startup folder to run a script each time the user logs in.[25][26]
S-Type may create the file %HOMEPATH%\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\Realtek {{Unique Identifier}}.lnk, which points to the malicious msdtc.exe file already created in the %CommonFiles% directory.[27]
SeaDuke is capable of persisting via a .lnk file stored in the Startup directory.[28]
SHIPSHAPE achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the Startup folder.[4]
SPACESHIP achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the current user's Startup folder.[4]

To establish persistence, SslMM identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an "Office Start," "Yahoo Talk," "MSN Gaming Z0ne," or "MSN Talk" shortcut.[29]
TinyZBot can create a shortcut in the Windows startup folder for persistence.[30]
mitigations: Limit permissions for who can create symbolic links in Windows to appropriate groups such as Administrators and necessary groups for virtualization. This can be done through GPO: Computer Configuration > [Policies] > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Local Policies > User Rights Assignment: Create symbolic links.
title: Shortcut Modification

description: Binaries signed with trusted digital certificates can execute on Windows systems protected by digital signature validation. Several Microsoft signed binaries that are default on Windows installations can be used to proxy execution of other files. This behavior may be abused by adversaries to execute malicious files that could bypass application whitelisting and signature validation on systems. This technique accounts for proxy execution methods that are not already accounted for within the existing techniques.
detection: Monitor processes and command-line parameters for signed binaries that may be used to proxy execution of malicious files. Legitimate programs used in suspicious ways, like msiexec.exe downloading an MSI file from the internet, may be indicative of an intrusion. Correlate activity with other suspicious behavior to reduce false positives that may be due to normal benign use by users and administrators.
examples: Cobalt Group has used odbcconf to proxy the execution of malicious DLL files.[9]
