Duqu has used msiexec to execute malicious Windows Installer packages. Additionally, a PROPERTY=VALUE pair containing a 56-bit encryption key has been used to decrypt the main payload from the installer packages.[11]
Rancor has used msiexec to download and execute malicious installer files over HTTP.[2]
TA505 has used msiexec to download and execute malicious Windows Installer files.[12][13]
mitigations: Certain signed binaries that can be used to execute other programs may not be necessary within a given environment. Use application whitelisting configured to block execution of these binaries if they are not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries.
If these binaries are required for use, then restrict execution of them to privileged accounts or groups that need to use them to lessen the opportunities for malicious use.
title: Signed Binary Proxy Execution

description: Scripts signed with trusted certificates can be used to proxy execution of malicious files. This behavior may bypass signature validation restrictions and application whitelisting solutions that do not account for use of these scripts.
detection: Monitor script processes, such as cscript, and command-line parameters for scripts like PubPrn.vbs that may be used to proxy execution of malicious files.
examples: APT32 has used PubPrn.vbs within execution scripts to execute malware, possibly bypassing defenses.[3]
mitigations: Certain signed scripts that can be used to execute other programs may not be necessary within a given environment. Use application whitelisting configured to block execution of these scripts if they are not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries.
title: Signed Script Proxy Execution

description: Software packing is a method of compressing or encrypting an executable. Packing an executable changes the file signature in an attempt to avoid signature-based detection. Most decompression techniques decompress the executable code in memory.
detection: Use file scanning to look for known software packers or artifacts of packing techniques. Packing is not a definitive indicator of malicious activity, because legitimate software may use packing techniques to reduce binary size or to protect proprietary code.
examples: APT29 used UPX to pack files.[2]
APT3 has been known to pack their tools.[3]
APT32 uses UPX to pack their macOS backdoor.[4]
APT38 has used several code packing methods such as Themida, Enigma, VMProtect, and Obsidium, to pack their implants.[5]
APT39 has repacked a modified version of Mimikatz to thwart anti-virus detection.[6]
Astaroth uses a software packer called Pe123\RPolyCryptor.[7]
China Chopper's client component is packed with UPX.[8]
Dark Caracal has used UPX to pack Bandook.[9]
DarkComet has the option to compress its payload using UPX or MPRESS.[10]
A version of Daserf uses the MPRESS packer.[11]
Elderwood has packed malware payloads before delivery to victims.[12]
Emotet has used custom packers to protect its payloads.[13]
A FinFisher variant uses a custom packer.[14][15]
Group5 packed an executable by base64 encoding the PE file and breaking it up into numerous lines.[17]
H1N1 uses a custom packing algorithm.[18]
Night Dragon is known to use software packing in its tools.[20]
OopsIE uses the SmartAssembly obfuscator to pack an embedded .Net Framework assembly used for C2.[21]
A Patchwork payload was packed with UPX.[22]
SeaDuke has been packed with the UPX packer.[23]
Soft Cell packed some payloads using different types of packers, both known and custom.[24]
The White Company has obfuscated their payloads through packing.[25]
TrickBot leverages a custom packer to obfuscate its functionality.[26]
Trojan.Karagany samples sometimes use common binary packers such as UPX and Aspack on top of a custom Delphi binary packer.[27]
yty packs a plugin with UPX.[30]
Zebrocy's Delphi variant was packed with UPX.[31][32]
Some ZeroT DLL files have been packed with UPX.[33]
mitigations: Employ heuristic-based malware detection. Ensure updated virus definitions and create custom signatures for observed malware.
title: Software Packing

data_sources: Process monitoring, File monitoring, Process command-line parameters
description: The source command loads functions into the current shell or executes files in the current context. This built-in command can be run in two different ways source /path/to/filename [arguments] or . /path/to/filename [arguments]. Take note of the space after the ".". Without a space, a new shell is created that runs the program instead of running the program within the current context. This is often used to make certain features or functions available to a shell or to update a specific shell's environment.
detection: Monitor for command shell execution of source and subsequent processes that are started as a result of being executed by a source command. Adversaries must also drop a file to disk in order to execute it with source, and these files can also detected by file monitoring.
title: Source

description: Adversaries can hide a program's true filetype by changing the extension of a file. With certain file types (specifically this does not work with .app extensions), appending a space to the end of a filename will change how the file is processed by the operating system. For example, if there is a Mach-O executable file called evil.bin, when it is double clicked by a user, it will launch Terminal.app and execute. If this file is renamed to evil.txt, then when double clicked by a user, it will launch with the default text editing application (not executing the binary). However, if the file is renamed to "evil.txt " (note the space at the end), then when double clicked by a user, the true file type is determined by the OS and handled appropriately and the binary will be executed [1].
detection: It's not common for spaces to be at the end of filenames, so this is something that can easily be checked with file monitoring. From the user's perspective though, this is very hard to notice from within the Finder.app or on the command-line in Terminal.app. Processes executed from binaries containing non-standard extensions in the filename are suspicious.
mitigations: Keydnap puts a space after a false .jpg extension so that execution actually goes through the Terminal.app program.[2]
title: Space after Filename

description: Spearphishing attachment is a specific variant of spearphishing. Spearphishing attachment is different from other forms of spearphishing in that it employs the use of malware attached to an email. All forms of spearphishing are electronically delivered social engineering targeted at a specific individual, company, or industry. In this scenario, adversaries attach a file to the spearphishing email and usually rely upon User Execution to gain execution.
detection: Network intrusion detection systems and email gateways can be used to detect spearphishing with malicious attachments in transit. Detonation chambers may also be used to identify malicious attachments. Solutions can be signature and behavior based, but adversaries may construct attachments in a way to avoid these systems.
examples: APT12 has sent emails with malicious Microsoft Office documents and PDFs attached.[1][2]
APT19 sent spearphishing emails with malicious attachments in RTF and XLSM formats to deliver initial exploits.[3]
APT28 sent spearphishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Office attachments.[4][5][6][7][8][9]
APT29 has used spearphishing emails with an attachment to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.[10][11]
APT32 has sent spearphishing emails with a malicious executable disguised as a document or spreadsheet.[12][13][14][15]
APT37 delivers malware using spearphishing emails with malicious HWP attachments.[16][17][18]
APT39 leveraged spearphishing emails with malicious attachments to initially compromise victims.[19]
BRONZE BUTLER used spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments to infect victims.[20]

Cobalt Group has sent spearphishing emails with various attachment types to corporate and personal email accounts of victim organizations. Attachment types have included .rtf, .doc, .xls, archives containing LNK files, and password protected archives containing .exe and .scr executables.[21][22][23][24][25][26][27][28]
Darkhotel has sent spearphishing emails with malicious RAR attachments.[29]

DarkHydrus has sent spearphishing emails with password-protected RAR archives containing malicious Excel Web Query files (.iqy). The group has also sent spearphishing emails that contained malicious Microsoft Office documents that use the "attachedTemplate" technique to load a template from a remote server.[30][31][32]
Dragonfly 2.0 used spearphishing with Microsoft Office attachments to target victims.[33][34]
Elderwood has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims via targeted emails containing malicious attachments.[35][36]
Emotet has been delivered by phishing emails containing attachments.[37][38][39][40][41][42][43][44]
FIN4 has used spearphishing emails containing attachments (which are often stolen, legitimate documents sent from compromised accounts) with embedded malicious macros.[45][46]
FIN7 sent spearphishing emails with either malicious Microsoft Documents or RTF files attached.[47][48][49]
FIN8 has distributed targeted emails containing Word documents with embedded malicious macros.[50][51][52]
Gallmaker sent emails with malicious Microsoft Office documents attached.[53]
Gorgon Group sent emails to victims with malicious Microsoft Office documents attached.[54]
Lazarus Group has targeted victims with spearphishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Word documents.[55]
Leviathan has sent spearphishing emails with malicious attachments, including .rtf, .doc, and .xls files.[56]
Magic Hound sent malicious attachments to victims over email, including an Excel spreadsheet containing macros to download Pupy.[57]
menuPass has sent malicious Office documents via email as part of spearphishing campaigns as well as executables disguised as documents.[58][59][60][61]
MuddyWater has compromised third parties and used compromised accounts to send spearphishing emails with targeted attachments to recipients.[62][63][64]
OceanSalt has been delivered via spearphishing emails with Microsoft Office attachments.[65]
OilRig has sent spearphising emails with malicious attachments to potential victims using compromised and/or spoofed email accounts.[66][67][68]
Patchwork has used spearphishing with an attachment to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.[69][70][71][72]
PLATINUM has sent spearphishing emails with attachments to victims as its primary initial access vector.[73]
Rancor has attached a malicious document to an email to gain initial access.[74]
Silence has sent emails with malicious DOCX, CHM and ZIP attachments. [75][76]
TA459 has targeted victims using spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments.[77]
TA505 has used spearphishing emails with malicious attachments to initially compromise victims.[78][79][80][81][82][83]
The White Company has sent phishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments to victims.[84]
TrickBot has used an email with an Excel sheet containing a malicious macro to deploy the malware[85]
Tropic Trooper sent spearphishing emails that contained malicious Microsoft Office attachments.[86][87][88]
Turla has used spearphishing emails to deliver BrainTest as a malicious attachment.[89]
mitigations: Anti-virus can also automatically quarantine suspicious files.
Network intrusion prevention systems and systems designed to scan and remove malicious email attachments can be used to block activity.

Block unknown or unused attachments by default that should not be transmitted over email as a best practice to prevent some vectors, such as .scr, .exe, .pif, .cpl, etc. Some email scanning devices can open and analyze compressed and encrypted formats, such as zip and rar that may be used to conceal malicious attachments in Obfuscated Files or Information.
Users can be trained to identify social engineering techniques and spearphishing emails.
permissions_required: File monitoring, Packet capture, Network intrusion detection system, Detonation chamber, Email gateway, Mail server
title: Spearphishing Attachment

description: Spearphishing with a link is a specific variant of spearphishing. It is different from other forms of spearphishing in that it employs the use of links to download malware contained in email, instead of attaching malicious files to the email itself, to avoid defenses that may inspect email attachments.
detection: URL inspection within email (including expanding shortened links) can help detect links leading to known malicious sites. Detonation chambers can be used to detect these links and either automatically go to these sites to determine if they're potentially malicious, or wait and capture the content if a user visits the link.
examples: APT28 sent spearphishing emails which used a URL-shortener service to masquerade as a legitimate service and to redirect targets to credential harvesting sites.[1][2]
APT29 has used spearphishing with a link to trick victims into clicking on a link to a zip file containing malicious files.[3]
APT32 has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious links.[4][5]
APT33 has sent spearphishing emails containing links to .hta files.[6][7]
APT39 leveraged spearphishing emails with malicious links to initially compromise victims.[8]
Cobalt Group has sent emails with URLs pointing to malicious documents.[9]
Dragonfly 2.0 used spearphishing with PDF attachments containing malicious links that redirected to credential harvesting websites.[10]
Elderwood has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims via targeted emails containing a link to malicious content hosted on an uncommon Web server.[11][12]
Emotet has been delivered by phishing emails containing links.[13][14][15][16][17][18][19][19][20]
FIN4 has used spearphishing emails (often sent from compromised accounts) containing malicious links.[21][22]
FIN8 has distributed targeted emails containing links to malicious documents with embedded macros.[23]
Leviathan has sent spearphishing emails with links, often using a fraudulent lookalike domain and stolen branding.[24]
Magic Hound sent shortened URL links over email to victims. The URLs linked to Word documents with malicious macros that execute PowerShells scripts to download Pupy.[25]
Night Dragon sent spearphishing emails containing links to compromised websites where malware was downloaded.[26]
OilRig has sent spearphising emails with malicious links to potential victims.[27]

Patchwork has used spearphishing with links to deliver files with exploits to initial victims. The group has used embedded image tags (known as web bugs) with unique, per-recipient tracking links in their emails for the purpose of identifying which recipients opened messages.[28][29][30]
Stolen Pencil sent spearphishing emails containing links to domains controlled by the threat actor.[31]
TA505 has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious links.[32][33]
Turla attempted to trick targets into clicking on a link featuring a seemingly legitimate domain from Adobe.com to download their malware and gain initial access.[34]
mitigations: Determine if certain websites that can be used for spearphishing are necessary for business operations and consider blocking access if activity cannot be monitored well or if it poses a significant risk.
Users can be trained to identify social engineering techniques and spearphishing emails with malicious links.
permissions_required: Packet capture, Web proxy, Email gateway, Detonation chamber, SSL/TLS inspection, DNS records, Mail server
title: Spearphishing Link

description: Spearphishing via service is a specific variant of spearphishing. It is different from other forms of spearphishing in that it employs the use of third party services rather than directly via enterprise email channels.
detection: Because most common third-party services used for spearphishing via service leverage TLS encryption, SSL/TLS inspection is generally required to detect the initial communication/delivery. With SSL/TLS inspection intrusion detection signatures or other security gateway appliances may be able to detect malware.
examples: Dark Caracal spearphished victims via Facebook and Whatsapp.[1]
Magic Hound used various social media channels to spearphish victims.[2]
mitigations: Anti-virus can also automatically quarantine suspicious files.

Determine if certain social media sites, personal webmail services, or other service that can be used for spearphishing is necessary for business operations and consider blocking access if activity cannot be monitored well or if it poses a significant risk.
Users can be trained to identify social engineering techniques and spearphishing emails with malicious links.
title: Spearphishing via Service

description: Adversaries may communicate using a common, standardized application layer protocol such as HTTP, HTTPS, SMTP, or DNS to avoid detection by blending in with existing traffic. Commands to the remote system, and often the results of those commands, will be embedded within the protocol traffic between the client and server.
detection: Analyze network data for uncommon data flows (e.g., a client sending significantly more data than it receives from a server). Processes utilizing the network that do not normally have network communication or have never been seen before are suspicious. Analyze packet contents to detect application layer protocols that do not follow the expected protocol for the port that is being used. [178]
examples: 3PARA RAT uses HTTP for command and control.[1]
4H RAT uses HTTP for command and control.[1]
ADVSTORESHELL connects to port 80 of a C2 server using Wininet API.[2]
Agent Tesla has used HTTP and SMTP for C2 communications.[3][4]
APT18 uses HTTP and DNS for C2 communications.[5]
APT19 used HTTP for C2 communications. APT19 also used an HTTP malware variant to communicate over HTTP for C2.[6][7]

APT28 used SMTP as a communication channel in various implants, initially using self-registered Google Mail accounts and later compromised email servers of its victims. Later implants such as CHOPSTICK use a blend of HTTP and other legitimate channels, depending on module configuration.[8]

APT32 has used JavaScript that communicates over HTTP or HTTPS to attacker controlled domains to download additional frameworks. The group has also used email for C2 via an Office macro. The group's backdoor can also exfiltrate data by encoding it in the subdomain field of DNS packets.[9][10][11][12]
APT33 has used HTTP for command and control.[13]
APT37 uses HTTPS to conceal C2 communications.[14]
APT38 used a backdoor, QUICKRIDE, to communicate to the C2 server over HTTP and HTTPS.[15]
BACKSPACE uses HTTP as a transport to communicate with its command server.[16]
BADNEWS establishes a backdoor over HTTP.[17]
BadPatch uses HTTP and SMTP for C2.[18]
Bankshot uses HTTP for command and control communication.[19]
BBSRAT uses GET and POST requests over HTTP or HTTPS for command and control to obtain commands and send ZLIB compressed data back to the C2 server.[20]
Bisonal uses HTTP for C2 communications.[21]
BlackEnergy communicates with its C2 server over HTTP.[22]
BONDUPDATER can use DNS and TXT records within its DNS tunneling protocol for command and control.[23]
Some Brave Prince variants have used South Korea's Daum email service to exfiltrate information, and later variants have posted the data to a web server via an HTTP post command.[24]
BRONZE BUTLER malware has used HTTP for C2.[25]
BUBBLEWRAP can communicate using HTTP or HTTPS.[26]
Cannon uses SMTP/S and POP3/S for C2 communications by sending and receiving emails.[27]
The Carbanak malware communicates to its command server using HTTP with an encrypted payload.[28]
Cardinal RAT is downloaded using HTTP over port 443.[29]
ChChes communicates to its C2 server over HTTP and embeds data within the Cookie HTTP header.[30][31]
China Chopper's server component executes code sent via HTTP POST commands.[32]
Various implementations of CHOPSTICK communicate with C2 over HTTP, SMTP, and POP3.[33]
One variant of CloudDuke uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2.[34]
Cobalt Group has used HTTPS and DNS tunneling for C2. The group has also used the Plink utility to create SSH tunnels.[35][36][37]

Cobalt Strike uses a custom command and control protocol that is encapsulated in HTTP, HTTPS, or DNS. In addition, it conducts peer-to-peer communication over Windows named pipes encapsulated in the SMB protocol. All protocols use their standard assigned ports.[38]
Cobian RAT uses DNS for C2.[39]
Comnie uses HTTP for C2 communication.[40]
ComRAT has used HTTP requests for command and control.[41]
CORALDECK has exfiltrated data in HTTP POST headers.[42]
CORESHELL can communicate over HTTP, SMTP, and POP3 for C2.[8][43]
CosmicDuke can use HTTP or HTTPS for command and control to hard-coded C2 servers.[34][44]
CozyCar's main method of communicating with its C2 servers is using HTTP or HTTPS.[45]
Dark Caracal's version of Bandook communicates with their server over a TCP port using HTTP payloads Base64 encoded and suffixed with the string "&&&".[46]
DarkComet can use HTTP for C2 communications.[47]
DealersChoice uses HTTP for communication with the C2 server.[48]
Denis has used DNS tunneling for C2 communications.[10][49]
DownPaper communicates to its C2 server over HTTP.[51]
Dridex has used HTTPS for C2 communications.[53]
Duqu uses a custom command and control protocol that communicates over commonly used ports, and is frequently encapsulated by application layer protocols.[54]
DustySky has used both HTTP and HTTPS for C2.[55]
Dyre uses HTTPS for C2 communications.[56]
Ebury has used DNS requests over UDP port 53.    [57]
Elise communicates over HTTP or HTTPS for C2.[58]
ELMER uses HTTP for command and control.[59]
Emissary uses HTTP or HTTPS for C2.[60]
Empire can conduct command and control over protocols like HTTP and HTTPS.[61]
Epic uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2 communications.[62][63]
EvilBunny has executed C2 commands directly via HTTP.[64]
Exaramel uses HTTPS for C2 communications.[65]
Some variants of FakeM use SSL to communicate with C2 servers.[66]
FELIXROOT uses HTTP and HTTPS to communicate with the C2 server.[68][69]
FIN4 has used HTTP POST requests to transmit data.[70][71]
FIN6 used the Plink command-line utility to create SSH tunnels to C2 servers.[72]
FIN7 has performed C2 using DNS via A, OPT, and TXT records.[73]
FlawedAmmyy has used HTTP for C2.[75]
FLIPSIDE uses RDP to tunnel traffic from a victim environment.[76]
A Gamaredon Group file stealer can communicate over HTTP for C2.[77]
Gazer communicates with its C2 servers over HTTP.[78]
GeminiDuke uses HTTP and HTTPS for command and control.[34]
Gold Dragon uses HTTP for communication to the control servers.[24]
GreyEnergy uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2 communications.[69]
The "Uploader" variant of HAMMERTOSS visits a hard-coded server over HTTP/S to download the images HAMMERTOSS uses to receive commands.[80]
HAWKBALL has used HTTP to communicate with a single hard-coded C2 server.[81]
Helminth can use HTTP or DNS for C2.[82]
Hi-Zor communicates with its C2 server over HTTPS.[83]
Honeybee uses FTP for command and control.[84]
HTTPBrowser has used HTTP, HTTPS, and DNS for command and control.[85][86]
httpclient uses HTTP for command and control.[1]
HyperBro  has used HTTPS for C2 communications.[87]
InvisiMole uses HTTP for C2 communications.[88]
Ixeshe uses HTTP for command and control.[89][90]
JHUHUGIT variants have communicated with C2 servers over HTTP and HTTPS.[91][92][93]
JPIN can communicate over FTP and send email over SMTP.[50]
Kazuar uses HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, and FTPS to communicate with the C2 server. Kazuar can also act as a webserver and listen for inbound HTTP requests through an exposed API.[94]

Ke3chang malware RoyalCli and BS2005 have communicated over HTTP with the C2 server through Internet Explorer (IE) by using the COM interface IWebBrowser2. Additionally, Ke3chang malware RoyalDNS has used DNS for C2.[95]
Keydnap uses HTTPS for command and control.[96]
The Komplex C2 channel uses HTTP POST requests.[97]
KONNI has used HTTP for C2.[98]
A Lazarus Group malware sample conducts C2 over HTTP.[99]
LOWBALL command and control occurs via HTTPS over port 443.[26]
MacSpy uses HTTP for command and control.[101]
Magic Hound malware has used HTTP and IRC for C2.[102]
Micropsia uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2 network communications.[105][106]
MiniDuke uses HTTP and HTTPS for command and control.[34]
Mis-Type network traffic can communicate over HTTP.[107]
NanHaiShu uses DNS for the C2 communications.[108]
NavRAT uses the email platform, Naver, for C2 communications, leveraging SMTP.[109]

NETEAGLE will attempt to detect if the infected host is configured to a proxy. If so, NETEAGLE will send beacons via an HTTP POST request; otherwise it will send beacons via UDP/6000. NETEAGLE will also use HTTP to download resources that contain an IP address and Port Number pair to connect to for further C2. Adversaries can also use NETEAGLE to establish an RDP connection with a controller over TCP/7519.[16]
Night Dragon has used HTTP for C2.[110]
NOKKI has used FTP and HTTP for C2 communications.[111]
Octopus uses HTTP for C2 communications.[112]
OilRig has used HTTP and DNS for C2. The group has also used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.[93][113]
OLDBAIT can use HTTP or SMTP for C2.[8]
OnionDuke uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2.[34]
OopsIE uses HTTP for C2 communications.[114][115]
Orangeworm has used HTTP for C2.[116]
OwaAuth uses incoming HTTP requests with a username keyword and commands and handles them as instructions to perform actions.[85]
PinchDuke transfers files from the compromised host via HTTP or HTTPS to a C2 server.[34]
Pisloader uses DNS as its C2 protocol.[117]
PlugX can be configured to use HTTP or DNS for command and control.[85]
pngdowner uses HTTP for command and control.[1]
PoshC2 can use protocols like HTTP/HTTPS for command and control traffic.[118]
POWERSOURCE uses DNS TXT records for C2.[119][120]
POWERTON has used HTTP/HTTPS for C2 traffic.[121]
POWRUNER can use HTTP and DNS for C2 communications.[122][113]
Proxysvc uses HTTP over SSL to communicate commands with the control server.[123]
Pteranodon can use HTTP for C2.[77]
PUNCHBUGGY enables remote interaction and can obtain additional code over HTTPS GET and POST requests.[124][125][126]
Pupy can communicate over HTTP for C2.[127]
QUADAGENT uses HTTPS, HTTP, and DNS for C2 communications.[128]
Rancor has used HTTP for C2.[129]
RARSTONE uses SSL to encrypt its communication with its C2 server.[130]
RATANKBA uses HTTP/HTTPS for command and control communication.[131][132]
Some Reaver variants use HTTP for C2.[133]
RedLeaves can communicate to its C2 over HTTP and HTTPS if directed.[134][135]
The Regin malware platform supports many standard protocols, including HTTP, HTTPS, and SMB.[136]
Remexi uses BITSAdmin to communicate with the C2 server over HTTP.[137]
Remsec is capable of using HTTP, HTTPS, SMTP, and DNS for C2.[138][139][140]
RGDoor uses HTTP for C2 communications.[141]
APT12 has used RIPTIDE, a RAT that uses HTTP to communicate.[142]
ROKRAT use HTTPS for all command and control communication methods.[143]
SeaDuke uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2.[34]
Seasalt uses HTTP for C2 communications.[145]
SilverTerrier uses SMTP, FTP, and HTTP for C2 communications.[148]
Smoke Loader uses HTTP for C2.[149]
SNUGRIDE communicates with its C2 server over HTTP.[134]
SOUNDBITE communicates via DNS for C2.[150]
SpeakUp uses POST and GET requests over HTTP to communicate with its main C&C server.[151]
Stealth Falcon malware communicates with its C2 server via HTTPS.[152]
TEXTMATE uses DNS TXT records for C2.[119]
Threat Group-3390 malware has used HTTP for C2.[154]
TrickBot uses HTTPS to communicate with its C2 servers, to get malware updates, modules that perform most of the malware logic and various configuration files.[155]
Turla has used HTTP and HTTPS for C2 communications.[156][157]
UBoatRAT has used HTTP for C2 communications.[158]
Umbreon provides access to the system via SSH or any other protocol that uses PAM to authenticate.[159]
UPPERCUT has used HTTP for C2, including sending error codes in Cookie headers.[160]
Ursnif  has used HTTPS for C2 as well as HTTP POSTs to exfil gathered information.[161][162][163]
Vasport creates a backdoor by making a connection using a HTTP POST.[164]
VERMIN uses HTTP for C2 communications.[165]
WIRTE has used HTTP for network communication. [166]
XAgentOSX contains the ftpUpload function to use the FTPManager:uploadFile method to upload files from the target system.[167]
Xbash uses HTTP for C2 communications.[168]
Zebrocy uses HTTP, SMTP, and POP3 for C2.[170][27][171][172][173][174]
ZeroT has used HTTP for C2.[175][176]
Zeus Panda uses HTTP for C2 communications.[177]
ZLib communicates over HTTP for C2.[107]
mitigations: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.[178]
permissions_required: Packet capture, Netflow/Enclave netflow, Process use of network, Malware reverse engineering, Process monitoring
title: Standard Application Layer Protocol

description: Adversaries may explicitly employ a known encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol. Despite the use of a secure algorithm, these implementations may be vulnerable to reverse engineering if necessary secret keys are encoded and/or generated within malware samples/configuration files.
detection: SSL/TLS inspection is one way of detecting command and control traffic within some encrypted communication channels. [67] SSL/TLS inspection does come with certain risks that should be considered before implementing to avoid potential security issues such as incomplete certificate validation. [68]
examples: 3PARA RAT command and control commands are encrypted within the HTTP C2 channel using the DES algorithm in CBC mode with a key derived from the MD5 hash of the string HYF54&%9&jkMCXuiS.[1]
adbupd contains a copy of the OpenSSL library to encrypt C2 traffic.[2]
A variant of ADVSTORESHELL encrypts some C2 with 3DES and RSA.[3]
APT33 has used AES for encryption of command and control traffic.[4]
Azorult can encrypt C2 traffic using XOR.[5][6]
BISCUIT uses SSL for encrypting C2 communications.[7]
Some Bisonal samples encrypt C2 communications with RC4.[8]
BRONZE BUTLER has used RC4 encryption (for Datper malware) and AES (for xxmm malware) to obfuscate HTTP traffic.[9]
CallMe uses AES to encrypt C2 traffic.[10]
Carbanak encrypts the message body of HTTP traffic with RC2 (in CBC mode) and Base64 encoding.[11][12]
Chaos provides a reverse shell connection on 8338/TCP, encrypted via AES.[13]
ChChes can encrypt C2 traffic with AES.[14][15]
CHOPSTICK encrypts C2 communications with RC4 as well as TLS.[16]
Cobalt Group has used the Plink utility to create SSH tunnels.[17]
Comnie encrypts command and control communications with RC4.[18]
Daserf uses RC4 encryption to obfuscate HTTP traffic.[9]
Dipsind encrypts C2 data with AES256 in ECB mode.[2]
Downdelph uses RC4 to encrypt C2 responses.[19]
Dridex has encrypted traffic with RSA and RC4.[20]
The Duqu command and control protocol's data stream can be encrypted with AES-CBC.[21]
Elise encrypts exfiltrated data with RC4.[22]
Emotet is known to use RSA keys for encrypting C2 traffic.[23]
Empire can use TLS to encrypt its C2 channel.[24]
Epic encrypts commands from the C2 server using a hardcoded key.[25]
Some variants of FakeM use RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.[10]
Some Felismus samples use AES to encrypt C2 traffic.[26]
FIN6 used the Plink command-line utility to create SSH tunnels to C2 servers.[27]
FIN8 has used the Plink utility to tunnel RDP back to C2 infrastructure.[28]
FlawedAmmyy has used SEAL encryption during the initial C2 handshake.[29]
gh0st RAT uses RC4 and XOR to encrypt C2 traffic.[30]
GreyEnergy encrypts communications using AES256 and RSA-2048.[31]
H1N1 encrypts C2 traffic using an RC4 key.[32]
Helminth encrypts data sent to its C2 server over HTTP with RC4.[33]
Koadic can use SSL and TLS for communications.[34]
Lazarus Group malware uses Caracachs encryption to encrypt C2 payloads.[35]
LightNeuron uses AES to encrypt C2 traffic.[36]
MobileOrder uses AES to encrypt C2 communications.[10]
MoonWind encrypts C2 traffic using RC4 with a static key.[37]
NanoCore uses DES to encrypt the C2 traffic.[38]
NDiskMonitor uses AES to encrypt certain information sent over its C2 channel.[39]
NETEAGLE will decrypt resources it downloads with HTTP requests by using RC4 with the key "ScoutEagle."[40]
Nidiran uses RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.[41]
OilRig used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.[42]
PoisonIvy uses the Camellia cipher to encrypt communications.[43]
POSHSPY encrypts C2 traffic with AES and RSA.[44]
POWERSTATS has encrypted C2 traffic with RSA.[45]
POWERTON has used AES for encrypting C2 traffic.[4]
Prikormka encrypts some C2 traffic with the Blowfish cipher.[46]
Pupy's default encryption for its C2 communication channel is SSL, but it also has transport options for RSA and AES.[47]
QuasarRAT uses AES to encrypt network communication.[48][49]
RedLeaves has encrypted C2 traffic with RC4, previously using keys of 88888888 and babybear.[50]
Remsec's network loader encrypts C2 traffic with RSA and RC6.[51]
APT12 has used the RIPTIDE RAT, which communicates over HTTP with a payload encrypted with RC4.[52]
SeaDuke C2 traffic has been encrypted with RC4 and AES.[53][54]
ServHelper may set up a reverse SSH tunnel to give the attacker access to services running on the victim, such as RDP.[55]
SNUGRIDE encrypts C2 traffic using AES with a static key.[56]
Stealth Falcon malware encrypts C2 traffic using RC4 with a hard-coded key.[57]
Taidoor uses RC4 to encrypt the message body of HTTP content.[58]
Tropic Trooper uses SSL to connect to C2 servers.[59]

Some versions of UPPERCUT have used the hard-coded string "this is the encrypt key" for Blowfish encryption when communicating with a C2. Later versions have hard-coded keys uniquely for each C2 address.[60]
Some Volgmer variants use SSL to encrypt C2 communications.[61]
XTunnel uses SSL/TLS and RC4 to encrypt traffic.[62][16]
Zebrocy uses SSL and AES ECB for encrypting C2 communications.[63][64]
ZeroT has used RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.[65][66]
mitigations: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.[70]
SSL/TLS inspection can be used to see the contents of encrypted sessions to look for network-based indicators of malware communication protocols.
permissions_required: Packet capture, Netflow/Enclave netflow, Malware reverse engineering, Process use of network, Process monitoring, SSL/TLS inspection
title: Standard Cryptographic Protocol

description: Use of a standard non-application layer protocol for communication between host and C2 server or among infected hosts within a network. The list of possible protocols is extensive. [1] Specific examples include use of network layer protocols, such as the Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP), transport layer protocols, such as the User Datagram Protocol (UDP), session layer protocols, such as Socket Secure (SOCKS), as well as redirected/tunneled protocols, such as Serial over LAN (SOL).
detection: Analyze network traffic for ICMP messages or other protocols that contain abnormal data or are not normally seen within or exiting the network.
examples: APT29 uses TCP for C2 communications.[3]
An APT3 downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.[4]
Carbon uses TCP and UDP for C2.[6]
Crimson uses a custom TCP protocol for C2.[7]
Derusbi binds to a raw socket on a random source port between 31800 and 31900 for C2.[8]
HiddenWasp communicates with a simple network protocol over TCP.[9]
Mis-Type network traffic can communicate over a raw socket.[10]
Misdat network traffic communicates over a raw socket.[10]
MoonWind completes network communication via raw sockets.[11]

If NETEAGLE does not detect a proxy configured on the infected machine, it will send beacons via UDP/6000. Also, after retrieving a C2 IP address and Port Number, NETEAGLE will initiate a TCP connection to this socket. The ensuing connection is a plaintext C2 channel in which commands are specified by DWORDs.[12]
PHOREAL communicates via ICMP for C2.[13]
PLATINUM has used the Intel® Active Management Technology (AMT) Serial-over-LAN (SOL) channel for command and control.[14]
PlugX can be configured to use raw TCP or UDP for command and control.[15]
Some Reaver variants use raw TCP for C2.[16]
The Regin malware platform can use ICMP to communicate between infected computers.[17]
Remsec is capable of using ICMP, TCP, and UDP for C2.[18][19]
WINDSHIELD C2 traffic can communicate via TCP raw sockets.[13]
mitigations: Filter network traffic to prevent use of protocols across the network boundary that are unnecessary.
Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.[20]

Properly configure firewalls and proxies to limit outgoing traffic to only necessary ports and through proper network gateway systems. Also ensure hosts are only provisioned to communicate over authorized interfaces.
permissions_required: Host network interface, Netflow/Enclave netflow, Network intrusion detection system, Network protocol analysis, Packet capture, Process use of network
title: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol

description: Per Apple’s documentation, startup items execute during the final phase of the boot process and contain shell scripts or other executable files along with configuration information used by the system to determine the execution order for all startup items [1]. This is technically a deprecated version (superseded by Launch Daemons), and thus the appropriate folder, /Library/StartupItems isn’t guaranteed to exist on the system by default, but does appear to exist by default on macOS Sierra. A startup item is a directory whose executable and configuration property list (plist), StartupParameters.plist, reside in the top-level directory.
detection: The /Library/StartupItems folder can be monitored for changes. Similarly, the programs that are actually executed from this mechanism should be checked against a whitelist. Monitor processes that are executed during the bootup process to check for unusual or unknown applications and behavior.
examples: jRAT can list and manage startup entries.[3]
mitigations: Since StartupItems are deprecated, preventing all users from writing to the /Library/StartupItems directory would prevent any startup items from getting registered.
Appropriate permissions should be applied such that only specific users can edit the startup items so that they can be leveraged for privilege escalation.
title: Startup Items

description: Adversaries may insert, delete, or manipulate data at rest in order to manipulate external outcomes or hide activity.[1][2] By manipulating stored data, adversaries may attempt to affect a business process, organizational understanding, and decision making.
detection: Where applicable, inspect important file hashes, locations, and modifications for suspicious/unexpected values.
examples: APT38 has used DYEPACK to create, delete, and alter records in databases used for SWIFT transactions.[1]

FIN4 has created rules in victims' Microsoft Outlook accounts to automatically delete emails containing words such as "hacked," "phish," and "malware" in a likely attempt to prevent organizations from communicating about their activities.[3]
mitigations: Consider encrypting important information to reduce an adversaries ability to perform tailored data modifications.

Consider implementing IT disaster recovery plans that contain procedures for taking regular data backups that can be used to restore organizational data. Ensure backups are stored off system and is protected from common methods adversaries may use to gain access and manipulate backups.[4]
Ensure least privilege principles are applied to important information resources to reduce exposure to data manipulation risk.
title: Stored Data Manipulation

description: The sudoers file, /etc/sudoers, describes which users can run which commands and from which terminals. This also describes which commands users can run as other users or groups. This provides the idea of least privilege such that users are running in their lowest possible permissions for most of the time and only elevate to other users or permissions as needed, typically by prompting for a password. However, the sudoers file can also specify when to not prompt users for passwords with a line like user1 ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL [1].
detection: On Linux, auditd can alert every time a user's actual ID and effective ID are different (this is what happens when you sudo).
mitigations: By requiring a password, even if an adversary can get terminal access, they must know the password to run anything in the sudoers file.
The sudoers file should be strictly edited such that passwords are always required and that users can't spawn risky processes as users with higher privilege.
title: Sudo

description: The sudo command "allows a system administrator to delegate authority to give certain users (or groups of users) the ability to run some (or all) commands as root or another user while providing an audit trail of the commands and their arguments." [1] Since sudo was made for the system administrator, it has some useful configuration features such as a timestamp_timeout that is the amount of time in minutes between instances of sudo before it will re-prompt for a password. This is because sudo has the ability to cache credentials for a period of time. Sudo creates (or touches) a file at /var/db/sudo with a timestamp of when sudo was last run to determine this timeout. Additionally, there is a tty_tickets variable that treats each new tty (terminal session) in isolation. This means that, for example, the sudo timeout of one tty will not affect another tty (you will have to type the password again).
detection: This technique is abusing normal functionality in macOS and Linux systems, but sudo has the ability to log all input and output based on the LOG_INPUT and LOG_OUTPUT directives in the /etc/sudoers file.
examples: Proton modifies the tty_tickets line in the sudoers file.[3]
mitigations: Similarly, ensuring that the tty_tickets setting is enabled will prevent this leakage across tty sessions.
Setting the timestamp_timeout to 0 will require the user to input their password every time sudo is executed.
title: Sudo Caching

description: Supply chain compromise is the manipulation of products or product delivery mechanisms prior to receipt by a final consumer for the purpose of data or system compromise.
detection: Use verification of distributed binaries through hash checking or other integrity checking mechanisms. Scan downloads for malicious signatures and attempt to test software and updates prior to deployment while taking note of potential suspicious activity. Perform physical inspection of hardware to look for potential tampering.
examples: CCBkdr was added to a legitimate, signed version 5.33 of the CCleaner software and distributed on CCleaner's distribution site.[6][7][1]
Elderwood has targeted manufacturers in the supply chain for the defense industry.[4]
NotPetya's initial infection vector for the June 27, 2017 compromise was a backdoor in the Ukrainian tax accounting software M.E.Doc.[8][9][10]
Smoke Loader was distributed through a compromised update to a Tor client with a coin miner payload.[2]
mitigations: A patch management process should be implemented to check unused dependencies, unmaintained and/or previously vulnerable dependencies, unnecessary features, components, files, and documentation.
Continuous monitoring of vulnerability sources and the use of automatic and manual code review tools should also be implemented as well.
title: Supply Chain Compromise

description: The BIOS (Basic Input/Output System) and The Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) or Extensible Firmware Interface (EFI) are examples of system firmware that operate as the software interface between the operating system and hardware of a computer. [1] [2] [3]
detection: System firmware manipulation may be detected. [7] Dump and inspect BIOS images on vulnerable systems and compare against known good images. [8] Analyze differences to determine if malicious changes have occurred. Log attempts to read/write to BIOS and compare against known patching behavior.
examples: Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit is a UEFI BIOS rootkit developed by the company Hacking Team to persist remote access software on some targeted systems.[4]
LoJax is a UEFI BIOS rootkit deployed to persist remote access software on some targeted systems.[5]
Trojan.Mebromi performs BIOS modification and can download and execute a file as well as protect itself from removal.[6]
mitigations: Check the integrity of the existing BIOS or EFI to determine if it is vulnerable to modification. Use Trusted Platform Module technology.
Prevent adversary access to privileged accounts or access necessary to perform this technique.
Patch the BIOS and EFI as necessary.
title: System Firmware

description: An adversary may attempt to get detailed information about the operating system and hardware, including version, patches, hotfixes, service packs, and architecture.
detection: System and network discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities based on the information obtained.
mitigations: 4H RAT sends an OS version identifier in its beacons.[1]
admin@338 actors used the following commands after exploiting a machine with LOWBALL malware to obtain information about the OS: ver >> %temp%\download systeminfo >> %temp%\download[2]
ADVSTORESHELL can run Systeminfo to gather information about the victim.[3][4]
Agent Tesla collects the system's computer name and also has the capability to collect information on the processor, memory, and video card from the system.[5][6]
APT18 can collect system information from the victim’s machine.[7]
APT19 collected system architecture information. APT19 used an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant to gather the hostname and CPU information from the victim’s machine.[8][9]
APT3 has a tool that can obtain information about the local system.[10][11]

APT32 has collected the OS version and computer name from victims. One of the group's backdoors can also query the Windows Registry to gather system information, and another macOS backdoor performs a fingerprint of the machine on its first connection to the C&C server.[12][13][14]
APT37 collects the computer name, the BIOS model, and execution path.[15]
Astaroth collects the machine name and keyboard language from the system.[16][17]

Azorult can collect the machine information, system architecture, the OS version, computer name, Windows product name, the number of CPU cores, video card information, and the system language.[18][19]
Backdoor.Oldrea collects information about the OS and computer name.[20]
During its initial execution, BACKSPACE extracts operating system information from the infected host.[21]
BADCALL collects the computer name and host name on the compromised system.[22]
BadPatch collects the OS system, OS version, MAC address, and the computer name from the victim’s machine.[23]
Bankshot gathers system information, network addresses, disk type, disk free space, and the operation system version.[24][25]
BISCUIT has a command to collect the processor type, operation system, computer name, uptime, and whether the system is a laptop or PC.[26]
Bisonal has a command to gather system information from the victim’s machine.[27]
BlackEnergy has used Systeminfo to gather the OS version, as well as information on the system configuration, BIOS, the motherboard, and the processor.[28][29]
Brave Prince collects hard drive content and system configuration information.[30]
BUBBLEWRAP collects system information, including the operating system version and hostname.[2]
Cannon can gather system information from the victim’s machine such as the OS version, machine name, and drive information.[31][32]
Cardinal RAT can collect the hostname, Microsoft Windows version, and processor architecture from a victim machine.[33]
ChChes collects the victim hostname, window resolution, and Microsoft Windows version.[34][35]
cmd can be used to find information about the operating system.[36]
Comnie collects the hostname of the victim machine.[37]
CORESHELL collects hostname, volume serial number and OS version data from the victim and sends the information to its C2 server.[38]
A system info module in CozyCar gathers information on the victim host’s configuration.[39]
Crimson contains a command to collect the victim PC name and operating system.[40]
DarkComet can collect the computer name, RAM used, and operating system version from the victim’s machine.[41][42]
Darkhotel has collected the hostname, OS version, service pack version, and the processor architecture from the victim’s machine.[43]
Denis collects OS information and the computer name from the victim’s machine.[44][45]
Derusbi gathers the name of the local host, version of GNU Compiler Collection (GCC), and the system information about the CPU, machine, and operating system.[46]
DownPaper collects the victim host name and serial number, and then sends the information to the C2 server.[47]
DustySky extracts basic information about the operating system.[48]
Elise executes systeminfo after initial communication is made to the remote server.[49]
Emissary has the capability to execute ver, systeminfo, and gpresult commands.[50]
Empire can enumerate host system information like OS, architecture, applied patches, and more.[51]
Epic collects the OS version, hardware information, computer name, available system memory status, disk space information, and system and user language settings.[52]
FALLCHILL can collect operating system (OS) version information, processor information, system name, and information about installed disks from the victim.[53]
Felismus collects the system information, including hostname and OS version, and sends it to the C2 server.[54]
FELIXROOT collects the victim’s computer name, processor architecture, OS version, volume serial number, and system type.[55][56]
Final1stspy obtains victim Microsoft Windows version information and CPU architecture.[57]
FinFisher checks if the victim OS is 32 or 64-bit.[58][59]
FlawedAmmyy beacons out the victim operating system and computer name during the initial infection.[60]
A Gamaredon Group file stealer can gather the victim's computer name and drive serial numbers to send to a C2 server.[61]
Gold Dragon collects endpoint information using the systeminfo command.[30]
GravityRAT collects the MAC address, computer name, and CPU information.[62]
HALFBAKED can obtain information about the OS, processor, and BIOS.[63]
can collect system information, including computer name, system manufacturer, IsDebuggerPresent state, and execution path.[64]
HAWKBALL can collect the OS version, architecture information, and computer name.[65]
Honeybee gathers computer name and information using the systeminfo command.[66]
HOPLIGHT has been observed collecting victim machine information like OS version, drivers, volume information and more.[67]
Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve information such as computer name, OS version, processor speed, memory size, and CPU speed.[68]
InnaputRAT gathers volume drive information and system information.[69]
InvisiMole can gather information on the mapped drives, OS version, computer name, and memory size.[70]
Ixeshe collects the computer name of the victim's system during the initial infection.[71]

JHUHUGIT obtains a build identifier as well as victim hard drive information from Windows registry key HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Disk\Enum. Another JHUHUGIT variant gathers the victim storage volume serial number and the storage device name.[72][73]
JPIN can obtain system information such as OS version and disk space.[74]
jRAT collects information about the OS (version, build type, install date) as well as system up-time upon receiving a connection from a backdoor.[75]
Kasidet has the ability to obtain a victim's system name and operating system version.[76]
Kazuar gathers information on the system and local drives.[77]
Ke3chang performs operating system information discovery using systeminfo.[78][79]
KeyBoy can gather extended system information, such as information about the operating system, disks, and memory.[80][81]
KEYMARBLE has the capability to collect the computer name, language settings, the OS version, CPU information, disk devices, and time elapsed since system start.[82]
KOMPROGO is capable of retrieving information about the infected system.[83]
KONNI can gather the OS version, architecture information, connected drives, hostname, and computer name from the victim’s machine.[84]

Kwampirs collects OS version information such as registered owner details, manufacturer details, processor type, available storage, installed patches, hostname, version info, system date, and other system information by using the commands systeminfo, net config workstation, hostname, ver, set, and date /t.[85]

Several Lazarus Group malware families collect information on the type and version of the victim OS, as well as the victim computer name and CPU information. A Destover-like variant used by Lazarus Group also collects disk space information and sends it to its C2 server.[86][87][88][89][90]
LightNeuron gathers the victim computer name using the Win32 API call GetComputerName.[91]
Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve system information.[92]

Magic Hound malware has used a PowerShell command to check the victim system architecture to determine if it is an x64 machine. Other malware has obtained the OS version, UUID, and computer/host name to send to the C2 server.[93]
Micropsia gathers the hostname and OS version from the victim’s machine.[94][95]
MirageFox can collect CPU and architecture information from the victim’s machine.[96]
The initial beacon packet for Mis-Type contains the operating system version and file system of the victim.[97]
The initial beacon packet for Misdat contains the operating system version of the victim.[97]
MobileOrder has a command to upload to its C2 server victim mobile device information, including IMEI, IMSI, SIM card serial number, phone number, Android version, and other information.[98]
MoonWind can obtain the victim hostname, Windows version, RAM amount, number of drives, and screen resolution.[99]
More_eggs has the capability to gather the OS version and computer name.[100]
MuddyWater has used malware that can collect the victim’s OS version and machine name.[101][102]
MURKYTOP has the capability to retrieve information about the OS.[103]
Naid collects a unique identifier (UID) from a compromised host.[104]
NanHaiShu can gather the victim computer name and serial number.[105]
NavRAT uses systeminfo on a victim’s machine.[106]
NDiskMonitor obtains the victim computer name and encrypts the information to send over its C2 channel.[107]
NETWIRE can discover and collect victim system information.[108]
njRAT enumerates the victim operating system and computer name during the initial infection.[109]
NOKKI can gather information on drives and the operating system on the victim’s machine.[110]
OceanSalt can collect the computer name from the system.[111]
Octopus collects system drive information, the computer name, and the size of the disk.[112]
OilRig has run hostname and systeminfo on a victim.[113][114]
OopsIE checks for information on the CPU fan, temperature, mouse, hard disk, and motherboard as part of its anti-VM checks.[115]
Orz can gather the victim OS version and whether it is 64 or 32 bit.[105]
OSInfo discovers information about the infected machine.[10]
OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D collects the MAC address, computer name, hardware UUID, serial number, and operating system version.[116]
Pasam creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve information such as hostname and free disk space.[117]

Patchwork collected the victim computer name, OS version, and architecture type and sent the information to its C2 server. Patchwork also enumerated all available drives on the victim's machine.[118][107]
Pisloader has a command to collect victim system information, including the system name and OS version.[120]
PLAINTEE collects general system enumeration data about the infected machine and checks the OS version.[121]
POORAIM can identify system information, including battery status.[64]
PoshC2 contains modules, such as Get-ComputerInfo, for enumerating common system information.[122]
PowerDuke has commands to get information about the victim's name, build, version, serial number, and memory usage.[123]
POWERSTATS can retrieve OS name/architecture and computer/domain name information from compromised hosts.[124]
POWRUNER may collect information about the system by running hostname and systeminfo on a victim.[125]
A module in Prikormka collects information from the victim about Windows OS version, computer name, battery info, and physical memory.[126]
Proxysvc collects the OS version, country name, MAC address, computer name, physical memory statistics, and volume information for all drives on the system.[90]
PUNCHBUGGY can gather system information such as computer names. [127]
Pupy can grab a system’s information including the OS version, architecture, etc.[128]
QuasarRAT has a command to gather system information from the victim’s machine.[129]
RATANKBA gathers information about the OS architecture, OS name, and OS version/Service pack.[130][131]

Reaver collects system information from the victim, including CPU speed, computer name, volume serial number, ANSI code page, OEM code page identifier for the OS, Microsoft Windows version, and memory information.[132]
RedLeaves can gather extended system information including the hostname, OS version number, platform, memory information, time elapsed since system startup, and CPU information.[35][133]
Remsec can obtain the OS version information, computer name, processor architecture, machine role, and OS edition.[134]
Revenge RAT collects the CPU information, OS information, and system language.[135]
RogueRobin gathers BIOS versions and manufacturers, the number of CPU cores, the total physical memory, and the computer name.[136]
ROKRAT gathers the computer name and checks the OS version to ensure it doesn’t run on a Windows XP or Windows Server 2003 systems.[137][138][139]
RTM can obtain the computer name, OS version, and default language identifier.[140]
RunningRAT gathers the OS version, logical drives information, processor information, and volume information.[30]
The initial beacon packet for S-Type contains the operating system version and file system of the victim.[97]
ServHelper will attempt to enumerate Windows version and system architecture.[141]
Shamoon obtains the victim's operating system version and keyboard layout and sends the information to the C2 server.[142]
SLOWDRIFT collects and sends system information to its C2.[64]
SOUNDBITE is capable of gathering system information.[83]
Sowbug obtained OS version and hardware configuration from a victim.[143]
SpeakUp uses the cat /proc/cpuinfo | grep -c "cpu family" 2>&1 command to gather system information.[144]
SslMM sends information to its hard-coded C2, including OS version, service pack information, processor speed, system name, and OS install date.[145]
Stealth Falcon malware gathers system information via WMI, including the system directory, build number, serial number, version, manufacturer, model, and total physical memory.[146]
StoneDrill has the capability to discover the system OS, Windows version, architecture and environment.  [147]
StreamEx has the ability to enumerate system information.[148]
SynAck gathers computer names, OS version info, and also checks installed keyboard layouts to estimate if it has been launched from a certain list of countries.[149]
Sys10 collects the computer name, OS versioning information, and OS install date and sends the information to the C2.[145]
Systeminfo can be used to gather information about the operating system.[150]
T9000 gathers and beacons the operating system build number and CPU Architecture (32-bit/64-bit) during installation.[151]
TrickBot gathers the OS version, CPU type, amount of RAM available from the victim’s machine.[152][153]
Tropic Trooper has detected a target system’s OS version.[154]
Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover operating system configuration details using the systeminfo and set commands.[155]
TURNEDUP is capable of gathering system information.[156]
TYPEFRAME can gather the disk volume information.[157]
Unknown Logger can obtain information about the victim computer name, physical memory, country, and date.[158]
UPPERCUT has the capability to gather the system’s hostname and OS version.[159]
Ursnif  has used Systeminfo to gather system information.[160]
VERMIN collects the OS name, machine name, and architecture information.[161]
Volgmer can gather system information, the computer name, OS version, drive and serial information from the victim's machine.[162][163][164]
WINDSHIELD can gather the victim computer name.[83]
WINERACK can gather information about the host.[64]
Wingbird checks the victim OS version after executing to determine where to drop files based on whether the victim is 32-bit or 64-bit.[165]
WinMM collects the system name, OS version including service pack, and system install date and sends the information to the C2 server.[145]
XAgentOSX contains the getInstalledAPP function to run ls -la /Applications to gather what applications are installed.[166]
Yahoyah checks for the system’s Windows OS version and hostname.[154]
yty gathers the computer name, the serial number of the main disk volume, CPU information, Microsoft Windows version, and runs the command systeminfo.[167]
Zebrocy collects the OS version, computer name and serial number for the storage volume C:. Zebrocy also runs the systeminfo command to gather system information.[168][31][169][32][170][171]
ZeroT gathers the victim's computer name, Windows version, and system language, and then sends it to its C2 server.[172]
Zeus Panda collects the OS version, system architecture, computer name, product ID, install date, and information on the keyboard mapping to determine the language used on the system.[173][174]
ZLib has the ability to enumerate system information.[97]
zwShell can obtain the victim PC name and OS version.[175]
title: System Information Discovery

description: Adversaries will likely look for details about the network configuration and settings of systems they access or through information discovery of remote systems. Several operating system administration utilities exist that can be used to gather this information. Examples include Arp, ipconfig/ifconfig, nbtstat, and route.
detection: System and network discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as Lateral Movement, based on the information obtained.
mitigations: admin@338 actors used the following command after exploiting a machine with LOWBALL malware to acquire information about local networks: ipconfig /all >> %temp%\download[1]
Agent Tesla can collect the IP address of the victim machine.[2]

Agent.btz collects the network adapter’s IP and MAC address as well as IP addresses of the network adapter’s default gateway, primary/secondary WINS, DHCP, and DNS servers, and saves them into a log file.[3]
APT1 used the ipconfig /all command to gather network configuration information.[4]
APT19 used an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant to collect the MAC address and IP address from the victim’s machine.[5]
A keylogging tool used by APT3 gathers network information from the victim, including the MAC address, IP address, WINS, DHCP server, and gateway.[6][7]
APT32 used the ipconfig /all command to gather the IP address from the system.[8]
APT39 has used nbtscan to discover vulnerable systems.[9]
Arp can be used to display ARP configuration information on the host.
Astaroth collects the external IP address from the system.[10]
Azorult can collect host IP information from the victim’s machine.[11]
Backdoor.Oldrea collects information about the Internet adapter configuration.[12]
BADCALL collects the network adapter information.[13]
Bisonal can execute ipconfig on the victim’s machine.[14]
BlackEnergy has gathered information about network IP configurations using ipconfig.exe and about routing tables using route.exe.[15][16]
Brave Prince gathers network configuration information as well as the ARP cache.[17]
Calisto runs the ifconfig command to obtain the IP address from the victim’s machine.[18]
Carbon can collect the IP address of the victims and other computers on the network using the commands: ipconfig -all nbtstat -n, and nbtstat -s.[19][20]
Catchamas gathers the Mac address, IP address, and the network adapter information from the victim’s machine.[21]
Comnie uses ipconfig /all and route PRINT to identify network adapter and interface information.[22]
Crimson contains a command to collect the victim MAC address and LAN IP.[23]
Darkhotel has collected the IP address and network adapter information from the victim’s machine.[24]
Denis uses ipconfig to gather the IP address from the system.[8]
Dragonfly 2.0 used batch scripts to enumerate network information, including information about trusts, zones, and the domain.[25]
The reconnaissance modules used with Duqu can collect information on network configuration.[26]
Elise executes ipconfig /all after initial communication is made to the remote server.[27][28]
Emissary has the capability to execute the command ipconfig /all.[29]
Empire can acquire network configuration information like DNS servers and network proxies used by a host.[30]
Epic uses the nbtstat -n and nbtstat -s commands on the victim’s machine.[31]
FALLCHILL collects MAC address and local IP address information from the victim.[32]
Felismus collects the victim LAN IP address and sends it to the C2 server.[33]
FELIXROOT collects information about the network including the IP address and DHCP server.[34]
GeminiDuke collects information on network settings and Internet proxy settings from the victim.[35]
GravityRAT collects the victim IP address, MAC address, as well as the victim account domain name.[36]
Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve IP addresses of compromised machines.[37][38]
ifconfig can be used to display adapter configuration on Unix systems, including information for TCP/IP, DNS, and DHCP.
iKitten will look for the current IP address.[39]
InvisiMole gathers informatin on the IP forwarding table, MAC address, and network SSID.[40]
ipconfig can be used to display adapter configuration on Windows systems, including information for TCP/IP, DNS, and DHCP.
Ixeshe enumerates the IP address, network proxy settings, and domain name from a victim's system.[41]
A JHUHUGIT variant gathers network interface card information.[42]
JPIN can obtain network information, including DNS, IP, and proxies.[43]
jRAT can gather victim internal and external IPs.[44]
Kazuar gathers information about network adapters.[45]
Ke3chang performs local network configuration discovery using ipconfig.[46][47]
KeyBoy can determine the public or WAN IP address for the system.[48]
KEYMARBLE gathers the MAC address of the victim’s machine.[49]
Koadic can retrieve information about the Windows domain.[50]
KONNI can collect the IP address from the victim’s machine.[51]

Kwampirs collects network adapter and interface information by using the commands ipconfig /all, arp -a and route print. It also collects the system's MAC address with getmac and domain configuration with net config workstation.[52]

Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia obtains and sends to its C2 server information about the first network interface card’s configuration, including IP address, gateways, subnet mask, DHCP information, and whether WINS is available.[53][54]
LightNeuron gathers information about network adapters using the Win32 API call GetAdaptersInfo.[55]
Magic Hound malware gathers the victim's local IP address, MAC address, and external IP address.[56]
menuPass has used several tools to scan for open NetBIOS nameservers and enumerate NetBIOS sessions.[57]
Mis-Type may create a file containing the results of the command cmd.exe /c ipconfig /all.[58]
MoonWind obtains the victim IP address.[59]
More_eggs has the capability to gather the IP address from the victim's machine.[60]
MuddyWater has used malware to collect the victim’s IP address and domain name.[62]
Naid collects the domain name from a compromised host.[63]
Naikon uses commands such as netsh interface show to discover network interface settings.[64]
NanHaiShu can gather information about the victim proxy server.[65]
NanoCore gathers the IP address from the victim’s machine.[66]
nbtstat can be used to discover local NetBIOS domain names.
Nltest may be used to enumerate the parent domain of a local machine using /parentdomain.[67]
NOKKI can gather information on the victim IP address.[68]
OceanSalt can collect the victim’s IP address.[69]
Octopus collects the host IP address from the victim’s machine.[70]
OilRig has run ipconfig /all on a victim.[71][72]
Olympic Destroyer uses API calls to enumerate the infected system's ARP table.[73]
Orz can gather victim proxy information.[65]
OSInfo discovers the current domain information.[6]
Pisloader has a command to collect the victim's IP address.[74]
PLAINTEE uses the ipconfig /all command to gather the victim’s IP address.[75]
PoshC2 can enumerate network adapter information.[76]
PowerDuke has a command to get the victim's domain and NetBIOS name.[77]
POWERSTATS can retrieve IP and network adapter configuration information from compromised hosts.[78]
POWRUNER may collect network configuration data by running ipconfig /all on a victim.[79]
A module in Prikormka collects information from the victim about its IP addresses and MAC addresses.[80]
Proxysvc collects the network adapter information and domain/username information based on current remote sessions.[81]
Pupy has built in commands to identify a host’s IP address and find out other network configuration settings by viewing connected sessions.[82]
QUADAGENT gathers the current domain the victim system belongs to.[83]
RATANKBA gathers the victim’s IP address via the ipconfig -all command.[84][85]
Reaver collects the victim's IP address.[86]
RedLeaves can obtain information about network parameters.[57]
Remsec can obtain information about network configuration, including the routing table, ARP cache, and DNS cache.[87]
Revenge RAT collects the IP address and MAC address from the system.[88]
RogueRobin gathers the IP address and domain from the victim’s machine.[89]
route can be used to discover routing configuration information.
Shamoon obtains the target's IP address and local network segment.[90]
Soft Cell used ipconfig /all to obtain information about the victim network configuration. The group also ran a modified version of nbtscan to identify available NetBIOS name servers.[91]
Stealth Falcon malware gathers the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) table from the victim.[93]
Sykipot may use ipconfig /all to gather system network configuration details.[94]
Sys10 collects the local IP address of the victim and sends it to the C2.[64]
T9000 gathers and beacons the MAC and IP addresses during installation.[95]
Threat Group-3390 actors use nbtscan to discover vulnerable systems.[96]
TrickBot obtains the IP address and other relevant network information from the victim’s machine.[97][98]

Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover network configuration details using the arp -a, nbtstat -n, nbtscan, and net config commands. Turla RPC backdoors have also retrieved registered RPC interface information from process memory.[31][99][100]
Unknown Logger can obtain information about the victim's IP address.[101]
UPPERCUT has the capability to gather the victim's proxy information.[102]
VERMIN gathers the local IP address.[103]
Volgmer can gather the IP address from the victim's machine.[104]
WannaCry will attempt to determine the local network segment it is a part of.[105]
Xbash can collect IP addresses and local intranet information from a victim’s machine.[106]
yty runs ipconfig /all and collects the domain name.[107]
ZeroT gathers the victim's IP address and domain information, and then sends it to its C2 server.[109]
zwShell can obtain the victim IP address.[110]
title: System Network Configuration Discovery

description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of network connections to or from the compromised system they are currently accessing or from remote systems by querying for information over the network.
detection: System and network discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities, such as Lateral Movement, based on the information obtained.
mitigations: admin@338 actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with LOWBALL malware to display network connections: netstat -ano >> %temp%\download[1]
APT1 used the net use command to get a listing on network connections.[2]
APT3 has a tool that can enumerate current network connections.[3][4][5]
APT32 used the netstat -anpo tcp command to display TCP connections on the victim's machine.[6]
BlackEnergy has gathered information about local network connections using netstat.[7][8]
Carbon uses the netstat -r and netstat -an commands.[9]
The discovery modules used with Duqu can collect information on network connections.[11]
Empire can enumerate the current network connections of a host.[12]
Epic uses the net use, net session, and netstat commands to gather information on network connections.[13][14]
GravityRAT uses the netstat command to find open ports on the victim’s machine.[15]
Ke3chang performs local network connection discovery using netstat.[17][18]
Kwampirs collects a list of active and listening connections by using the command netstat -nao as well as a list of available network mappings with net use.[19]
menuPass has used net use to conduct connectivity checks to machines.[20]
nbtstat can be used to discover current NetBIOS sessions.
Commands such as net use and net session can be used in Net to gather information about network connections from a particular host.[21]
netstat can be used to enumerate local network connections, including active TCP connections and other network statistics.[22]
OilRig has used netstat -an on a victim to get a listing of network connections.[23]
OSInfo enumerates the current network connections similar to  net use .[3]
PlugX has a module for enumerating TCP and UDP network connections and associated processes using the netstat command.[24]
Poseidon Group obtains and saves information about victim network interfaces and addresses.[25]
PoshC2 contains an implementation of netstat to enumerate TCP and UDP connections.[26]
POWRUNER may collect active network connections by running netstat -an on a victim.[27]
Pupy has a built-in utility command for netstat, can do net session through PowerView, and has an interactive shell which can be used to discover additional information.[28]
RATANKBA uses netstat -ano to search for specific IP address ranges.[29]
RedLeaves can enumerate drives and Remote Desktop sessions.[30]
Remsec can obtain a list of active connections and open ports.[31]
SHOTPUT uses netstat to list TCP connection status.[32]
Soft Cell used netstat -oan to obtain information about the victim network connections.[33]
Sykipot may use netstat -ano to display active network connections.[35]
Threat Group-3390 has used net use to conduct internal discovery of systems. The group has also used quser.exe to identify existing RDP sessions on a victim.[36]

Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover active local network connections using the netstat -an, net use, net file, and net session commands. Turla RPC backdoors have also enumerated the IPv4 TCP connection table via the GetTcpTable2 API call.[13][37]
Volgmer can gather information about TCP connection state.[38]
Zebrocy uses netstat -aon to gather network connection information.[39]
title: System Network Connections Discovery

data_sources: File monitoring, Process monitoring, Process command-line parameters
description: Adversaries may attempt to identify the primary user, currently logged in user, set of users that commonly uses a system, or whether a user is actively using the system. They may do this, for example, by retrieving account usernames or by using Credential Dumping. The information may be collected in a number of different ways using other Discovery techniques, because user and username details are prevalent throughout a system and include running process ownership, file/directory ownership, session information, and system logs.
detection: System and network discovery techniques normally occur throughout an operation as an adversary learns the environment. Data and events should not be viewed in isolation, but as part of a chain of behavior that could lead to other activities based on the information obtained.
mitigations: Agent Tesla collects the username from the victim’s machine.[1][2]
Agent.btz obtains the victim username and saves it to a file.[3]
APT19 used an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant to collect the victim’s username.[4]
An APT3 downloader uses the Windows command "cmd.exe" /C whoami to verify that it is running with the elevated privileges of "System."[5]
APT32 collected the victim's username and executed the whoami command on the victim's machine.[6][7]
APT39 used Remexi to collect usernames from the system.[9]
Azorult can collect the username from the victim’s machine.[10]
Backdoor.Oldrea collects the current username from the victim.[11]
BISCUIT has a command to gather the username from the system.[12]
Cannon can gather the username from the system.[13]
Cardinal RAT can collect the username from a victim machine.[14]
DarkComet gathers the username from the victim’s machine.[15]
Denis collects the username from the victim’s machine.[16]

A Linux version of Derusbi checks if the victim user ID is anything other than zero (normally used for root), and the malware will not execute if it does not have root privileges. Derusbi also gathers the username of the victim.[17]
